editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: LICENSED BY Roger L'e≈øtrange,

AN ACCOUNT OF TWO VOYAGES TO NEW-ENGLAND. Wherein you have the ≈øetting out of a Ship, with the charges; The prices of all nece≈ø≈øaries for furni≈øhing a Planter and his Family at his fir≈øt coming; A De≈øcription of the Countrey, Natives and Creatures, with their Merchantil and Phy≈øical u≈øe; The Government of the Countrey as it is now po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Engli≈øh, &c. A large Chronological Table of the mo≈øt remarkable pa≈ø≈øages, from the fir≈øt di≈øcovering of the Continent of America, to the year 1673.
By John Jo≈ø≈øelyn Gent.

q.bibl: Memner. di≈øtich rendred Engli≈øh by Dr. Heylin.
q.l: Heart, take thine ea≈øe,
Men hard to plea≈øe
Thou haply might'≈øt offend,
Though one ≈øpeak ill
Of thee, ≈øome will
Say better; there's an end.

div.p: London, Printed for Giles Widdows, at the Green-Dragon in St. Paul's-Church-yard. 1674.

TO THE RIGHT HONOURABLE, AND MOST ILLUSTRIOUS THE Pre≈øident & Fellows OF THE ROYAL SOCIETY: The following Account of Two VOYAGES TO New-England, Is Mo≈øt Humbly pre≈øented By the Authour John Jo≈ø≈øelyn.

div.head: To the Reader:

div.head: A RELATION OF TWO VOYAGES TO New-England.
The fir≈øt Voyage.
div.p: ANNO Dom. 1638. April the 26th being Thur≈øday, I came to Grave≈øend and went aboard the New Supply, alias, the Nicholas of London, a Ship of good force, of 300 Tuns burden, carrying 20 Sacre and Minion, man'd with 48 Sailers, the Ma≈øter Robert Taylor, the Merchant or undertaker Mr. Edward Tinge, with 164 Pa≈ø≈øengers men, women and children.
At Grave≈øend I began my Journal, from whence we departed on the 26. of April, about Six of the clock at night, and went down into the Hope.

The 27. being Fryday, we ≈øet ≈øail out of the Hope, and about Nine of the clock at night we came to an Anchor in Ma ‚Ä¢ garet-Road in three fathom and a half water: by the way we pa≈øt a States man of war, of 500 Tun, ca≈øt away a month before upon the Goodwin, nothing remaining vi≈øible above water but her main ma≈øt top, 16 o ‚Ä¢ her men were drowned, the re≈øt ≈øaved by Fi≈øhermen.

The 28. we twined into the Downs, where Captain Clark one of His Maje≈øties Captains in the Navy, came aboard of us in the afternoon, and pre≈øt two of our Trumpeters. Here we had good ≈øtore of Flounders from the Fi≈øhermen, new taken out of the Sea and living, which being readily gutted, were fry'd while they were warm; me thoughts I never ta≈øted of a delicater Fi≈øh in all my life before.

The Third of May being A≈øcen≈øion day, in the afternoon we weighed out of the Downs, the wind at E. and ran down into Dover Road, and lay by the lee, whil≈øt they ≈øent the Skiffe a≈øhore for one of the Ma≈øters mates: by the way we pa≈øt Sandwich in the
Hope, Sandown-Ca≈øtle, Deal, So we ≈øteered away for Donie≈ø≈øe, from thence we ≈øteered S. W. ¬Ω S. for the Beachie, about one of the clock at night the wind took us a ≈øtayes with a gu≈øt, rain, thunder and lightning, and now a Servant of one of the pa≈ø≈øengers ≈øickned of the ≈ømall pox.

The Fifth day in the afternoon we Anchored, the I≈øle of Wight W.N.W. 10 leagues off, Beachie E. N. E. 8 leagues off, rode in 32 fathom-water at low water, at 8 of the clock at night the land over the Needles bore N. W. 4 leagues off, we ≈øteered W. afore the Start, at noon the Boult was N. W. by W. about 3¬Ω leagues off, we were becalmed from 7 of the clock in the morning, till 12 of the clock at noon, where we took good ≈øtore of Whitings, and half a ≈øcore Gurnets, this afternoon an infinite number of Porpi≈øces ≈øhewed them≈øelves above water round about the Ship, as far as we could kenn, the night proved tempe≈øtuous with much lightning and thunder.
The Sixth day being Sunday, at five of the clock at night the Lizard was N. W. by W. 6 leagues off, and the Blackhead which ‚Ä¢ s to the we≈øtward of Falmouth was N. W. about 5 leagues off.
The Seventh day the uttermo≈øt part of Silly was N. E. 12 leagues off, and now we ‚Ä¢ egan to ≈øail by the logg.

The Eighth day, one Boremans man a pa≈ø≈øenger was duck'd at the main yards arm (for being drunk with his Ma≈øters ≈øtrong waters which he ≈øtole) thrice, and fire given to two whole Sacree, at that in≈øtant. Two mighty Whales we now ≈øaw, the one ≈øpouted water through two great holes in her head into the Air a great height, and making a great noi≈øe with pu≈ø≈øing and blowing, the Seamen called her a Soutler; the other was further off, about a league from the Ship, fighting with the Sword-fi≈øh, and the Flailfi≈øh, who≈øe ≈øtroakes with a fin that growes upon her back like a flail, upon the back of the Whale, we heard with amazement: when pre≈øently ≈øome more than half as far again we ≈øpied a ≈øpout from above, it came pouring down like a River of water; So that if they ≈øhould light in any Ship, ≈øhe were in danger to be pre≈øently ≈øunk down into the Sea, and falleth with ≈øuch an extream violence all whole together as one drop, or as water out of a Ve≈ø≈øel, and dured a quarter of an hour, making the Sea to boyle like a pot, and if any Ve≈ø≈øel be near, it ≈øucks it in. I ≈øaw many of the≈øe ≈øpouts afterwards at nearer di≈øtance. In the afternoon the Mariners ≈øtruck a Porpi≈øce, called al≈øo a Mar≈øovius or Sea-hogg, with an ‚Ä¢ harping Iron, and hoi≈øted her aboard,
they cut ≈øome of it into thin pieces, and fryed, it ta≈øts like ru≈øty Bacon, or hung Beef, if not wor≈øe; but the Liver boiled and ≈øou≈øed ≈øometime in Vinegar is more grateful to the pallat. About 8 of the clock at night, a flame ≈øettled upon the main ma≈øt, it was about the bigne≈øs of a great Candle, and is called by our Seamen St. Elmes fire, it comes before a ≈øtorm, and is commonly thought to be a Spirit; if two appear they progno≈øticate ≈øafety: The≈øe are known to the learned by the names of Ca≈øtor and Pollux, to the Italians by St. Nicholas and St. Hermes, by the Spaniards called Corpos Santes.

The Ninth day, about two of the clock in the afternoon, we found the head of our main ma≈øt clo≈øe to the cap twi≈øted and ≈øhivered, and we pre≈øently after found the foretop-ma≈øt crackt a little above the cap; So they wolled them both, and about two of the clock in the morning 7 new long Boat oars brake away from our Star-board quarter with a horrid crack.

The Eleventh day, they ob≈øerved and made the Ship to be in latitude 48 degrees 46 minuts, having a great Sea all night; about 6 of the clock in the morning we ≈øpake with Mr. Rupe in a Ship of Dartmouth, which came from Marcelloes; and now is Silly N. E. by E. 34 leagues off;
about 9 of the clock at night we ≈øounded, and had 85 fathom water, ≈ømall browni≈øh pepperie ≈øand, with a ≈ømall piece of Hakes Tooth, and now we are 45 leagues off the Lizard, great Seas all night, and now we ≈øee to the S. W. ≈øix tall Ships, the wind being S. W.

The Twelfth day being Whit≈øunday, at prayer-time we found the Ships trine a foot by the ≈øtern, and al≈øo the partie that was ≈øick of the ≈ømall pox now dyed, whom we buried in the Sea, tying a bullet (as the manner is) to his neck, and another to his leggs, turned him out at a Port-hole, giving fire to a great Gun. In the afternoon one Martin Jvy a ≈øtripling, ≈øervant to Captain Thomas Cammock was whipt naked at the Cap-≈øtern, with a Cat with Nine tails, for filching 9 great Lemmons out of the Chirurgeons Cabbin, which he eat rinds and all in le≈øs than an hours time.

The Thirteenth day we took a Sharke, a great one, and hoi≈øted him aboard with his two Companions (for there is never a Sharke, but hath a mate or two) that is the Pilot fi≈øh or Pilgrim, which lay upon his back clo≈øe to a long finn; the other fi≈øh (≈øome what bigger than the Pilot) about two foot long, called a Remora, it hath no ≈øcales and ≈øticks clo≈øe for the Sh ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ kes belly.
So the Whale hath the Sea-gudgeon, a ≈ømall fi≈øh for his mate, marching before him, and guiding him; which I have ≈øeen likewi≈øe. The Seamen divided the Sharke into quarters, and made more quarter about it than the Pur≈øer, when he makes five quarters of an Oxe, and after they had cooked him, he proved very rough Grain'd, not worthy of whole≈øome preferment; but in the afternoon we took ≈øtore of Bonitoes, or Spani≈øh Dolphins, a fi≈øh about the ≈øize of a large Mackarel, beautified with admirable varietie of glittering colours in the water, and was excellent food.

The Fourteenth day we ≈øpake with a Plimouth man (about dinner time) bound for New-found-land, who having gone up we≈øt-ward ≈øprang a leak, and now bore back for Plimouth. Now was Silly 50 leagues off, and now many of the pa≈ø≈øengers fall ≈øick of the ≈ømall Pox and Calenture.

The Sixteenth Mr. Clarke, who came out of the Downs with us, and was bound for the I≈øle of Providence, one of the ≈øummer I≈ølands; the Spaniards having taken it a little before, though unknown to Clarke, and to Captain Nathaniel Butler going Governour, they now departed from us the Wind N. W. great Seas and ≈øtormie winds all night.

The Seventeenth day, the wind at N. W. about 8 of the clock we ≈øaw 5 great Ships bound for the Channel, which was to the We≈øtward of us, about two leagues off, we thought them to be Flemmings; here we expected to have met with Pirates, but were happily deceived.

The One and twentieth day, the wind S. by W. great Seas and Wind fu'd our cour≈øes, and tryed from 5 of the clock afternoon, till 4 in the morning, the night being very ≈øtormie and dark; we lo≈øt Mr. G ‚Ä¢ odlad and his Ship, who came out with us, and bound for Bo≈øton in New-England.
The Eight and twentieth day, all this while a very great grown Sea and mighty winds.

June the fir≈øt day in the afternoon, very thick foggie weather, we ≈øailed by an inchanted I≈øland, ≈øaw a great deal of filth and rubbi≈øh floating by the Ship, heard Cawdimawdies, Sea-gulls and Crowes, (Birds that alwayes frequent the ≈øhoar) but could ≈øee nothing by rea≈øon of the mi≈øt: towards Sun≈øet, when we were pa≈øt the I≈øland, it cleared up.

The Fourteenth day of June, very foggie weather, we ≈øailed by an I≈øland of Ice (which lay on the Star-board ≈øide) three leagues in length mountain high, in form of
land, with Bayes and Capes like high clift land, and a River pouring off it into the Sea. We ≈øaw likewi≈øe two or three Foxes, or Devils skipping upon it. The≈øe I≈ølands of Ice are congealed in the North, and brought down in the ≈øpring-time with the Current to the banks on this ≈øide New-found-land, and there ≈øtopt, where they di≈ø≈øolve at la≈øt to water; by that time we had ≈øailed half way by it, we met with a French Pickeroon. Here it was as cold as in the middle of January in England, and ≈øo continued till we were ≈øome leagues beyond it.

The Sixteenth day we ≈øounded, and found 35 fathom water, upon the bank of New-found-land, we ca≈øt our our hooks for Cod-fi≈øh, thick foggie weather, the Codd being taken on a Sanday morning, the Sectaries aboard threw tho≈øe their ≈øervants took into the Sea again, although they wanted fre≈øh victuals, but the Sailers were not ≈øo nice, among≈øt many that were taken, we had ≈øome that were wa≈øted Fi≈øh, & it is ob≈øervable and very ≈øtrange, that fi≈øhes bodies do grow ≈ølender with age, their Tails and Heads retaining their former bigne≈øs; Fi≈øh of all Creatures have generally the bigge≈øt heads, and the fir≈øt part that begins to taint in a fi≈øh is the head.

The Nineteenth day, Captain Thomas
Cammock (a near kin≈øman of the Earl of Warwicks) now had another lad Thomas Jones, that dyed of the ≈ømall pox at eight of the clock at night.

The Twentieth day, we ≈øaw a great number of Sea-bats, or Owles, called al≈øo flying fi≈øh, they are about the bigne≈øs of a Whiting, with ≈øour tin≈øel wings, with which they fly as long as they are wet, when pur≈øued by other fi≈øhes. Here likewi≈øe we ≈øaw many Grandpi≈øces or Herringhogs, hunting the ≈øcholes of Herrings, in the afternoon we ≈øaw a great fi≈øh called the vehuella or Sword fi≈øh, having a long, ≈øtrong and ≈øharp finn like a Sword-blade on the top of his head, with which he pierced our Ship, and broke it off with ≈øtriving to get loo≈øe, one of our Sailers dived and brought it aboard.

The One and twentieth day, we met with two Bri≈øtow men bound for New-England, and now we are 100 and 75 leagues off Cape-Sable, the ≈øandy Cape, for ≈øo Sable in French ≈øignifieth, off of which lyeth the I≈øle of Sable, which is beyond New-found-land, where they take the Amphibious Creature, the Walrus, Mors, or Sea-Hor≈øe.

The Two and twentieth, another pa≈ø≈øenger dyed of a Con≈øumption. Now we pa≈ø≈øed by the Southern part of New-found-land,
within ≈øight of it; the Southern part of New-found-land is ≈øaid to be not above 600 leagues from England.

The Six and twentieth day, Capt. Thomas Cammock went aboard of a Barke of 300 Tuns, laden with I≈øland Wine, and but 7 men in her, and never a Gun, bound for Richmonds I≈øland, ≈øet out by Mr. Trelaney of Plimouth, exceeding hot weather now.
The Eight and twentieth, one of Mr. Edward Ting's the undertakers men now dyed of the Phthi≈øick.

The Nine and twentieth day, ≈øounded at night, and found 120 fathome water, the head of the Ship ≈øtruck again≈øt a rock; At 4 of the clock we de≈øcryed two ≈øail bound for New-found-land, and ≈øo for the Streights, they told us of a general Earth-quake in New-England, of the Birth of a Mon≈øter at Bo≈øton, in the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets-Bay a mortality, and now we are two leagues off Cape Aun.
The Thirtieth day proved ≈øtormie, and having lo≈øt the ≈øight of Land, we ≈øaw none untill the morning; doubtfully di≈øcovering the Coa≈øt, fearing the Lee-≈øhore all night we bore out to Sea.
July the fir≈øt day, we founded at 8 of the clock at night, and found 93 fathome water, de≈øcried land.

The Third day, we Anchored in the Bay
of Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets before Bo≈øton. Mr. Tinges other man now dyed of the ≈ømall pox.
The Tenth day, I went a ≈øhore upon Noddles I≈øland to Mr. Samuel Maverick (for my pa≈ø≈øage) the only ho≈øpitable man in all the Countrey, giving entrtainment to all Comers gratis.

Now before I proceed any further, it will not be Impertinent to give the intending planter ≈øome In≈øtructions for the furni≈øhing of him≈øelf with things nece≈ø≈øary, and for undertaking the Tran≈øport of his Family, or any others.

To which end ob≈øerve, that a Ship of 150 Tuns, with 2 Decks and a half, and 26 men, with 12 pieces of Ordnance, the charge will amount per moneth, with the Mariners, to 120 pound per moneth. It is better to let the Owners undertake for the Victualling of the Mariners, and their pay for Wages, and the Tran≈øporter only to take care of the pa≈ø≈øengers.

list.head: The common proportion of Victuals for the Sea to a Me≈øs, being 4 men, is as followeth;
list.item: Two piece of Beef, of 3 pound and ¬º per piece.
Four Gallons of Bear, with Mu≈øtard and Vinegar for three fle≈øh dayes in the week.
For four fi≈øh dayes, to each me≈øs per day.
Two pieces of Codd or Habberdine, making three pieces of a fi≈øh.
One quarter of a pound of Butter.
Three quarters of a pound of Chee≈øe.

div.p: Bear as before.
Oatmeal per day, for 50 men, Gallon 1. and ≈øo proportionable for more or fewer.
Thus you ≈øee the Ships provi≈øion, is Beef or Porke, Fi≈øh, Butter, Chee≈øe, Pea≈øe, Pottage, Water-gruel, Bisket, and ≈øix ≈øhilling Bear.

For private fre≈øh provi≈øion, you may carry with you (in ca≈øe you, or any of yours ≈øhould be ≈øick at Sea) Con≈øerves of Ro≈øes, Clove-gilliflowers, Wormwood, Green-Ginger, Burnt-Wine, Engli≈øh Spirits, Prunes to ≈øtew, Rai≈øons of the Sun, Currence, Sugar, Nutmeg, Mace, Cinnam ‚Ä¢ n, Pepper and Ginger, White Bisket, or Spani≈øh rusk, Eggs, Rice, juice of Lemmons well put up to cure, or prevent the Scurvy. Small Skillets, Pipkins, Porrengers, and ≈ømall Frying pans.
To prevent or take away Sea ≈øickne≈øs, Con≈øerve of Wormwood is very proper, but the≈øe following Troches I prefer before it.

Fir≈øt make pa≈øte of Sugar and Gum-Dragagant mixed together, then mix therewith
a rea≈øonable quantitie of the powder of Cinnam ‚Ä¢ n and Ginger, and if you plea≈øe a little Musk al≈øo, and make it up into Roules of ≈øeveral fa≈øhions, which you may gild, of this when you are troubled in your Stomach, take and eat a quantity according to di≈øcretion.

table.head: Apparel for one man, and after the rate for more.

row.cell: Seven ells of cour≈øe Canvas to make a bed at Sea for two men, to be filled with ≈øtraw
One cour≈øe Rug at Sea for two men

table.head: Victuals for a whole year to be carried out of England for one man, and ≈øo for more after the rate.

row.cell: Two bu≈øhels of Pea≈øe at three ≈øhillings a bu≈øhel
Two bu≈øhels of Oatmeal, at four and ≈øix pence the bu≈øhel

div.p: Note.

Of Sugar and Spice, 8 pound make the ≈øtone, 13 ≈øtone and an half, i. e. 100 pound maketh the hundred, but your be≈øt way is to buy your Sugar there, for it is cheape≈øt, but for Spice you mu≈øt carry it over with you.

row.cell: A Hog≈øhead of Engli≈øh Beef will co≈øt
A Hog≈øhead of Iri≈øh Beef will co≈øt
A Hog≈øhead of Aqua-vitae will co≈øt

div.p: A Kental of fi≈øh, Cod or Habberdine is 112 pound, will co≈øt if it be merchantable fi≈øh, Two or three and thirty Rials a Kental, if it be refu≈øe you may have it for 10 or 11 ≈øhillings a Kental.

row.cell: A pair of Wheels for a Cart, if you buy them in the Countrey, they will co≈øt 3 or 4 pound
Wheelbarrow you may have there' in England they co≈øt
A great pail in England will co≈øt
A Boat called a Canow, will co≈øt in the Countrey (with a pair of Paddles) if it be a good one
A ≈øhort Oake ladder in England will co≈øt but

table.head: For Tobacco pipes ≈øhort heads, and great bouls 14 pence and 16 pence the gro≈øe.

row.cell: For clipping an hundred ≈øheep in England

table.head: Arms for one man, but if half of your men have Armour it is ≈øufficient, ≈øo that all have pieces and ≈øwords.

row.cell: One long piece five foot, or five and a half near Musket bore
Sixty pound of ≈øhot or lead, pi≈øtol and Goo≈øe ≈øhot

table.head: Tools for a Family of Six per≈øons, and ≈øo after the rate for more.

row.cell: Five broad howes at two ≈øhillings a piece
Five narrow howes at 16 pence a piece
Five felling Axes at 18 pence a piece
Two ≈øteel hand ≈øawes at 16 pence the piece
One whip ≈øaw, ≈øet and filed with box
Two broad Axes at 3 ≈øhillings 8 pence a piece
Two Hatchets One and twenty pence a piece
Two froues to cleave pail at 18 pence a piece
Two hand-bills at 20 pence a piece
Nails of all ≈øorts to be valued
Three Locks, and 3 pair of Fetters
For a Brand to brand Bea≈øts with
For a Chain and lock for a Boat
For one hundred weight of Spikes
Nails and pins 120, to the hundred

table.head: Hou≈øhould Implements for a Family of ≈øix per≈øons, and ≈øo for more or le≈øs after the rate.

row.cell: For Sugar, Spice and fruits at Sea for ≈øix men

p.hi: The fraught will be for one man half a Tun.

div.p:
Having refre≈øhed my ≈øelf for a day or ‚Ä¢ wo upon Noddles-I≈øland, I cro≈ø≈øed the Bay ‚Ä¢ in a ≈ømall Boat to Bo≈øton, which then was ‚Ä¢ ather a Village, than a Town, there being
not above Twenty or thirty hou≈øes; and pre≈øenting my re≈øpects to Mr. Winthorpe the Governour, and to Mr. Cotton the Teacher of Bo≈øton Church, to whom I delivered from Mr. Francis Quarles the poet, the Tran≈ølation of the 16, 25, 51, 88, 113, and 137. P≈øalms into Engli≈øh Meeter, for his approbation, being civilly treated by all I had occa≈øion to conver≈øe with, I returned in the Evening to my lodging.

The Twelfth day of July, after I had taken my leave of Mr. Maverick, and ≈øome other Gentlemen, I took Boat for the Ea≈øtern parts of the Countrie, and arrived at Black point in the Province of Main, which is 150 miles from Bo≈øton, the Fourteenth day, which makes my voyage 11 weeks and odd dayes.
The Countrey all along as I ≈øailed, being no other than a meer Wilderne≈øs, here and there by the Sea-≈øide a few ≈øcattered plantations, with as few hou≈øes.

About the Tenth of Augu≈øt, I hapned to walk into the Woods, not far from the Sea-≈øide, and falling upon a piece of ground over-grown with bu≈øhes, called there black Currence, but di≈øtring from our Garden Currence, they being ripe and hanging in lov ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ y bunches; I ≈øet up my piece again≈øt a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ly Oake, with a re≈øolution to fill my
belly, being near half a mile from the hou≈øe; of a ≈øudden I heard a hollow thumping noi≈øe upon the Rocks approaching towards me, which made me pre≈øently to recover my piece, which I had no ≈øooner cock'd, than a great and grim over-grown ≈øhe-Wolf appears, at whom I ≈øhot, and finding her Gor-belly ≈øtuft with fle≈øh newly taken in, I began pre≈øently to ≈øu≈øpect that ≈øhe had fallen foul upon our Goats, which were then valued (our ≈øhe Goats) at Five pound a Goat; Therefore to make further di≈øcovery, I de≈øcended (it being low water) upon the Sea ≈øands, with an intent to walk round about a neck of land where the Goats u≈øually kept. I had not gone far before I found the footing of two Wolves, and one Goat betwixt them, whom they had driven into a hollow, betwixt two Rocks, hither I followed their footing, and perceiving by the Crowes, that there was the place of ≈ølaughter, I hung my piece upon my back, and upon all four clambered up to the top of the Rock, where I made ready my piece and ≈øhot at the dog Wolf, who was feeding upon the remainder of the Goat, which was only the fore ≈øhoulders, head and horns, the re≈øt being devoured by the ≈øhe-Wolf, even to the very hair of the Goat: and it is very ob≈øervable, that when
the Wolves have kill'd a Bea≈øt, or a Hog, not a Dog-Wolf among≈øt them offers to eat any of it, till the ≈øhe-Wolves have fill'd their paunches.

The Twenty fourth of September, being Munday about 4 of the clock in the afternoon, a fearful ≈øtorm of wind began to rage, called a Hurricane. It is an impetuous wind that goes commonly about the Compa≈øs in the ≈øpace of 24 hours, it began from the W. N. W. and continued till next morning, the greate≈øt mi≈øchief it did us, was the wracking of our Shallop, and the blowing down of many tall Trees, in ≈øome places a mile together.

December the Tenth, happened an Eclip≈øe of the Moon at 8 of the clock at night, it continued till after 11, as near as we could gue≈øs; in old England it began after midnight, and continued till 4 of The clock in the morning; if Seamen would make ob≈øervation of the time, either of the beginning or ending of the Eclip≈øe, or total darkne≈øs of Sun and Moon in all places where they ≈øhall happen to be, and confer their ob≈øervations to ≈øome Arti≈øt, hereby the longitude of all places might be certainly known, which are now very uncertainly reported to us.

1639. May, which fell out to be extream hot and foggie, about the middle of May I
kill'd within a ≈øtones throw of our hou≈øe, above four ≈øcore Snakes, ≈øome of them as big as the ≈ømall of my leg, black of colour, and three yards long, with a ≈øharp horn on the tip of their tail two inches in length.

June the Six and twentieth day, very ≈øtormie, Lightning and Thunder. I heard now two of the greate≈øt and fearfulle≈øt thunder-claps that ever were heard, I am confident. At this time we had ≈øome neighbouring Gentlemen in our hou≈øe, who came to welcome me into the Countrey; where among≈øt variety of di≈øcour≈øe they told me of a young Lyon (not long before) kill'd at Pi≈øcataway by an Indian, af a Sea-Serpeut or Snake, that lay quoiled up like a Cable upon a Rock at Cape-Ann: a Boat pa≈ø≈øing by with Engli≈øh aboard, and two Indians, they would have ≈øhot the Serpent, but the Indians di≈ø≈øwaded them, ≈øaying, that if he were not kill'd out-right, they would be all in danger of their lives.

One Mr. Mittin related of a Triton or Mereman which he ≈øaw in Ca≈øcebay, the Gentleman was a great Fouler, and u≈øed to goe out with a ≈ømall Boat or Canow, and fetching a compa≈øs about a ≈ømall I≈øland, (there being many ≈ømall I≈ølands in the Bay) for the advantage of a ≈øhot, was encountred
with a Triton, who laying his hands upon the ≈øide of the Canow, had one of them chopt off with a Hatchet by Mr. Mittin, which was in all re≈øpects like the hand of a man, the Triton pre≈øently ≈øunk, dying the water with his purple blood, and was no more ≈øeen. The next ≈øtory was told by Mr. Foxwell, now living in the province of Main, who having been to the Ea≈øtward in a Shallop, as far as Cape-Ann-a Waggon in his return was overtaken by the night, and fearing to land upon the barbarous ≈øhore, he put off a little further to Sea; about midnight they were wakened with a loud voice from the ≈øhore, calling upon Foxwell, Foxwell come a ≈øhore, two or three times: upon the Sands they ≈øaw a great fire, and Men and Women hand in hand dancing round about it in a ring, after an hour or two they vani≈øhed, and as ≈øoon as the day appeared, Foxwell puts into a ≈ømall Cove, it being about three quarters floud, and traces along the ≈øhore, where he found the footing of Men, Women and Children ≈øhod with ≈øhoos; and an infinite number of brands-ends thrown up by the water, but neither Indian nor Engli≈øh could he meet with on the ≈øhore, nor in the woods; the≈øe with many other ≈øtories they told me, the credit whereof I will neither impeach nor inforce, but ≈øh ‚Ä¢ ll
≈øatisfie my ≈øelf, and I hope the Reader hereof, with the ≈øaying of a wi≈øe, learned and honourable Knight, that there are many ≈øtranger things in the world, than are to be ≈øeen between London and Stanes.

September the Sixth day, one Mr. John Hickford the Son of Mr. Hickford a Linnen-Draper in Cheap≈øide, having been ≈øometime in the province of Main, and now determined to return for England, ≈øold and kill'd his ≈øtock of Cattle and Hoggs, one great Sow he had which he made great account of, but being very fat, and not ≈øu≈øpecting that ≈øhe was with pig, he cau≈øed her to be kill'd, and they ≈øound 25 pigs within her belly; verifying the old proverb, As fruitful as a white ≈øow. And now we were told of a ≈øow in Virginia that brought forth ≈øix pigs, their fore-parts Lyons, their hinder-parts hogs. I have read that at Bruxels, Anno 1564. a ≈øow brought forth ≈øix pigs, the fir≈øt whereof (for the la≈øt in generating is alwayes in bruit bea≈øts the fir≈øt brought forth) had the head, face, arms and legs of a man, but the whole trunck of the body from the neck, was of a ≈øwin ‚Ä¢ , a ≈øodomitical mon≈øter is more like the mother than the father in the organs of the vegetative ≈øoul.

The Three and twentieth, I left Black-point, and came to Richmonds I≈øland about
three leagues to the Ea≈øtward, where Mr. Tralanie kept a fi≈øhing, Mr. John Winter a grave and di≈øcreet man was his Agent, and imployer of 60 men upon that de≈øign.

The Four and twentieth day being Munday, I went aboard the Fellow≈øhip of 100 and 70 Tuns a Flemi≈øh bottom, the Ma≈øter George Luxon of Bittiford in Devon≈øhire, ≈øeveral of my friends came to bid me farewell, among the re≈øt Captain Thomas Wannerton who drank to me a pint of kill-devil alias Rhum at a draught, at 6 of the clock in the morning we weighed Anchor, and ≈øet ≈øail for the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets-bay.

The Seven and twentieth day being Fryday, we Anchored in the afternoon in the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets-bay before Bo≈øton. Next day I went aboard of Mr. Hinder≈øon, Ma≈øter of a ≈øhip of 500 Tuns, and Captain Jack≈øon in the Queen of Bohemia a privateer, and from thence I went a≈øhore to Bo≈øton, where I refre≈øhed my ≈øelf at an Ordinary. Next morning I was invited to a fi≈øhermans hou≈øe ≈øomewhat lower within the Bay, and was there by his Wife pre≈øented with a handful of ≈ømall Pearl, but none of them bored nor orient. From thence I cro≈øt the Bay to Charles-town, where at one Longs Ordinary I met with Captain Jack≈øon and others, walking on the back ≈øide we ≈øpi ‚Ä¢ d a rattle
Snake a yard and half long, and as thick in the middle as the ≈ømall of a mans leg, on the belly yellow, her back ≈øpotted with black, ru≈ø≈øet, yellow and green, placed like ≈øcales, at her tail ≈øhe had a rattle which is nothing but a hollow ≈øhelly bu≈ø≈øine≈øs joynted, look how many years old ≈øhe is, ≈øo many rattles ≈øhe hath in her tail, her neck ≈øeemed to be no bigger than ones Thumb; yet ≈øhe ≈øwallowed a live Chicken, as big as one they give 4 pence for in England, pre≈øently as we were looking on. In the afternoon I returned to our Ship, being no ≈øooner aboard but we had the ≈øight of an Indian-Pinnace ≈øailing by us made of Birch-bark, ≈øcwed together with the roots of ≈øpru≈øe and white Cedar (drawn out into threads) with a deck, and trimmed with ≈øails top and top gallant very ≈øumptuou≈øly.

The Thirtieth day of September, I went a≈øhore upon Noddles-I≈øland, where when I was come to Mr. Mavericks he would not let me go aboard no more, until the Ship was ready to ≈øet ≈øail; the next day a grave and ≈øober per≈øon de≈øcribed the Mon≈øter to ‚Ä¢ ne, that was born at Bo≈øton of one Mrs. Dyer a great Sectarie, the Nine and twentieth of June, it was (it ≈øhould ≈øeem) without a head, but having horns like a Bea≈øt, and ears, ≈øcales on a rough skin like a fi≈øh
called a Thornback, legs and claws like „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Hawke, and in other re≈øpects as a Woman-child.

The Second of October, about 9 of the clock in the morning, Mr. Mavericks Negro woman came to my chamber window, and in her own Countrey language and tune ≈øang very loud and ≈øhril, going out to her, ≈øhe u≈øed a great deal of re≈øpect towards me, and willingly would have expre≈ø≈øed her grief in Engli≈øh; but I apprehended it by her countenance and deportment, whereupon I repaired to my ho≈øt, to learn of him the cau≈øe, and re≈øolved to intreat him in her behalf, for that I under≈øtood before, that ≈øhe had been a Queen in her own Countrey, and ob≈øerved a very humble and dutiful garb u≈øed towards her by another Negro who was her maid. Mr. Maverick was de≈øirous to have a breed of Negroes, and therefore ≈øeeing ≈øhe would not yield by per≈øwa≈øions to company with a Negro young man he had in his hou≈øe; he commanded him will'd ≈øhe nill'd ≈øhe to go to bed to her, which was no ≈øooner done but ≈øhe kickt him out again, this ≈øhe took in high di≈ødain beyond her ≈ølavery, and this was the cau≈øe of her grief. In the afternoon I walked into the Woods on the back ≈øide of the hou≈øe, and happening into a
fine broad walk (which was a ≈øledg-way) I wandered till I chanc't to ≈øpye a fruit as I thought like a pine Apple plated with ≈øcales, it was as big as the crown of a Womans hat; I made bold to ≈øtep unto it, with an intent to have gathered it, no ≈øooner had I toucht it, but hundreds of Wa≈øps were about me; at la≈øt I cleared my ≈øelf from them, being ≈ølung only by one upon the upper lip, glad I was that I ≈øcaped ≈øo well; But by that time I was come into the hou≈øe my lip was ≈øwell'd ≈øo extreamly, that they hardly knew me but by my Garments.

The Tenth of October, I went aboard and we fell down to Nanta≈øcot, here Mr. Davies (Mr. Hicks the Apothecarie in Fleet-≈øtreets Son-in-law) dyed of the Phthi≈øick aboard on a Sunday in the afternoon. The next day Mr. Luxon our Ma≈øter having been a≈øhore upon the Governours I≈øland gave me half a ≈øcore very fair Pippins which he brought from thence, there being not one Apple-tree, nor Pear planted yet in no part of the Countrey, but upon that I≈øland.
The Fifteenth day, we ≈øet ≈øail from Nanta≈øcot.

The Sixteenth day Mr. Robert Fo≈øter, one of our pa≈ø≈øengers Preached aboard upon
the 113 P≈øalm; The Lord ≈øhall pre≈øerve thy going out, & thy coming in; The Sectaries began to quarrel with him, e≈øpecially Mr. Vincent Potter, he who was afterwards que≈øtioned for a Regicide.

The Seventeenth day, towards Sun-≈øet a Lanner ≈øettled upon our main Ma≈øt-top, when it was dark I hired one of the Sailers to fetch her down, and I brought her into England with much ado, being fain to feed her with hard Eggs. After this day we had very cold weather at Sea, our deck in a morning ore-≈øpread with hoarie fro≈øt, and dangling I≈øickles hung upon the Ropes. Some ≈øay the Sea is hotter in winter, than in ≈øummer; but I did not find it ≈øo.

November the Fifth day, about three of the clock in the afternoon, the Mariners ob≈øerved the ri≈øing of a little black cloud in the N. W. which increa≈øing apace, made them prepare again≈øt a coming ≈øtorm, the wind in ≈øhort time grew to boi≈øterous, bringing after us a huge grown Sea, at 5 of the clock it was pitchie dark.

l.hi: And the bitter ≈øtorm augments; the wild winds wage
War from all parts; and joyn with the Seas rage.
The ≈øad clouds ≈øink in ≈øhowers; you would have thought,
That high-≈øwoln-≈øeas even unto Heaven had wrought;
And Heaven to Seas de≈øcended: no ≈øtar ≈øhown;
Blind night in darkne≈øs, tempe≈øts, and her own
Dread terrours lo≈øt; yet this dire lightning turns
To more fear'd light; the Sea with lightning Burns.
The Pilot knew not what to chu≈øe or fly, Art ≈øtood amaz'd in Ambiguity.

div.p: The ≈øtorm augmenting ≈øtill, the next day about 4 of the clock afternoon we lo≈øt our Rudder, and with that our hopes, ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary a part it is, that a ≈øhip without it, is like a wild hor≈øe without a bridle; yet Ari≈øtotle that Eag ‚Ä¢ e-ey'd Philo≈øopher could not give a rea≈øon, why ≈øo ≈ømall a thing as a Helm ≈øhould rule the ≈øhip.

The Seventh day at night, the wind began to dye away, the next day we had lea≈øure to repair our breaches; it continued calm till the 13 day, and all the while we ≈øaw many dead bodies of men and women floating by us.
The Four and twentieth, we arrived before Bittiford, having pa≈øt before under Lundee-I≈øland.

div.head: The Second VOYAGE.
div.p:
I Have heard of a certain Merchant in the we≈øt of England, who after many great lo≈ø≈øes, walking upon the Seabank in a calm Sun-≈øhining day; ob≈øerving the ≈ømoothne≈øs of the Sea, coming ‚Ä¢ n with a chequered or dimpled wave: Ah (quoth he) thou flattering Element, many a time ha≈øt thou inticed me to throw my ≈øelf and my fortunes into thy Arms; ‚Ä¢ ut thou ha≈øt hitherto proved treacherous; ‚Ä¢ hinking to find thee a Mother of encrea≈øe, „Äà‚óä„Äâ have found thee to be the Mother of mi≈ø
‚Ä¢ hief and wickedne≈øs; yea the Father of ‚Ä¢ rodigies; therefore, being now ≈øecure, I ‚Ä¢ ill tru≈øt thee no more: But mark this ‚Ä¢ ans re≈øolution a while after, periculum maris ‚Ä¢ es lucri ≈øuperat. So fared it with me, that ‚Ä¢ aving e≈øcaped the dangers of one Voyage, ‚Ä¢ u≈øt needs put on a re≈øolution for a ≈øecond, ‚Ä¢ herein I plowed many a churli≈øh billow
with little or no advantage, but rather to my lo≈øs and detriment. In the ≈øetting down, whereof I purpo≈øe not to in≈øi≈øt in a methodical way, but according to my quality, in a plain and brief relation as I have done already; for I perceive, if I u≈øed all the Art that po≈ø≈øibly I could, it would be difficult to plea≈øe all, for all mens eyes, ears, faith, judgement, are not of a ≈øize. There be a ≈øort of ≈øtagnant ≈øtinking ≈øpirits, who, like flyes, lye ≈øucking at the botches of carnal plea≈øures, and never travelled ≈øo much Sea, as is between. Heth-ferry, and Lyon-Key; yet notwith≈øtanding, (≈øitting in the Chair of the ≈øcornful over their whi≈øts and draughts of intoxication) will de≈øperately cen≈øure the relations of the greate≈øt Travellers. It was a good provi≈øo of a learned man, never to report wonders, for in ≈øo doing, of the greate≈øt he will be ≈øure not to be believed, but laughed at, which certainly bewraies their ignorance and want of di≈øcretion. Of Fools and Mad-men then I ≈øhall take no care, I will not invite the≈øe in the lea≈øt to honour me with a glance from their ≈øupercilious eyes; but rather advi≈øe them to keep their in≈øpection for their fine-tongu'd Romances, and playes. This homely piece, „Äà‚óä„Äâ prote≈øt ingenuou≈øly, is prepared for ≈øuch only who well know how to make u≈øe of their
charitable con≈øtructions towards works of this nature, to whom I ≈øubmit my ≈øelf in all my faculties, and proceed in my ≈øecond voyage.

Anno 1663. May the Three and twentieth, I went down to Grave≈øend, it being Saturday I lay a≈øhore till Monday the fifth, about 11 a clock at night, I went aboard the Society belonging to Bo≈øton in the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets a Colony of Engli≈øh in New-England, of 200 and 20 Tun, carrying 16 Iron Guns mo≈øt un≈øerviceable, man'd with 33 ≈øailers, and 77 pa≈ø≈øengers, men, women and children.
The Six and twentieth day, about 6 of the clock in the morning we weighed Anchor, and fell down with the tide three or four miles below Grave≈øend.
The Seven and twentieth in the afternoon, we weighed Anchor and came into the Hope before Deal-Ca≈øtle, here we were wind bound till

The 30 day, we ≈øet ≈øail out of the Downs, being Saturday about 9 of the clock in the morning, about 4 of the clock ‚Ä¢ n the afternoon we came up with Beachy
‚Ä¢ y W. at Nore.

The One and thirtieth at 4 of the clock ‚Ä¢ n the morning we came up with the I≈øle of Wight, at 4 of the clock in the afternoon
we had Portland N. N. W. of us, 6. leagues off, the wind being then at N. W. by N. at 5 of the clock we came to Darimouth, the wind W. S. W.

June the fir≈øt day, being Monday about 4 of the clock Plimouth was about 9 leagues off, our cour≈øe W. S. W. the Start bore North di≈øtant about 6 leagues from whence our reckonings began; the wind now E. N. E. a fair gale.
The ≈øecond day the Lizard bore N. N. W. in the latitude 51.300 leagues from Cape-Cod in New England, our cour≈øe W. and by S. One of our pa≈ø≈øengers now dyed of a Con≈øumption.
The Fifth day we ≈øteered S. W. ob≈øerved and found the ≈øhip in latitude 47 degrees, and 44 minutes.
The Tenth day ob≈øerved and found the ≈øhip in la ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ ude 49 degrees, and 24 minutes.

The Five and twentieth day, about 3 of the clock in t ‚Ä¢ e morning we di≈øcovered land, about 6 of the clock Flowers, ≈øo called from abundance of flowers, and Corvo from a multitude of Crowes; two of the Azor ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
or we≈øtern I≈ølands, in the Atlantique Ocea ‚Ä¢
not above 250 leagues form Lisbon bo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
N. W. of us ≈øome 3 leagues off, we ≈øteere ‚Ä¢ away W. by W. ob≈øerved and found Flowe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
to be in the Southern part in latitude 39 degrees
13 minuts, we de≈øcryed a Village and a ≈ømall Church or Chappel ≈øeated in a plea≈øant valley to the Ea≈øter-≈øide of the I≈øland, the whole I≈øland is rockie and mountanious about 8 miles in compa≈øs, ≈øtored with Corn, Wine and Goats, and inhabited by outlaw'd Portingals, the Town they call Santa Cruz. Corvo is not far from this, I ≈øuppo≈øed two or three leagues, a meer mountain, and very high and ≈øteep on all ≈øides, cloathed with tall wood on the very top, uninhabited, but the Flowreans here keep ≈øome number of Goats.

The Seven and twentieth day, 30 leagues to the we≈øtward of the≈øe I≈ølands we met with a ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øel ≈øtoln from Jamaico, but 10 men in her, and tho≈øe of ≈øeveral nations, Engli≈øh, French, Scotch, Dutch almo≈øt ≈øami≈øh'd, having been out as they told us, by rea≈øon of calms, three moneths, bound for Holland.

July the ≈øixth, calm now for two or three dayes, our men went out to ≈øwim, ≈øome hoi≈øted the Shallop out and took divers Turtles, there being an infinite number of them all over the Sea as far as we could ken, and a man may ken at Sea in a clear Air 20 miles, they floated upon the top of the water being a ≈øleep, and driving gently upon them with the Shallop, of a ≈øudden
they took hold of their hinder legs and lifted them into the boat, if they be not very nimble they awake and pre≈øently dive under water; when they were brought aboard they ≈øob'd and wept exceedingly, continuing to do ≈øo till the next day that we killed them, by chopping off their heads, and having taken off their ≈øhells (that on their back being faire≈øt, is called a Gally patch) we opened the body and took out three hearts in one ca≈øe, and (which was more ≈øtrange) we perceived motion in the hearts ten hours after they were taken out. I have ob≈øerved in England in my youthful dayes the like in the heart of a Pike, and the heart of a Frog, which will leap and skip as nimbly as the Frog u≈øed to do when it was alive from whom it was taken. Likewi≈øe the heart of a Pig will ≈øtir after it is exenterated. Being at a friends hou≈øe in Cambridg-≈øhire, the Cook maid making ready to ≈ølaughter a Pig, ≈øhe put the hinder parts between her legs as the u≈øual manner is, and taking the ≈ønout in her le≈øt hand with a long knife ≈øhe ≈øtu ‚Ä¢ k the Pig and cut the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ of the heart almo≈øt in two, letting „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ as any bloud came forth, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ing of it into a Kettle of boy
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , the Pig ≈øwom twice round a
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the k ‚Ä¢ ttle, when taking of it out to
the dre≈ø≈øer ≈øhe rubd it with powdered Rozen and ≈øtript off the hair, and as ≈øhe was cutting off the hinder pettito, the Pig lifts up his head with open mouth, as if it would have bitten: well, the belly was cut up, and the entrails drawn out, and the heart laid upon the board, which notwith≈øtanding the wound it received had motion in it, above four hours after; there were ≈øeveral of the Family by, with my ≈øelf, and we could not otherwayes conclude but that the Pig was bewitched; but this by the way. Of the Sea Turtles there be five ≈øorts, fir≈øt the Trunck-turtle which is bigge≈øt, Secondly, the Loggerhead-turtle. Thirdly, the Hawkbill-turtle, which with its bill will bite horribly. Fourthly, the Green-turtle which is be≈øt for food, it is affirmed that the feeding upon this Turtle for a twelve moneth, forbearing all other kind of food will cure ab≈øolutely Con≈øumptions, and the great pox; They are a very delicate food, and their Eggs are very whole≈øome and re≈øtorative, it is an Amphibious Creature going a≈øhore, the male throws the female on her back when he couples with her, which is termed cooting, their Eggs grown to perfection the female goes a≈øhore again and making a hole in the Sand, there layes her Eggs which are numerous, I have ≈øeen a peck
of Eggs taken out of one Turtle; when they have laid they cover the hole again with ≈øand, and return to the Sea never looking after her Eggs, which hatching in the ≈øand and coming to ≈øome ≈øtrength break out and repair to the Sea. Having fill'd our bellies with Turtles and Boni ‚Ä¢ o's, called Spani≈øh Dolphins excellently well cooked both of them, the wind blowing fair,

The Eighth day we ≈øpread our ≈øails and went on our voyage, after a while we met with abundance of Sea-weeds called Gulfweed coming out of the Bay of Mexico, and firr-trees floating on the Sea, ob≈øerved and found the Ship to be in 39 degrees and 49 minuts.

The Fifteenth day we took a young Sharke about three foot long, which being dre≈øt and di≈øhed by a young Merchant a pa≈ø≈øenger happened to be very good fi≈øh, having very white fle≈øh in flakes like Codd but delicately curl'd, the back-bone which is perfectly round, joynted with ≈øhort joynts, the ≈øpace between not above a quarter of an inch thick, ≈øeparated they make fine Table-men, being wrought on both ≈øides with curious works.
The One and twentieth thick ha≈øie weather.

The Five and twentieth we met with a
Plimouth man come from St. Malloes in France, 10 weeks out, laden with cloath, fruit, and honey, bound for Bo≈øton in New-England.
The Six and twentieth we had ≈øight of land.

The Seven and twentieth we Anchored at Nanta≈øcot, in the afternoon I went aboard of a Ketch, with ≈øome other of our pa≈ø≈øengers, in hope to get to Bo≈øton that night; but the Ma≈øter of the Ketch would not con≈øent.

The Eight and twentieth being Tue≈øday, in the morning about 5 of the clock he lent us his Shallop and three of his men, who brought us to the we≈øtern end of the town where we landed, and having gratified the men, we repaired to an Ordinary (for ≈øo they call their Taverns there) where we were provided with a liberal cup of burnt Madera-wine, and ≈øtore of plum-cake, about ten of the clock I went about my Affairs.

Before I pur≈øue my Voyage to an end, I ≈øhall give you to under≈øtand what Countrie New-England is. New-England is that part of America, which together with Virginia, Mary land, and Nova-≈øcotia were by the Indians called (by one name) Wingadacoa, after the di≈øcovery by Sir Walter
Rawleigh they were named Virginia, and ≈øo remained untiil King James divided the Countrey into Provinces. New-England then is all that tract of land that lyes between the Northerly latitudes of 40 and 46, that is from De-la-ware-Bay to New-found-land, ≈øome will have it to be in latitude from 41 to 45. in King Jame's Letters Patents to the Council of Plimouth in Devon≈øhire from 40 to 48 of the ≈øame latitude, it is judged to be an I≈øland, ≈øurrounded on the North with the ≈øpacious River of Canada, on the South with Mahegan or Hud≈øons River, having their ri≈øe, as it is thought, from two great lakes not far off one another, the Sea lyes Ea≈øt and South from the land, and is very deep, ≈øome ≈øay that the depth of the Sea being mea≈øured with line and plummet, ≈øeldom exceeds two or three miles, exc ‚Ä¢ pt in ≈øome places near the Swevian-≈øhores, and about Pontus, ob≈øerved by Pliny. Sir Francis Drake threw out 7 Hogsheads of line near Porto-bello and ≈øound no bottom, but whether this be true or no, or that they were deceived by the Currants carrying away their lead and line, this is certainly true, that there is more Sea in the We≈øtern than the Ea≈øtern Hemi≈øphere, on the ≈øhore in more places than one at ≈øpringtides, that is at the full or new of the moon,
the Sea ri≈øeth 18 foot perpendicular, the rea
‚Ä¢ on of this great flow of waters I refer to the ‚Ä¢ earned, onely by the way I ≈øhall acquaint you ‚Ä¢ ith two rea≈øons for the ebbing and flow
‚Ä¢ ng of the Sea; the one delivered in Common conference, the other in a Sermon at Bo≈øton in the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets-Bay by an eminent man; The fir≈øt was, that God and his ≈øpirit ‚Ä¢ oving upon the waters cau≈øed the motion;
‚Ä¢ he other, that the ≈øpirit of the waters gathered ‚Ä¢ he waters together; as the ≈øpirit of Chri≈øt gathered Souls.

The ≈øhore is Rockie, with high cliffs, ‚Ä¢ aving a multitude of con≈øiderable Har
‚Ä¢ ours; many of which are capacious ‚Ä¢ nough for a Navy of 500 ≈øail, one of a ‚Ä¢ hou≈øand, the Countrie within Rockie and mountanious, full of tall wood, on ‚Ä¢ ≈øtately mountain there is ≈øurmounting the „Äà‚óä„Äâ , about four ≈øcore mile from the Sea: The de≈øcription of it you have in my rarities of New-England, between the mountains are many ample rich and pregnant valleys as ‚Ä¢ ver eye beheld, be≈ø ‚Ä¢ t on each ≈øide with variety of goodly Trees, the gra≈øs man-high unmowed, uneaten and u≈øel ‚Ä¢ ≈øly withering; within the≈øe valleys are ≈øpacious lakes or ponds well ≈øtored with Fi≈øh and Beavers; the original of all the great Rivers in the Countrie, of which there are many with le≈ø≈øer
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
≈øtreams (wherein are an infinite of fi≈øh) manife≈øting the goodne≈øs of the ≈øoil which is black, red-clay, gravel, ≈øand, loom, and very deep in ≈øome places, as in the valleys and ≈øwamps, which are low grounds and bottoms infinitely thick ≈øet with Trees and Bu≈øhes of all ≈øorts for the mo≈øt part, others having no other ≈øhrub or Tree growing, but ≈øpru≈øe, under the ≈øhades whereof you may freely walk two or three mile together; being goodly large Trees, and convenient for ma≈øts and ≈øail-yards. The whole Countrie produceth ≈øprings in abundance repleni≈øhed with excellent waters, having all the properties a≈øcribed to the be≈øt in the world.

l.hi: Swift is't in pace, light poiz'd, to look in clear,
And quick in b ‚Ä¢ iling (which e≈øteemed were)
Withouten the≈øe no water could be good.

div.p: One Spring there is, at Black-point in the Province of Main, coming out of muddy-clay that will colour a ≈øpade, as if hatcht with ≈øilver, it is purgative and cures ≈øcabs and Itch, &c.

The Mountains and Rocky Hills are richly ≈øurni≈øhed with mines of Lead S ‚Ä¢ lver,
Copper, Tin, and divers ≈øorts of minerals, ‚Ä¢ ranching out even to their ≈øummits, where ‚Ä¢ n ≈ømall Crannies you may meet with threds of perfect ≈øilver; yet have the Engli≈øh no ‚Ä¢ naw to open any of them, whether out of ‚Ä¢ gnorance or fear of bringing a forraign Enemy upon them, or (like the dog in the manger) to keep their Soveraign from par
‚Ä¢ aking of the benefits, who certainly may claim an intere≈øt in them as his due, being eminently a gift proceeding from divine bounty to him; PLACE="marg" I≈øa. 45.3. no per≈øon can pretend intere≈øt in Gold, Silver, or Copper by the law of Nations, but the Soveraign Prince; but the ≈øubjects of our King have a right to mines di≈øcovered in their own Lands and inheritances; So as that every tenth Tun of ≈øuch Oar is to be paid to the proprieters of ≈øuch lands, and not to the ≈øtate, if it be not a mine-Royal: if it prove to be a mine-Royal, every fifth Tun of all ≈øuch Oar as ≈øhall hold Gold or Silver worth refining, is to be rendered to the King. The learned Judges of our Kingdom have long ≈øince concluded, that alihough the Gold or Silver conteined in the ba≈øe mettals of a mine in the land of a Subj ‚Ä¢ ct, be of le≈øs value than the ba≈øer mettal; yet if the Gold or Silver do countervail the charge of refining it, or be more worth than the ba≈øe mettal ≈øpent
in refining it, that then it is a mine-Royal and as well the ba≈øe mettal as the Gold an ‚Ä¢ Silver in it belongs by prerogative to th ‚Ä¢ Crown.

The ≈øtones in the Countrey are for th ‚Ä¢ mo≈øt mettle-≈øtone, free-≈øtone, pebble, ≈ølate, none that will run to lime, of which they have great want, of the ≈ølate you may make Tables ea≈øie to be ≈øplit to the thickne≈øs of an inch, or thicker if you plea≈øe and long enough for a dozen men to ≈øit at. Pretious ≈øtones there are too, but if you de≈øire to know further of them, ≈øee the Rarities of New-England; onely let me add this ob≈øervation by the way, that Cry≈øtal ≈øet in the Sun taketh fire, and ≈øetteth dry Tow or brown Paper on fire held to it. There is likewi≈øe a ≈øort of glittering ≈øand, which is altogether as good as the gla≈ø≈øie powder brought from the Indies to dry up Ink on paper newly written. The climate is rea≈øonably temperate, hotter in Summer, and colder in Winter than with us, agrees with our Con≈øtitutions better than hotter Climates, the≈øe are limbecks to our bodies, forraign heat will extract the inward and adventitions beat con≈øume the natural, ≈øo much more heat any man receives outwardly from the heat of the Sun, ≈øo much more wants he the ≈øame inwardly, which is one rea≈øon why
they are able to receive more and larger draughts of Brandy, & the like ≈øtrong ≈øpirits than in England without offence. Cold is le≈øs tolerable than heat, this a friend to nature, that an enemy. Many are of opinion that the greate≈øt enemies of life, con≈øi≈øting of heat and moi≈øture, is cold and dryne≈øs, the extremity of cold is more ea≈øie to be endured than extremity of heat, the violent ≈øharpne≈øs of winter, than the fiery raging of Summer. To conclude, they are both bad, too much heat brings a hot Feaver, too much cold dimini≈øheth the fle≈øh, withers the face, hollowes the eyes, quencheth natural heat, peeleth the hair, and procureth baldne≈øs.

A≈øtronomers have taken ≈øpecial knowledge of the number of 1024 of the principal apparent noted Stars of all the re≈øt, be≈øides the 7 Planets, and the 12 Signs, and it is agreed upon that there are more Stars under the Northern-pole, than under the Southern, the number of Stars under both poles are innumerable to us; but not to the Almighty Creator of Heaven and Earth, who calleth them all by their names. I≈øai. 40. Levate in excel≈øum oculos ve≈øtros & videte quis creavit haec? quis educit in numero militiam eorum & omnia ≈øuis nominibus vocat? In January 1668. two Suns appeared and two Moons. The year before was publi≈øhed the Suns prerogative, vindicated by
Alexander Nowel a young ≈øtudient at Harvard-Colledge in the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets Colony, which was as followeth.

Mathematicians have that priviledge above other Philo≈øophers, that their foundations are ≈øo founded upon, and proved by demon≈øtration, that rea≈øon volens nolens mu≈øt approve of them, when they are once viewed by the eye of the intellect, ip≈øo facto it grants a probatum e≈øt; if upon tho≈øe foundations he rai≈øes famous Architectures, which are in≈øeparably joynted in, and joyned to their ground-works, yet are not their Elements of ≈øuch va≈øt exten≈øions, as to have their dimen≈øions adequated with the machine of the primum mobile, and ≈øo include the Fabrick of created beings; but there are ≈øphears above the ≈øphear of their Activity, and Orbs placed above the reach of their In≈øtruments, which will non-plus the mo≈øt acute inqui≈øitors, at lea≈øt in reference to an accurate ≈øcrutiny: hence di≈ø≈øentions about Cele≈øtial bodies, whether the planets have any natural light, has been a que≈øtion, proving that they borrow their light from the Sun: he being the primitive, they derivatives; he the Augmentum primum, they Orta, who though they have light in ≈øe, yet not ex ≈øe. This a≈ø≈øertion is not expugned by Geocentricks who produce ≈øen≈øe and Antiquity to ≈øupport their ≈øuppo≈øitions; nor oppugned by Heliocentricks,
who deduce their Hypothe≈øis from rea≈øon, and new ob≈øervations: for, quicquid in ambitu alicujus circuli actu diffu≈øum, comprehenditur, id in centro eju≈ødem continetur potentia collectum. Should I put the que≈øtion to the vote, que≈øtionle≈øs the major part of modern A≈øtronomers would carry it affirmatively; but a te≈øtimony being Inartificialis Argumentum, I ≈øhall found my po≈øition upon a more Artificial Ba≈øis. As for the multiplication of Eclip≈øes which ≈øome fear, it's needle≈øs, for the extent of the Cone of the earths ≈øhaddow (√† Centro terrae) being 250 Semidiameters, it cannot reach Mars; Venus and Mercury never oppo≈øe the Sun. It has been ob≈øerved by the help of Optick Tubes, that Venus has divers faces, according to her diver≈øe po≈øition to the Sun. Some affirm the ≈øame of Mercury, but he's not ≈øo liable to ob≈øervation, being ≈øeldom clear of the radiancy of the Sun. The ≈øuperior Planets being above the Sun, turn the ≈øame ≈øide to the Sun, as they do to us. Venus and Mars are more lucid in their Parhelion, than in their Aphelion. The Tele≈øcope may convince us of this truth; Evincit enim cra≈ø≈øa, opaca & di≈ø≈øimilium plane partium corpora, planctas e≈ø≈øe. La≈øtly God made the Sun and Moon, the two greater lights (though not the greater lucid hodies) that the Moons light is adventitions, followes from her invi≈øibilitie
in a central Eclip≈øe: hence the other planets are di≈øtitute of native light; nam √† majore ad minus valet con≈øequentia negativ√©.

In the year 1664. a Star or Comet appeared in New-England in December in the South-Ea≈øt, ri≈øing con≈øtantly about one of the clock in the morning, carrying the tail lower and lower till it came into the We≈øt, and then bare it directly before it; the Star it ≈øelf was of a duski≈øh red, the tail of the colour of via lactea, or the milkie way. A fortnight after it appeared again ri≈øing higher near the Nadir or point over our heads, of the ≈øame form and colour, of which hear the former Scholar.

Comets (≈øay Naturali≈øts) proceed from natural cau≈øes, but they oft preceed preternatural effects. That they have been Antecedents to ≈øtrange con≈øequents is an univer≈øal truth, and proved by particulars, viz. That which hung over Hieru≈øalem before its extirpation by V ‚Ä¢ ≈øpatian, that vertical to Germany, before tho≈øe bloudy Wars &c. So that experience Atte≈øts, and rea≈øon A≈ø≈øents, that they have ≈øerved for ≈øad Prologues to Tragical Epilogues. For the future, preludiums to what events they'l prove, may be proved by con≈øequence, if they han't ≈øuffered a privation of their powerful Ene ‚Ä¢ gie. Dr. Ward to ≈øalve Conte≈øts, di≈øtingui≈øhes between Cometaeidae, which are
Sublunary exhalations, and Cometae, which are heavenly bodies, coevous with the Stars; the cau≈øe of the inequality of who≈øe motion, is their Apoge and Periges. Concerning the height of the late Comets O ‚Ä¢ b, becau≈øe of the deficiency of In≈øtruments, here's pars deficiens. As for its motion December 10. 'twas about the middle of Virgo. Jan. 24.26 deg. Aries. Some ob≈øerve that Comets commonly follow a Conjunction of the ≈øuperiour planets. A≈øtronomers attribute much to the predominancy of that planet which rules it, which they judge by the Colour; a dull leaden colour, claims Saturn for his Lord; bright, Jupiter; Red, Mars; Golden, Sol; Yellow, Venus; variable, Mercury; pale, Luna. Al≈øo to the A≈øpects it receives from other planets, the ≈øign it is in, and the hou≈øe of the Heavens in which it fir≈øt was. Hence ≈øome may judge a ≈øcheam of the Heavens nece≈ø≈øary, but unle≈øs Calculated for its certain ri≈øe (which is uncertain) it's adjudged by the judicious, ≈øuperfluous. Some put much tru≈øt or virtue in the tail, terming it the Ignomon, &c. But that is probable of all, which has been ob≈øerved of ≈øome, that it's alwayes oppo≈øite to the Sun; hence when the Sun is at the Meridian of the Antipodes it turns, &c. Which Regiomont ob≈øerved of that in 1475. and Keckerman of that in 1607. Longomontanus ob≈øerves of that in 1618. that its fir≈øt
appearance was vertical to Germany and went Northward, ≈øo its effect began there, and made the like progre≈øs: it's rational, that as a cau≈øe, it ≈øhould operate mo≈øt powerfully on tho≈øe in who≈øe Zenith it is, as the meridional Altitude; nor is it irrational, that as a ≈øign, it ≈øhould pre≈øage ≈øomewhat to all tho≈øe, in who≈øe Horizon it appears; for in rea≈øon, Relata ≈øe mutuo inferunt, hence ≈øignum infers ≈øignatum, and the ≈øignifier implies a ≈øignified. Diver≈øe de≈øire to be certified of the event; but he is wi≈øe that knowes it. Some pre≈øume prophetically to ≈øpecificate from generals truths; others de≈øperately deny generals and all; of al whom it's a truth, Incidunt in Scyllam, &c. Noble Ticho concludes, (with whom I conclude) that it's not rational particularly to determine the ≈øequel; for ≈øhould any, it would be only in a c ‚Ä¢ ntingent Axiom, and proceed from fancie; therefore of no nece≈ø≈øary con≈øequence, and would produce only opinion.

A friend of mine ≈øhewed me a ≈ømall Treati≈øe written and printed in the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets-Bay by B. D. Intituled An A≈øtronomical de≈øcription of the late Comet, or Blazing-Star, as it appeared in New England in the Ni ‚Ä¢ th, T ‚Ä¢ nth, Eleventh, and the beginning o ‚Ä¢ the Twelfth moneth, 1664. printed at Cambridge by Samuel Green 1665. An ingenious pi ‚Ä¢ ce, but becau≈øe I could not per≈øwad ‚Ä¢
my friend to part with it, I took out ≈øome ≈øhort notes being ≈øtraitned in time, which are as followes.

Comets are di≈øtingui≈øhed in re≈øpect of their figure, according to the divers a≈øpects of the Sun, into Barbate, Caudate, and Crinite.
1. When the ≈øtream like a beard goes before the body.
2. When the ≈øtream followes the body.
3. When the ≈øtream goes right up into the Heavens.
A Comet is ≈øaid to be Vertical to any people, when the body of the Comet pa≈ø≈øeth over their heads.
The light of the Comet alters and varies according to the diver≈øe A≈øpects of the Sun enlightning it.
Some took notice of it in the beginning of November.
In Anno Dom. 1668. July the Fifteenth happened an Eclip≈øe of the moon from 9 of the clock at night, till after 11, digits 9, and 35 minutes.
In November following appeared a Star between the horns of the Moon in the mid≈øt.
In Anno Dom. 1669. about the middle of June at 4 of the clock in the afternoon, appeared a Rain-bow rever≈øt, and at night about 10 of the clock we had a Lunar Rain-bow.

The Indians ≈øo far as I could perceive have but little knowledge of the Stars and Planets, ob≈øerving the Sun and Moon only, the dividers of time into dayes and years: they being nearer to the Equinoctial-line by 10 degrees, have their dayes and nights more equally divided, being in Summer two hours ≈øhorter, in Winter two hours longer than they are in England The 11 of June the Sun ri≈øeth at 4 and 26 minu ‚Ä¢ es, and ≈øetteth at 7 & 34 minutes: in December, the 13 the ≈øhorte≈øt day, the Sun ri≈øeth at 7 and 35 minutes, and ≈øetteth at 4 and 27 minutes.

Mid-March their Spring begins, in April they have Rain a ‚Ä¢ d Thunder; So again at Michaelmas, about which ≈øea≈øon they have either before Michaelmas or after outrageous ≈øtorms of Wind and Rain. It's ob≈øervable that there is no part of the World, which hath not ≈øome certain times of our-rageous ≈øtorms. We have upon our Coa≈øt in England a Michaelmas flaw, that ≈øeldom fails: in the We≈øt-Indies in Augu≈øt and September the forcible North-wind, which though ≈øome call Tuffins or Hurricanes we mu≈øt di≈øtingui≈øh, for a right Hurricane is (as I have ≈øaid before) an impetuous wind that goes about the Compa≈øs in the ≈øpace of 24 hours, in ≈øuch a ≈øtorm the Lord Willoughby
of Parham Governour of the Barbadoes was ca≈øt away, going with a Fleet to recover St. Chri≈øtophers from the French, Anno Dom. 1666. July. Cold weather begins with the middle of November, the winter's perpetually freezing, in≈øomuch that their Rivers and ≈øalt-Bayes are frozen over and pa≈ø≈øable for Men, Hor≈øe, Oxen and Carts: Aequore cum gelido zephyrus fer ‚Ä¢ xenia Cymbo. The North-we≈øt wind is the ≈øharpe≈øt wind in the Countrie. In England mo≈øt of the cold winds and weathers come from the Sea, and tho≈øe ≈øeats that are neare≈øt the Sea-coa≈øts in England are accounted unwhol≈øome, but not ≈øo in New England, for in the extremity of winter the North-Ea≈øt and South-wind coming from the Sea produceth warm weather, only the North-We≈øt-wind coming over land from the white mountains (which are alwayes (except in Augu≈øt) covered with ≈ønow) is the cau≈øe of extream cold weather, alwayes accompanied with deep ≈ønowes and bitter fro≈øts, the ≈ønow for the mo≈øt part four and ≈øix foot deep, which melting on the ≈øuperficies with the heat of the Sun, (for the mo≈øt part ≈øhining out clearly every day) and freezing again in the night makes a cru≈øt upon the ≈ønow ≈øufficient to bear a man walking with ≈ønow-≈øhoos upon it. And at this
≈øea≈øon the Indians go forth on hunting of Dear and Moo≈øe twenty, thirty, forty miles up into the Countrie. Their Summer is hot and dry proper for their Indian Wheat; which thrives be≈øt in a hot and dry ≈øea≈øon, the skie for the mo≈øt part Summer and Winter very clear and ≈øerene; if they ≈øee a little black cloud in the North-We≈øt, no bigger than a man may cover with his Hat, they expect a following ≈øtorm, the cloud in ≈øhort time ≈øpreading round about the Horizon accompanied with violent gu≈øts of wind, rain, and many times lightning and terrible thunder. In all Countries they have ob≈øervations how the weather will fall out, and the≈øe rules following are ob≈øervable in New-England. If the Moon look bright and fair, look for fair weather, al≈øo the appearing of one Rainbow after a ≈øtorm, is a known ≈øign of fair weather; if mi≈øts come down from the Hills, or de≈øcend from the Heavens, and ≈øettle in the valleys, they promi≈øe fair hot weather; mi≈øts in the Evening ≈øhew a fair hot day on the morrow: the like when mi≈øts ri≈øe from waters in the Evening. The ob≈øcuting of the ≈ømaller Stars is a certain ≈øign of Tempe≈øts approaching; the oft changing of the wind is al≈øo a fore-runner of a ≈øtorm; the re≈øounding of the Sea from the ≈øhore, and murmuring of
the winds in the woods without apparent wind, ≈øheweth wind to follow: ≈øhooting of the Stars (as they call it) is an u≈øual ≈øign of wind from that quarter the Star came from. So look whether the re≈øounding of the Sea upon the ≈øhore be on the Ea≈øt or We≈øt ≈øide of the dwelling, out of that quarter will the wind proceed the next day. The redne≈øs of the sky in the morning, is a token of winds, or rain or both: if the Circles that appear about the Sun be red and broken, they portend wind; if thick and dark, wind, ≈ønow and rain; the like may be ≈øaid of the Circles about the moon. If two rainbow ‚Ä¢ s appear, they are a ≈øign of rain; If the Sun or Moon look pale, look for rain; if a dark cloud be at Sun ri≈øing, in which the Sun ≈øoon after is hid, it will di≈ø≈øolve it, and rain will follow; nebula a≈øcendens indicat imbres, nebula de≈øcendens ≈øerenitatem. If the Sun ≈øeem greater in the Ea≈øt, than in the We≈øt about Sun-≈øetting, and that there appears a black cloud, you may expect rain that night, or the day following.

Sed ≈øi mane rubet venturos indicat Imbres.

div.p: To conclude; if the white hills look clear and con≈øpicuous, it is a ≈øign of fair weather; if black and cloudy, of rain; if yellow, it is a certain ≈øign of ≈ønow ≈øhortly to en≈øue.

In Anno Dom. 1667. March, appeared a ≈øign in the Heavens in the form of a Sphear, pointing directly to the We≈øt: and in the year following on the third day of April being Friday, there was a terrible Earthquake, before that a very great one in 1638. and another in 58 and in 166 ‚Ä¢ /3. January 26, 27, & 28. (which was the year before I came thither) there were Earthquakes 6 or 7 times in the ≈øpace of three dayes. Earthquakes are frequent in the Countrie; ≈øome ≈øuppo≈øe that the white mountains were fir≈øt rai≈øed by Earthquakes, they are hollow as may be gue≈ø≈øed by the re≈øounding of the rain upon the level on the top. The Indians told us of a River who≈øe cour≈øe was not only ≈øtopt by an Earthquake in 1668. (as near as I can remember) but the whole River ≈øwallowed up. And I have heard it reported from credible per≈øons, that (whil≈øt I was there in the Countrie) there happened a terr ‚Ä¢ ble Earthquake among≈øt the French, rending a huge Rock a≈øunder even to the center, wherein was a va≈øt hollow of an immea≈øurable depth, out of which came many infernal Spirits. I ≈øhall
conclude this di≈øcour≈øe of Earthquakes, with that which came from the Pen of our Royal Martyr King Charles the Fir≈øt; A ≈øtorm at Sea wants not its terrour, but an Earthquake, ≈øhaking the very foundation of all, the World hath nothing more of horrour. And now I come to the plants of the Countrie.

The plants in New England for the variety, number, beauty, and vertues, may ≈øtand in Competition with the plants of any Countrey in Europe. John≈øon hath added to Gerard's Herbal 300. and Parkin≈øon mentioneth many more; had they been in New England they might have found 1000 at lea≈øt never heard of nor ≈øeen by any Engli≈øhman before: 'Tis true, the Countrie hath no Bonerets, or Tartarlambs, no glittering coloured Tuleps; but here you have the American Mary Gold, the Earth-nut bearing a princely Flower, the beautiful leaved Pirola, the honied Colibry, &c. They are generally of (≈øomewhat) a more ma≈øculine vertue, than any of the ≈øame ≈øpicies in England, but not in ≈øo terrible a degree, as to be mi≈øchievous or ineffectual to our Engli≈øh bodies. It is affirm by ≈øome that no forraign. Drugg or Simple can be ≈øo proper to Engli≈øhmen as their own, for the quantity of Opium which Turks do ≈øafely take will kill four Engli≈øhmen, and that which will
≈øalve their wounds within a day, will not recure an Engli≈øhman in three. To which I an≈øwer that it is cu≈øtom that brings the Turks to the familiar u≈øe of Opium. You may have heard of a Taylor in Kent, who being afflicted with want of ≈øleep ventured upon Opium, taking at fir≈øt a grain, and increa≈øing of it till it came to an ounce, which quantitie he took as familiarly as a Turk, without any harm, more than that he could not ≈øleep without it. The Engli≈øh in New-England take white Hellebore, which operates as fairly with them, as with the Indians, who ≈øteeping of it in water ≈øometime, give it to young lads gathered together a purpo≈øe to drink, if it come up they force them to drink again their vomit, (which they ≈øave in a Birchen-di≈øh) till it ≈øtayes with them, & he that gets the victory of it is made Captain of the other lads for that year. There is a plant likewi≈øe, called for want of a name Clownes wound wort by the Engli≈øh, though it be not the ≈øame, that will heal a green wound in 24 hours, if a wi≈øe man have the ordering of it. Thus much for the general, I ≈øhall now begin to di≈øcover unto you the plants more particularly, and I ≈øhall fir≈øt begin with Trees, and of them, fir≈øt with ≈øuch as are called in Scripture Trees of God, that is great
Trees, that grow of them≈øelves without planting. P≈øal. 104.16, 17. Satiantur arbores Jehovae, cedri libani quas plantavit; (ubi aviculae nidificent) abietes domicilia ciconiae. The Herons take great delight to ≈øit basking upon the tops of the≈øe Trees. And I ≈øhall not be over large in any, having written of them in my Treati≈øe of the rarities of New England, to which I refer you.

The Oake I have given you an account of, and the kinds; I ≈øhall add the ordering of Red Oake for Wain≈øcot. When they have cut it down and clear'd it from the branches, they pitch the body of the Tree in a muddy place in a River, with the head downward for ≈øome time, afterwards they draw it out, and when it is ≈øea≈øoned ≈øufficiently, they ≈øaw it into boards for Wain≈øcot, and it will branch out into curious works.

There is an admirable rare Creature in ≈øhape like a Buck, with Horns, of a gummy ≈øub≈øtance, which I have often found in the fall of the leaf upon the ground among≈øt the withered leaves; a living Creature I cannot call it; having only the ≈øign of a mouth and eyes: ≈øeldom or never ≈øhall you meet with any of them whole, but the head and horns, or the hinder parts, broken off from the re≈øt; the Indians call them Tree Bucks, and have a ≈øuper≈øtitious ≈øaying (for I believe
they never ≈øee any of them living) that if they can ≈øee a Tree-Buck walking upon the branches of an Oake when they go out in a morning to hunt, they ≈øhall have good luck that day. What they are good for I know not, but certainly there is ≈øome more than ordinary vertue in them. It is true that nothing in nature is ≈øuperfluous, and we have the Scripture to back it, that God created nothing in vain. The like Creatures they have at the Barbadoes which they call Negroes heads, found in the Sands, about two inches long, with forehead, eyes, no≈øe, mouth, chin, and part of the neck, they are alwayes found loo≈øe in the Sands without any root, it is as black as Jet, but whence it comes they know not. I have read likewi≈øe, that in the Canaries or Fortunate-I≈ølands, there is found a certain Creature, which Boys bring home from the mountains as oft as they would, and named them Tude≈øquels, or little Germans: for they were dry'd dead Carca≈øes, almo≈øt three footed, which any boy did ea≈øily carry in one of the palms of his hand, and they were of an humane ≈øhape; but the whole dead Carca≈øe was clearly like unto Parchment, and their bones were flexible, as it were griftles: again≈øt the Sun, al≈øo, their bowels and inte≈øtines were ≈øeen. Surely (≈øaith my Authour) the de≈øtroyed race of the Pigmies was there. There is
al≈øo many times ≈øound upon the leaves of the Oake a Creature like a Frog, being as thin as a leaf, and tran≈øparent, as yellow as Gold, with little fiery red eyes, the Engli≈øh call them Tree-frogs or Tree-toads (but of Tree-toads I ≈øhall have occa≈øion to ≈øpeak in another place) they are ≈øaid to be venemous, but may be ≈øafely u≈øed, being admirable to ≈øtop womens over-flowing cour≈øes hung about their necks in a Taffe ‚Ä¢ ie bag.

Captain Smith writes that in New-England there growes a certain berry called Kermes, worth 10 ≈øhillings a pound, and had been formerly ≈øold for 30 or 40 ≈øhillings a pound, which may yearly be gathered in good quantity. I have ≈øought for this berry, he ≈øpeaks of, as a man ≈øhould ≈øeek for a needle in a bottle of Hay, but could never light upon it; unle≈øs that kind of Solomon ≈øeal called by the Engli≈øh Treacle-berry be it. Gera ‚Ä¢ d our famous Herbali≈øt writes that they grow upon a little Tree called Scarlet-Oake, the leaves have one ≈øharp prickle at the end of it; it beareth ≈ømall Acorns: But the grain or ‚Ä¢ erry growes out of the woody branches, like an excre≈øcence of the ≈øub≈øtance of the Oake-Apple, and of the bigne≈øs of Pea≈øe, at fir≈øt white, when ripe of an A≈øh-colour, which ingenders little Maggots, which when it begins
to have wings are put into a bag and boulted up and down till dead, and then made up into lumps, the Maggot as mo≈øt do deem is Cutchenele; So that Chermes is Cutchenele: the berries dye ≈øcarlet. Mr. George Sands in his Travels ≈øaith (much to the ≈øame purpo≈øe) that ≈øearlet dye growes like a bli≈øter on the leaf of the Holy Oake, a little ≈øhrub, yet producing Acorns, being gathered they rub out of it a certain red du≈øt, that converteth after a while into worms, which they kill with Wine, when they begin to quicken. See farther concerning Treacle-berries and Cutchinele in the rarities of New-England.

The Pine-Tree challengeth the next place, and that ≈øort which is called Boardpine is the principal, it is a ≈øtately large Tree, very tall, and ≈øometimes two or three fadom about: of the body the Engli≈øh make large Canows of 20 foot long, and two foot and a half over, hollowing of them with an Adds, and ≈øhaping of the out≈øide like a Boat. Some conceive that the wood called Gopher in Scripture, of which Noah made the Ark, was no other than Pine, Gen. 6.14. The bark thereof is good for Ulcers in tender per≈øons that refu≈øe ≈øharp medicines. The inner bark of young board-pine cut ≈ømall and ≈øtampt and boiled in a Gallon of water is a very ≈øoveraign medicine for burn
or ≈øcald, wa≈øhing the ≈øore with ≈øome of the decoction, and then laying on the bark ≈øtampt very ≈øoft: or for frozen limbs, to take out the fire and to heal them, take the bark of Board-pine-Tree, cut it ≈ømall and ≈øtamp it and boil it in a gallon of water to Gelly, wa≈øh the ≈øore with the liquor, ≈øtamp the bark again till it be very ≈øoft and bind it on. The Turpentine is excellent to heal wounds and cuts, and hath all the properties of Venice Turpentine, the Ro≈øen is as good as Frankincen≈øe, and the powder of the dryed leaves generateth fle≈øh; the di≈øtilled water of the green Cones taketh away wrinkles in the face being laid on with Cloths.

The Firr-tree is a large Tree too, but ≈øeldom ≈øo big as the Pine, the bark is ≈ømooth, with knobs or bli≈øters, in which lyeth clear ‚Ä¢ iquid Turpentine very good to be put into ≈øalves and oyntments, the leaves or Cones boiled in Beer are good for the Scurvie, the young buds are excellent to put into Epithemes for Warts and Corns, the Ro≈øen is altogether as good as Frank ‚Ä¢ ncen≈øe; out of this Tree the Poleakers draw Pitch and Tarr; the manner I ≈øhall give you, for that ‚Ä¢ t may (with many other things contained ‚Ä¢ n this Treati≈øe) be beneficial to my Coun
‚Ä¢ rymen, either there already ≈øeated, or that
may happen to go thither hereafter. Out of the fatte≈øt wood changed into Torchwood, which is a di≈øea≈øe in that Tree they draw Tarr, fir≈øt a place mu≈øt be paved with ≈øtone or the like, a little higher in the middle, about which there mu≈øt be made gutters, into which the liquor falls, then out from them other gutters are to be drawn, by which it may be received, then is it put into barrels. The place thus prepared, the cloven wood mu≈øt be ≈øet upright, then mu≈øt it be covered with a great number of ≈øin and pitch bowes; and on every part all about with much lome and ≈øods of earth, and great heed mu≈øt be taken, le≈øt there be any cleft or chink remaining, only a hole left in the top of the furnace, through which the fire may be put in, and the flame and ≈ømoak to pa≈øs out: when the fire burneth, the Pitch or Tarr runneth forth fir≈øt thin, and then thicker; of which when i ‚Ä¢ is bo ‚Ä¢ led is made Pitch: the powder o ‚Ä¢ dried Pitch is 'u≈øed to generate fle≈øh in wounds and ≈øores. The knots of this Tree and ≈øat-pine are u≈øed by the Engli≈øh in≈øtead of Candles, and it will burn a long time but it makes the people pale.

The Spruce-tree I have given you an account of in my New-England ra ‚Ä¢ ities. I ‚Ä¢ the N ‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢ h-ea≈øt of Scotland upon the bank
