of Lough-argick, there hath been formerly of the≈øe Trees 28 handful about at the Root, and their bodies mounted to 90 foot of height, bearing at the length 20 inches diameter. At Pu≈øcataway there is now a Spruce-tree brought down to the water≈øide by our Ma≈øs-men of an incredible bigne≈øs, and ≈øo long that no Skipper dur≈øt ever yet adventure to ≈øhip it, but there it lyes and Rots.

The Hemlock-tree is a kind of ≈øpruce or pine; the bark boiled and ≈øtampt till it be very ≈øoft is excellent for to heal wounds, and ≈øo is the Turpentine thereof, and the Turpentine that i≈ø≈øueth from the Cones of the Larch-tree, (which comes neare≈øt of any to the right Turpentine) is ≈øingularly good to heal wounds, and to draw out the malice (or Thorn, as Helmont phra≈øes is) of any Ach, rubbing the place therewith, and ≈øtrowing upon it the powder of Sage-leaves.

The white Cedar is a ≈øtately Tree, and is taken by ≈øome to be Tamarisk, this Tree the Engli≈øh ≈øaw into boards to floor their Rooms, for which purpo≈øe it is excellent, long la≈øting, and wears very ≈ømooth and white; likewi≈øe they make ≈øhingles to cover their hou≈øes with in≈øtead of tyle, it will never warp. This Tree, the Oak and the
Larch-tree are be≈øt for building. Ground≈øels made of Larch-tree will never rot, and the longer it lyes the harder it growes, that you may almo≈øt drive a nail into a bar of Iron as ‚Ä¢ a≈øily as into that. Oh, that my Countreymen might obtain that ble≈ø≈øing with their buildings, which E≈øay prophe≈øied to the Jewes in the 65 Chapter and 22 ver≈øe. Non aedificabunt & alius inhabitabit, non plantabunt & alius comedet: ≈øed ut ≈øun ‚Ä¢ dies Arboris, dies erunt populi mei, & opus manuum ≈øuarum deterent electi mei.

The Sa≈ø≈øafras-tree is no great Tree, I have met with ≈øome as big as my middle, the rind is tawny and upon that a thin colour of A≈øhes, the inner part is white, of an excellent ≈ømell like Fennel, of a ≈øweet ta≈øt with ≈øome bitterne≈øs; the leaves are like Fig-leaves of a dark green. A decoction of the Roots and bark thereof ≈øweetned with Sugar, and drunk in the morning fa≈øting will open the body and procure a ≈øtool or two, it is good for the Scurvie taken ≈øome time together, and laying upon the legs the green leaves of white. Hellebore. They give it to Cows that have newly cal
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d to make them ca≈øt their Cleanings. „Äà‚óä„Äâ Tree growes not beyond Black-point
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ward: it is ob≈øerved, that there is no „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Trees and plants not „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ gions.

The Walnut which is divers, ≈øome bearing ≈øquare nuts, others like ours, but ≈ømaller: there is likewi≈øe black Walnut of precious u≈øe for Tables, Cabinets and the like. The Walnut-tree is the toughe≈øt wood in the Countrie, and therefore made u≈øe of for Hoops and Bowes, there being no Yew there growing; In England they made their Bowes u≈øually of Witch, Ha≈øel, A≈øh, Yew, the be≈øt of outlandi≈øh Elm, but the Indians make theirs of Walnut.

The Line-tree with long nuts, the other kind I could never find: the wood of this Tree, Laurel, Rhamnus, Holly and Ivy are accounted for woods that cau≈øe fire by attrition; Laurel and Ivy are not growing in New-England: the Indians will rub two ≈øear'd ≈øticks of any ≈øort of wood, and kindle a fire with them pre≈øently.
The Maple-tree, on the boughs of this Tree I have often found a jellied ≈øub≈øtance like Jewes-Ears, which I found upon tryal to be as good for fore throats &c.

The Birch-tree is of two kinds, ordinary Birch, and black Birch, many of the≈øe Trees are ≈øtript of their bark by the Indians, who make of it their Canows, Kettles,
and Birchen-di≈øhes: there is an excre≈øcence growing out of the body of the Tree called ≈øpunck, or dead mens Caps, it growes at the Roots of A≈øh, or Beech, or Elm; but the be≈øt is that which growes upon the black B ‚Ä¢ rch, this boiled and beaten, and then dried in an Oven maketh excellent Touchwood, and Balls to play with.

Alder, of which wood there is abundance in the wet ≈øwamps: the bark thereof with the yolke of an Egg is good for a ≈øtrain; an Indian brui≈øing of his knee, chew'd the bark of Alder fa≈øting and laid it to, which quickly helped him. The wives of our We≈øt-Countrey Engli≈øh make a drink with the ≈øeeds of Alder, giving it to their Children troubled with the Alloes. I have talk'd with many of them, but could never apprehend what di≈øea≈øe it ≈øhould be they ≈øo name, the≈øe Trees are called by ≈øome Sullinges.

The Indians tell of a Tree that growes for up in the land, that is as big as an Oake, that will cure the falling-≈øickne≈øs infallibly, what part thereof they u≈øe, Bark, Wood, leaves or fruit, I could never learn; they promi≈øed often to bring of it to me, but did not. I have ≈øeen a ≈øtately Tree growing here and there in valleys, not like to any Trees in Europe, having a ≈ømooth bark of
a dark brown colour, the leaves like great Maple, in England called Sycamor, but larger, it may be this is the Tree they brag of.

Thus much concerning Trees, now I ≈øhall pre≈øent to your view the Shrubs; and fir≈øt of the Sumach Shrub, which as I have told you in New-Englands rarities, differeth from all the kinds ≈øet down in our Engli≈øh Herbal ‚Ä¢ the root dyeth wool or cloth reddi≈øh, ‚Ä¢ he decoction of the leaves in wine drunk, is good for all Fluxes of the belly in man or woman, the whites, &c. For galled places ≈øtamp the leaves with honey, and apply it, nothing ≈øo ≈øoon healeth a wound in the head as Sumach ≈øtampt and applyed once in three dayes, the powder ≈øtrewed in ≈øtayeth the bleeding of wounds: The ≈øeed of Sumach pounded and mixt with honey, healeth the Hemorrhoids, the gum put into a hollow tooth a≈ø≈øwageth the pain, the bark or berries in the fall of the leaf, is as good as galls to make Ink of.

Elder in New-England is ≈øhurubbie, & dies once in two years: there is a ≈øort of dwar≈ø-Elder that growes by the Sea-≈øide that hath a red pith, the berries of both are ≈ømaller than Engli≈øh-Elder, not round but corner'd, neither of them ≈ømall ≈øo ≈øtrong as ours.

Juniper growes for the mo≈øt part by the Sea-≈øide, it bears abundance of skie-coloured
berries fed upon by Partridges, and hath a woodie root, which induceth me to believe that the plant mention'd in Job 30.4. Qui decerpebant herbas √© ≈øal≈øilagine cum ≈øt ‚Ä¢ rpibus; etiam radices Juniperorum cibo erant iliis, was our Indian plant Ca≈ø≈øava. They write that Juniper-coals pre≈øerve fire longe≈øt of any, keeping fire a whole year without ≈øupply, yet the Indian never burns of i ‚Ä¢ .

Sweet fern, ≈øee the rarities of New England, the tops and nucaments of ≈øweet forn boiled in water or milk and drunk helpeth all manner of Fluxes, being boiled in water it makes an excellent liquor for Inck.
Current-bu ‚Ä¢ hes are of two kinds red and black, the black cur ‚Ä¢ ents which are larger than the red ≈ømell like cats pi≈øs, yet are rea≈øonable plea≈øant in eating.
The Goo≈øeberry-bu≈øh, the berry of which is called Gro≈øers or thorn Grapes, grow all over the Countrie, the berry is but ≈ømall, of a red or purple colour when ripe.

There is a ≈ømall ≈øhrub which is very common, growing ≈øometimes to the height of Elder, bearing a berry like in ≈øhape to the fruit of the white thorn, of a pale yellow colour at fri≈øt, then red, when it is ripe of a deep purple, of a delicate Aromatical ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øt, ≈øomewhat ≈øtiptick: to conclude, alwayes
ob≈øerve this rule in taking or re≈øu≈øing unknown fruit: it you find them eaten of the fowl or bea≈øt, you may boldly venture to eat of them, otherwi≈øe do not touch them.

Maze, otherwi≈øe called Turkie-wheat, or rather Indian-wheat, becau≈øe it came fir≈øt from thence; the leaves boiled and drunk helpeth pain in the back; of the ≈øtalkes when they are green you may make Beverage, as they do with Calamels, or Sagarcanes. The raw Corn chewed ripens felons or Cats hairs, or you may lay Samp to it: The Indians before it be thorow ripe eat of it parched. Certainly the parched Corn that Abigail brought to David was of this kind of grain, 1 Sam. 25.18. The Jewes manner was (as it is delivered to us by a learned Divine) fir≈øt to parch their Corn, then they fryed it, and la≈øtly they bailed it to a pa≈øte, and then tempered it with water, Chee≈øe-Curds, H ‚Ä¢ ncy and Eggs, this they carried drye with them to the Camp, and ≈øo wet the Cakes in Wine or milk; ≈øuch was the pul≈øe too of Africa.

French-beans, or rather American-beans, the Heabali≈øts call them kidney beans from their ≈øhape and effects, for they ≈øtrengthen the kidneys; they are variegated much, ≈øome being bigger a great deal than others; ≈øome
white, black, red, yellow, blew, ≈øpotted; be≈øides your Bonivis and Calavances and the kidney-bean, that is proper to Ronoake, but the≈øe are brought into the Countrie, the other are natural to the climate. So the Mexico pompion which is flat and deeply camphered, the fle≈øh laid to, a≈ø≈øwageth pain of the eyes. The water-mellon is proper to the Countrie, the fle≈øh of it is of a fle≈øh colour, a rare cooler of Feavers, and excellent again≈øt the ≈øtone. Pomum ≈øpino≈øum and palma-Chri≈øti too growes not here, unle≈øs planted, brought from Peru; the later is thought to be the plant, that ≈øhaded Jonah the Prophet, Jonas 4.6. Paraverat enim Jehova Deus ricinum qui a≈øcenderet ≈øupra Jonam, ut e≈ø≈øet umbra ≈øuper caput ejus ereptura eum √† malo ip≈øius; laetabaturque Jonas de ricino illo laetitia magna. Ricinum, that is palma Chri≈øti, called al≈øo cucurbita, and therefore tran≈ølated a Gourd.

Tobacco, or Tabacca ≈øo called from Tabaco or Tabag ‚Ä¢ , one of the Caribbe-I≈ølands about 50 Engli≈øh miles from Trinidad. The right name, according to Monardus, is picielte, as others will petum, nicotian from Nicot, a Portingal, to whom it was pre≈øented for a raritie in Anno Dom. 1559. by one that brought it from Florida. Great conte≈øt there is about the time when it was fir≈øt
brought into England, ≈øome will have Sir John Hawkins the fir≈øt, others Sir Francis Drake's Mariners; others again ≈øay that one Mr. Lane imployed by Sir Walter Rawleigh brought it fir≈øt into England; all conclude that Sir Walter Rawleigh brought it fir≈øt in u≈øe. It is ob≈øerved that no one kind of forraign Commodity yieldeth greater advantage to the publick than Tobacco, it is generally made the complement of our entertainment, and hath made more ≈ølaves than Mahomet. There is three ≈øorts of it Marchantable, the fir≈øt hor≈øe Tobacco, having a br ‚Ä¢ ad long leaf piked at the end; the ≈øecond round pointed Tobacco; third ≈øweet ≈øcented Tobacco. The≈øe are made up into Cane, leaf or ball; there is little of it planted in New-England, neither have they learned the right way of curing of it. It is ≈øowen in April upon a bed of rich mould ≈øifted, they make a bed about three yards long, or more according to the ground they intend to plant, and a yard and a half over; this they tread down hard, then they ≈øow their ≈øeed upon it as thick as may be, and ≈øift fine earth upon it, then tread it down again as hard as po≈ø≈øible they can, when it hath gotten four or ≈øix leaves, they remove in into the planting ground; when it begins to bud towards flowring, they crop off the
top, for the Flower drawes away the ≈øtrength of the leaf. For the re≈øt I refer you to the Planter, being not willing to di≈øcover their my≈øteries. The Indians in New England u≈øe a ≈ømall round leafed Tobacco, called by them, or the Fi≈øhermen Poke. It is odious to the Engli≈øh. The vertues of Tobacco are the≈øe, it helps dige≈øtion, the Gout, the Tooth-ach, prevents infection by ≈øcents, it heats the cold, and cools them that ≈øweat, feedeth the hungry, ≈øpent ≈øpirits re≈øtoreth, purgeth the ≈øtomach, killeth nits and lice, the juice of the green leaf healeth green wounds although poy≈øoned, the Syrup for many di≈øea≈øes, the ≈ømoak for the Phthi≈øick, cough of the lungs, di≈øtillations of Rheume, and all di≈øer≈øes of a cold and moi≈øt cau≈øe, good for all bodies cold and moi≈øt taken upon an emptie ≈øtomach, taken upon a full ≈øtomach it precipitates dige≈øtion, immoderately taken it dryeth the body, enflameth the bloud, hurteth the brain, weakens the eyes and the ≈øinews.

White Hellebore is u≈øed for the Scurvie by the Engli≈øh. A friend of mine gave them fir≈øt a purge, then con≈øerve of Bear-berries, then ≈øumed their leggs with vinegar, ≈øprinkled upon a piece of mill-≈øtone made hot, and applied to the ≈øores white Hellebore leaves; drink made of Orpine and ≈øorrel were given likewi≈øe with it, and Sea≈øcurvie-gra≈øs.
To kill lice, boil the roots of Hellebore in milk, and anoint the hair of the head therewith or other places.

Mandrake, is a very rare plant, the Indians know it not, it is found in the woods about Pa≈øcataway, they do in plain terms ≈øtink, therefore Reubens-Flowers that he brought home were not Mandrakes, Gen. 30.14, 15, 16. They are rendered in the Latine Amabiles flores, the ≈øame word ≈øay our Divines is u≈øed in Canticles, 7.4. Amabiles i≈øtos flores edentes odorem, & ≈øecundum o≈øtia no≈øtra omnes pretio≈øos fructus, recentes ≈øimulac veteres, dilecte mi, repono tibi. So that the right tran≈ølation is, Reuben brought home amiable and ≈øweet ≈ømelling Flowers; this in the Canticles (≈øay they) expounding the other.
Calamus Aromaticus, or the ≈øweet ≈ømelling reed, it Flowers in July; ≈øee New-Englands rarities.

Sar≈øaparilla or roughbind-weed (as ≈øome de≈øcribe it) the leaves and whole bind ≈øet with thorns, of this there is ≈øtore growing upon the banks of Pouds. See the rarities of New-England. The leaves of the Sar≈øaparilla there de≈øcribed pounded with Hogs grea≈øe and boiled to an unguent, is excellent in the curing of wounds.

Live for ever, it is a kind of Cud-weed,
flouri≈øheth all ≈øummer long till cold weather comes in, it growes now plentifully in our Engli≈øh Gardens, it is good for cough of the lungs, and to clean≈øe the brea≈øt taken as you do Tobacco; and for pain in the head the decoction, or the juice ≈øtrained and drunk in Bear, Wine, or Aqua vitae, killeth worms. The Fi≈øhermen when they want Tobacco take this herb being cut and dryed.

Ly≈øimachus or Loo≈øe-≈øtrife: there are ≈øeveral kinds, but the mo≈øt noted is the yellow Ly≈øimachus of Virginia, the root is longi≈øh and white, as thick as ones thumb, the ≈øtalkes of an overworn colour, and a little hairie, the middle vein of the leaf whiti≈øh, the Flower yellow and like Primro≈øes, and therefore called Tree-primro≈øe, growes upon ≈øeedie ve≈ø≈øels, &c. The fir≈øt year it growes not up to a ≈øtalke, but ≈øends up many large leaves hand≈øomely lying one upon another, Ro≈øe fa≈øhion, Flowers in June, the ≈øeed is ripe in Augu≈øt, this as I have ≈øaid is taken by the Engli≈øh for Scabious.
St. John's wort, it pre≈øerveth Chee≈øe made up in it, at Sea.
Spurge or Wolfes milch there are ≈øeveral ≈øorts.

Avens, or herb-bennet; you have an account of it in New-Englands rarities; but one
thing more I ≈øhall add, that you may plainly perceive a more ma≈øculine quality in the plants growing in New-England. A neighbour of mine in Hay-time, having overheat him≈øelf, and melted his grea≈øe, with ≈øtriving to outmowe another man, fell dangerou≈øly ≈øick, not being able to turn him≈øelf in his bed, his ≈øtomach gon, and his heart fainting ever and anon; to whom I admini≈øtred the decoction of Avens-Roots and leaves in water and wine, ≈øweetning it with Syrup of Clove-Gilliflowers, in one weeks time it recovered him, ≈øo that he was able to perform his daily work, being a poor planter or husbandman as we call them.

Red-Lilly growes all over the Countrey among≈øt the bu≈øhes. Mr. John≈øon upon Gerard takes the Tulip to be the Lilly of the field mentioned by our Saviour, Matth. 6.28, 29. Ac de ve≈øtitu quid ≈øoliciti e≈øtis? di≈øcite quomodo lilia agrorum auge≈øcant: non fatigantur, neque nent, ≈øed dico vobis, ne Solomonem quidem cum univer≈øa gloria ≈øic amictum fui≈ø≈øe ut unum ex i≈øtis. Solomon in all his Royalty was not like one of them. His rea≈øons are, fir≈øt from the ≈øhape, like a lilly; The ≈øecond, becau≈øe tho≈øe places where „Äà‚óä„Äâ Savio ‚Ä¢ r was conver≈øant they grow wild in the fields. Third, the infinite variety of the colours.
The fourth and la≈øt rea≈øon, the wondrous beautie and mixture of the≈øe Flowers.
Water-lillys; the black roots dryed and pulverized, are wondrous effectual in the ≈øtopping of all manner of fluxes of the belly, drunk with wine or water.
Herba-paris, one berry, herb true love, or four-leaved night-≈øhade, the leaves are good to be laid upon hot tumours.
∆≤mbiticus veneris, or New-England dai≈øie, it is good for hot humours, Eri≈øipelas, St. Anthonie's fire, all inflammations.
Gla≈øs-wort, a little quantity of this plant you may take for the Drop≈øie, but be very careful that you take not too much, for it worketh impetuou≈øly.
Water-plantane, called in New-England water Suck-leaves, and Scurvie-leaves, you mu≈øt lay them whole to the leggs to draw out water between the skin and the fle≈øh.

Ro≈øa-≈øolis, Sun-dew, moor-gra≈øs, this plant I have ≈øeen more of, than ever I ≈øaw in my whole life before in England, a man may gather upon ≈øome mari≈øh-grounds an incr ‚Ä¢ dible quantity in a ≈øhort time; towards the middle of June it is in its ≈øea≈øon, for then its ≈øpear is ≈øhot out to its length, of which they take hold and pull the whole plant up by the roots from the mo≈øs with ca≈øe.

Amber-gree≈øe I take to be a Mu≈øhroom, ≈øee the rarities of New-England. Monardus writeth that Amber-gree≈øe ri≈øeth out of a certain clammy and bituminous earth under the Seas, and by the Sea-≈øide, the billows ca≈øting up part of it a land, and fi≈øh devour the re≈øt; Some ≈øay it is the ≈øeed of a Whale, others, that it ≈øpringeth from fountains as pitch doth; which fi≈øhes ≈øwallow down; the air congealeth it. And ≈øometimes it is found in the crevi≈øes and corners of Rocks.
Fu≈øs-balls, Mullipuffes called by the Fi≈øhermen Wolves-farts, are to be found plentifully, and tho≈øe bigger by much than any I have ≈øeen in England.
Coraline there is infinite ≈øtore of it ca≈øt upon the ≈øhore, and another plant that is more ≈øpinie, of a Red colour, and as hard as Corral. Coraline laid to the gout ea≈øeth the pain.
Sea-Oake or wreach, or Sea-weed; the black pouches of O ‚Ä¢ r-weed dryed and pulverized, and drunk with White-wine, is an excellent remedy for the ≈øtone.

I will fini≈øh this part of my relation concerning plants, with an admirable plant for the curing and taking away of Corns, which many times ≈øore troubleth the Traveller: it is not above a handful high; the little branches are woodie, the leaves like
the leaves of Box, but broader and much thicker, hard, and of a deep gra≈øs-green colour; this brui≈øed or champt in the mouth and laid upon the Corn will take it away clean in one night. And ob≈øerve all Indian Trees and plants, their Roots are but of ≈ømall depth, and ≈øo they mu≈øt be ≈øet.

Of Bea≈øts of the earth there be ≈øcarce 120 ≈øeveral kinds, and not much more of the Fowls of the Air, is the opinion of ≈øome Naturali≈øts; there are not many kinds of Bea≈øts in New-England, they may be divided into Bea≈øts of the Cha≈øe of the ≈øtinking foot, as Roes, Foxes, Jaccals, Wolves, Wild-cats Racoons, Porcupines, Squncks, Mu≈øqua≈øhes, Squirrels, Sables, and Mattri≈øes; and Bea≈øts of the Cha≈øe of the ≈øweet foot, Buck, Red Dear, Rain-Dear, Elke, Marou≈øe, Maccarib, Bear, Beaver, Otter, Marten, Hare.
The Roe a kind of Deer, and the fleete≈øt Bea≈øt upon earth is here to be found, and is good veni≈øon, but not over fat.

The Fox, the male is called a dog-fox, the female a bitch-fox, they go a clicketing the beginning of the ≈øpring, and bring forth their Cubs in May and June. There are two or three kinds of them; one a great yellow Fox, another grey, who will climb up into Trees; the black Fox is of much e≈øteem. Foxes and Wolves are u≈øually hunted
in England from Holy-Rood day, till the Annunciation. In New-England they make be≈øt ≈øport in the depth of winter: they lay a ≈øledg-load of Cods-heads on the other ≈øide of a paled fence when the moon ≈øhines, and about nine or ten of the clock the Foxes come to it, ≈øometimes two or three, or half a dozen, and more; the≈øe they ≈øhoot, and by that time they have ca≈øed them, there will be as many; So they continue ≈øhooting and killing of Foxes as long as the moon ≈øhineth: I have known half a ≈øcore kill'd in one night. Their pi≈øles are bonie like a doggs, their fat liquified and put into the ears ea≈øeth the pain, their tails or bu≈øhes are very fair ones and of good u≈øe, but their skins are ≈øo thin (yet thick ≈øet with deep ‚Ä¢ urr) that they will hardly hold the dre≈ø≈øing.
Jaccals there be abundance, which is a Creature much like a Fox, but ≈ømaller, they ‚Ä¢ re very frequent in Palae≈øtina, or the Holy- ‚Ä¢ and.

The Wolf ≈øeeketh his mate and goes a ‚Ä¢ licketing at the ≈øame ≈øea≈øon with Foxes, and bring forth their whelps as they do, but ‚Ä¢ heir kennels are under thick bu≈øhes by great Trees in remote places by the ≈øwamps, he is to be hunted as the Fox from Holy
‚Ä¢ ood day till the Annunciation. But there
they have a quicker way to de≈øtroy them. See New-England rarities. They commonly go in routs, a rout of Wolves is 12 or more, ≈øometimes by couples. In 1664. we ≈øound a Wolf a≈øleep in a ≈ømall dry ≈øwamp under an Oake, a great ma≈øtiff which we had with us ≈øeized upon him, and held him till we had put a rope about his neck, by which we brought him home, and tying of him to a ≈øtake we bated him with ≈ømaller Doggs, and had excellent ≈øport; but his hinder legg being broken, they knockt out his brains. Sometime before this we had an excellent cour≈øe after a ≈øingle Wolf upon the hard ≈øands by the Sea-≈øide at low water for a mile or two, at la≈øt we lo≈øt our doggs, it being (as the Lanca≈øhire people phra≈øe it) twi-l ‚Ä¢ ght, that is almo≈øt dark, and went beyond them, for a ma≈øtiff-bitch had ≈øeized upon the Wolf being gotten into the Sea, and there held him till one went in and led him out, the bitch keeping her hold till they had tyed his leggs, and ≈øo carried him home like a Calf upon a ≈øtaff between two men; being brought into the hou≈øe they unbound him and ≈øet him upon his leggs, h ‚Ä¢ not offering in the lea≈øt to bite, or ≈øo much as to ≈øhew his teeth, but clapping his ≈øtern betwixt his leggs, and leering towards the door would willingly have had his liberty,
but they ≈øerved him as they did the other, knockt his brains out, for our doggs were not then in a condition to bate him; their eyes ≈øhine by night as a Lanthorn: the Fangs of a Wolf hung about childrens necks keep them from frighting, and are very good to rub their gums with when they are breeding of Teeth, the gall of a Wolf is Soveraign for ≈øwelling of the ≈øinews; the fiants or dung of a Wolf drunk with white-wine helpeth the Collick.
The Wild-cat, Lu≈øern or luceret, or Ounce as ≈øome call it, is not inferiour to Lamb, their grea≈øe is very ≈øoveraign for lamene≈øs upon taking cold.

The Racoon or Rattoon is of two ≈øorts, gray Rattoons, and black Rattoons, their grea≈øe is ≈øoveraign for wounds with brui≈øes, aches, ≈øtreins, brui≈øes; and to anoint after broken bones and di≈ølocations.

The Squnck is almo≈øt as big as a Racoon, perfect black and white or pye-bald, with a bu≈øh-tail like a Fox, and offen≈øive Carion; the Urine of this Creature is of ≈øo ≈øtrong a ≈øcent, that if it light upon any thing, there is no abiding of it, it will make a man ≈ømell, though he were of Alexanders complexion; and ≈øo ≈øharp that if he do but whisk his bu≈øh which he pi≈ø≈øeth upon in the face of a dogg hunting of him, and that
any of it light in his eyes it will make him almo≈øt mad with the ≈ømart thereof.

The Mu≈øqua≈øhes is a ≈ømall Bea≈øt that lives in ≈øhallow ponds, where they build them hou≈øes of earth and ≈øticks in ≈øhape like molehills, and feed upon Calamus Aromaticus: in May they ≈øcent very ≈øtrong of Muske; their furr is of no great e≈øteem; their ≈øtones wrapt up in Cotten-wool will continue a long time, and are good to lay among≈øt cloths to give them a grateful ≈ømell.

The Squirril, of which there are three ≈øorts, the mou≈øe-≈øquirril, the gray ≈øquirril, and the flying ≈øquirril, called by the Indian A≈ø≈øapanick. The mou≈øe-≈øquirril is hardly ≈øo big as a Rat, ≈øtreak'd on both ≈øides with bl ‚Ä¢ ck and red ≈øtreaks, they are mi≈øchievous vermine de≈øtroying abundance of Corn both in the field and in the hou≈øe, where they will gnaw holes into Che≈øts, and tear clothes both linnen and wollen, and are notable nut-g ‚Ä¢ therers in Augu≈øt; when ha≈øel and ti ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ert nuts are ripe you may ≈øee upon every Nut-tree as many mou≈øe-≈øquirrils as leaves; So that the: u ‚Ä¢ s are gone in a trice, w ‚Ä¢ ich they convey to their Drays or Ne≈øts. The gray ≈øquirril is pretty large, almo≈øt as big as a Conie, and are very good meat: in ≈øome parts of the Countrie there are many of them. The flying ≈øquirril is ≈øo called, becau≈øe
(his skin being loo≈øe and large) he ≈øpreads it on both ≈øides like wings when he pa≈ø≈øeth from one Tree to another at great di≈øtance. I cannot call it flying nor leaping, for it is both.
The Mattri≈øe is a Creature who≈øe head and fore-parts is ≈øhaped ≈øomewhat like a Lyons, not altogether ≈øo big as a hou≈øe-cat, they are innumerable up in the Countrey, and are e≈øteemed good furr.
The Sable is much of the ≈øize of a Mattri≈øe perfect black, but what ≈øtore there is of them I cannot tell, I never ≈øaw but two of them in Eight years ≈øpace.
The Martin is as ours are in England, but blacker, they breed in holes which they make in the earth like Conies, and are innumerable, their skins or furr are in much reque≈øt.

The Buck, Stag, and Rain-Dear are Creatures that will live in the colde≈øt climates, here they are innumerable, bringing forth three Fawns or Calves at a time, which they hide a mile a≈øunder to prevent their de≈øtruction by the Wolves, wild-Cats, Bears, and Mequans: when they are in ≈øea≈øon they will be very fat; there are but few ≈ølain by the Engli≈øh. The Indians who ≈øhoot them, and take of them with toyls, bring them in
with their ≈øuet, and the bones that grow upon Stags-Hearts.

What would you ≈øay, if I ≈øhould tell you that in Green-land there are Does that have as large horns as Bucks, their brow Antlers growing downwards beyond their Mu≈øles, and broad at the end wherewith they ≈øcrape away the ≈ønow to the gra≈øs, it being impo≈ø≈øible for them otherwayes to live in tho≈øe cold Countries; the head of one of the≈øe Does was ≈øometime ≈øince nailed upon a ≈øignpo≈øi in Charter hou≈øe-lane, and the≈øe following ver≈øes written upon a board underneath it.

q.l: Like a Bucks-head I ≈øtand in open view,
And yet am none; nay, wonder not, 'tis true;
The living Bea≈øt that the≈øe fair horns did owe
Well known to many, was a Green-land Doe.
The proverb old is here fulfill'd in me,
That every like is not the ≈øame you ≈øee.

div.p:
The Moo≈øe or Elke is a Creature, or rather if you will a Mon≈øter of ≈øuperfluity; a full grown Moo≈øe is many times bigger than an Engli≈øh Oxe, their horns as I have ≈øaid el≈øewhere, very big (and brancht out into palms) the tips whereof are ≈øometimes found to be two fathom a≈øunder, (a fathom
is ≈øix feet from the tip of one finger to the tip of the other, that is four cubits,) and in height from the toe of the fore-foot, to the pitch of the ≈øhoulder twelve foot, both which hath been taken by ≈øome of my ≈øceptique Readers to be mon≈øtrous lyes. If you con≈øider the breadth that the bea≈øt carrieth, and the magnitude of the horns, you will be ea≈øily induced to contribute your belief. And for their height ≈øince I came into England I have read Dr. Scroderns his Chymical di≈øpen≈øatory tran≈ølated into Engli≈øh by Dr. Rowland, where he writes that when he lived in Finland under Gu≈øtavus Horns, he ≈øaw an Elke that was killed and pre≈øented to Gu≈øtavus his Mother, ≈øeventeen ≈øpans high. Lo you now Sirs of the Gibing crue, if you have any skill in men≈øuration, tell me what difference there is between Seventeen ≈øpans and twelve foot. There are certain tran≈øcendentia in every Creature, which are the indelible Characters of God, and which di≈øcover God; There's a prudential for you, as John Rhodes the Fi≈øherman u≈øed to ≈øay to his mate, Kitt Lux. But to go on with the Mo ‚Ä¢ ≈øe; they are accounted a kind of Deer, and have three Calves at a time, which they hide a mile a≈øunder too, as other Deer do, their skins make excellent Coats for Martial men, their ≈øinews which are as
big as a mans finger are of perdurable toughne≈øs and much u≈øed by the Indians, the bone that growes upon their heart is an excellent Cordial, their bloud is as thick as an A≈ø≈øes or Bulls who have the thicke≈øt bloud of all others, a man the thinne≈øt. To what age they live I know not, certainly a long time in their proper climate. Some particular living Creatures cannot live in every particular place or region, e≈øpecially with the ≈øame j ‚Ä¢ y and felicity as it did where it was fir≈øt br ‚Ä¢ d, for the certain agreement of nature that is between the place and the thing bred in that place: As appeareth by Elephants, which being tran≈ølated and brought out of the Second or Third Climate, though they may live, yet will they never ingender or bring forth young. So for plants, Birds, &c. Of both the≈øe Creatures, ≈øome few there have been brought into England, but did not long continue. Sir R. Baker in his Chronicle tells us of an Elephant in Henry the Thirds R ‚Ä¢ ign, which he ≈øaith was the fir≈øt that was ever ≈øeen there, which as it ≈øeems is an error, unle≈øs he re≈øtrain it to the Norman's time. For Mr. Speed writeth that Claudius Dru≈øius Emperour of Rome brought in the fir≈øt in his Army; the bones of which digg'd up ≈øince are taken for Gyants bones. As for the Moo≈øe the fir≈øt that was ≈øeen in England,
was in King Charles the Fir≈øt Raign; thus much for the≈øe magnals among≈øt the Creatures of God to be wondered at, the next bea≈øt to be mentioned is
The Maurou≈øe, which is ≈øomewhat like a Moo≈øe, but his horns are but ≈ømall, and him≈øelf about the ≈øize of a Stag, the≈øe are the Deer that the flat- ‚Ä¢ ooted Wolves hunt after.
The Maccarib is a Creature not found that ever I heard yet, but upon Cape-Sable near to the French plantations.

The Bear when he goes to mate is a terrible Creature, they bring forth their Cubs in March, hunted with doggs they take a Tree where they ≈øhoot them, when he is fat he is excellent Veni≈øon, which is in Acorn time, and in winter, but then there is none dares to attempt to kill him but the Indian. He makes his Denn among≈øt thick Bu≈øhes, thru≈øting in here and there ≈øtore of Mo≈øs, which being covered with ≈ønow and melting in the day time with heat of the Sun, in the night is frozen into a thick coat of Ice; the mouth of his Den is very narrow, here they lye ≈øingle, never two in a Den all winter. The Indian as ≈øoon as he finds them, creeps in upon all ‚Ä¢ our, ≈øeiz ‚Ä¢ s with his left hand upon the neck of the ≈øleeping Bear, drags h ‚Ä¢ m to the mouth of
the Den, where with a club or ≈ømall hatchet in his right hand he knocks out his brains before he can open his eyes to ≈øee his enemy. But ≈øometimes they are too quick for the Indians, as one among≈øt them call ‚Ä¢ d black Robin lighting upon a male Bear had a piece of his buttock torn off before he could fetch his blow: their grea≈øe is very ≈øoveraign. One Mr. Purcha≈øe cured him≈øelf of the Sciatica with Bears-gree≈øe, keeping ≈øome of it continually in his groine. It is good too for ≈øwell'd Cheeks upon cold, for Rupture of the hands in winter, for limbs taken ≈øuddenly with Sciatica, Gout, or other di≈øea≈øes that cannot ≈øtand upright nor go, bed-rid; it mu≈øt be well chaft in, and the ≈øame cloth laid on ≈øtill; it prevents the ≈øhedding of the hair occa≈øioned by the coldne≈øs of winters weather; and the yard of a Bear which as a Doggs or Foxes is bonie, is good for to expell Gravel out of the kidneys and bladder, as I was there told by one Mr. Abraham Philater a Jer≈øey-man.

The Beaver or Pound-dog is an Amphibious Creature, lives upon the land as well as in the water. I ≈øuppo≈øe they feed upon fi≈øh, but am ≈øure that the Bark of Trees is al≈øo their food; there is an old proverbial ≈øaying, ≈øic me jubes quotidie, ut fiber ≈ø ‚Ä¢ licem: you love me as the Beaver doth the willow;
who eateth the Bark and killeth the Tree. They will be tame, witne≈øs the Beaver that not long ≈øince was kept at Bo≈øton in the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets-Bay, and would run up and down the ≈øtreets, returning home without a call. Their skins are highly valued, and their ≈øtones are good for the pal≈øie, trembling, and numbne≈øs of the hands, boiling of them in Oyl of Spike, and anointing the ≈øinews in the neck. If you take of Ca≈øtorium two drams, of womans hair one dram, and with a little Rozen of the Pine-Tree, make it up into pills as big as Filberts and perfume a woman in a fit of the mother with one at a time laid upon coals under her no≈øtrils, it will recover her out of her fit. The grea≈øe of a Beaver is good for the Nerves, Convul≈øions, Epilep≈øies, Apoplexies &c. The tail as I have ≈øaid in another Treati≈øe, is very fat and of a ma≈øculine vertue, as good as Erigno's or Satyrion-Roots.

The Otter or River-Dog is Amphibious too, he hunteth for his kind in the ≈øpring, and bringeth forth his whelps as the Beaver doth, they are generally black, and very numerous, they are hunted in England from Shrovetide untill Mid≈øummer, but in New-England they take them when they can. The skin of an Otter is worth Ten Shillings,
and the Gloves made thereof are the be≈øt fortification for the hands again≈øt wet weather that can be thought of, the furr is excellent for muffs, and is almo≈øt as dear as Beaver, the grea≈øe of an Otter will make fi≈øh turn up their bellies, and is of rare u≈øe for many things.

The Hare, I have no more to write of them than that they kindle in hollow Trees. What el≈øe concerns him, or any of the fore-mentioned Creatures you have in my New-Englands rarities, to which I refer you.
The Porcupine likewi≈øe I have treated of, only this I forgot to acquaint you with, that they lay Eggs, and are good meat.

The la≈øt kind of Bea≈øts are they that are begot by equivocal generation, as Mules and ≈øeveral others, that when the Bea≈øts were brought by the Almighty Creator to Adam, who gave them names, were not then in rerum natura. Of the≈øe there are not many known in New-England. I know but of one, and that is the Indian dog begotten betwixt a Wolf and a Fox, or between a Fox and a Wolf, which they made u≈øe of, taming of them, and bringing of them up to hunt with, but ≈øince the Engli≈øh came among≈øt them they have gotten ≈øtore of our dogs, which they bring up and keep in as much ≈øubjection as they do their webbs.

Of Birds there are not many more than 120 kinds as our Naturali≈øts have conjectured, but I think they are deceived; they are divided into land-birds and water-birds, the land-birds again into birds of prey, birds for meat, ≈øinging-birds and others.

The Pilhannaw is the King of Birds of prey in New-England, ≈øome take him to be a kind of Eagle, others for the Indian-Ruck the bigge≈øt Bird that is, except the O≈øtrich. One Mr. Hilton living at Pa≈øcataway, had the hap to kill one of them: being by the Sea-≈øide he perceived a great ≈øh ‚Ä¢ dow over his head, the Sun ≈øhining out clear, ca≈øting up his eyes he ≈øaw a mon≈øtrous Bird ≈øoaring aloft in the air, and of a ≈øudden all the Ducks and Gee≈øe, (there being then a great many) dived under water, nothing of them appearing but their heads. Mr. Hilton having made readie his piece, ≈øhot and brought her down to the ground, how he di≈øpo≈øed of her I know not, but had he taken her alive & ≈øent her over into England, neither Bartholomew nor Sturbridge-Fair could have produced ≈øuch another ≈øight.

Hawkes there are of ≈øeveral kinds, as Go≈øhawkes, Falcons, Laniers, Sparrow-hawkes, and a little black hawke highly prized by the Indians who wear them on their
heads, and is accounted of worth ≈øufficient to ran≈øome a Sagamour: they are ≈øo ≈øtrangely couragious and hardie, that nothing flyeth in the Air that they will not bind with. I have ≈øeen them tower ≈øo high, that they have been ≈øo ≈ømall that ≈øcarcely could they be taken by the eye. Hawkes grea≈øe is very good for ≈øore eyes.

The O≈øprey I have treated of. There is a ≈ømall A≈øh-colour Bird that is ≈øhaped like a Hawke with talons and beak that falleth upon Crowes, mounting up into the Air after them, and will beat them till they make them cry.
The Vulture or Geire, which is ≈øpoken of in Levit. 11.14. and called a Gripe, their skins are good to line doublets with, and the bones of their head hung about the neck helpeth the head-ach.
The Gripe; ≈øee New Englands rarities, and for the Turkie-buzzard.

The Owl the mo≈øt flagging Bird that is, of which there are three ≈øorts, a great grey Owl with ears, a little grey Owl, and a white Owl, which is no bigger than a Thru≈øh. Plinie writes that the brains of an Owl a≈ø≈øwageth the pain & inflammation in the lap of the ear. And that Eggs of an Owl put into the liquour that a to ≈øpot u≈øeth to be drunk with, will make him loath drunkenne≈øs
ever after. But now peradventure ≈øome will ≈øay, what doth this man mean to bring Owls to Athens? verily Sirs I pre≈øume to ≈øay, had I brought over of the little white Owls they would have been acceptable, they are good mou≈øers, and pretty Birds to look upon: the Athenians, no que≈øtion are better imployed than to take notice of my Owls, poor ragged Birds they are and want tho≈øe gli≈øtering golden feathers that Draiton's Owl is adorned with, yet they are ≈øomewhat of that nature; if an Athenian chance in this ≈øea≈øon of diverti≈øement to ca≈øt an eye upon them I ≈øhall be glad, but more glad if he vouch≈øafe to prune and correct their feathers, which I confe≈øs are di≈øcompo≈øed for want of Art; plain Birds they are, and fit for none but plain men to manage. Sirs do not mi≈øtake me, there's no man living honours an Athenian more than I do, e≈øpecially where I perceive great abilities concomiting with goodne≈øs of nature: A good nature (≈øaith Mr. Perkins) is the Character of God, and God is the father of learning, knowledge, and every good gift, and hath conde≈øcended to become a School-ma≈øter to us poor mortals, furni≈øhing of us with Philo≈øophy, Hi≈øtorie, Divinity by his holy Scriptures, which if we diligently learn and practi≈øe, we ≈øhall in
time be brought into his Heavenly Academy, where we ≈øhall have fulne≈øs and perfection of knowledge eternally. But there are a Generation of men and women in this prophane age that de≈øpi≈øe Gods learning and his U≈øhers to the Athenians, choo≈øing to wallow in the plea≈øures of ≈øin for a ≈øea≈øon. I ≈øhall conclude this excur≈øion, with that which a Poet writ ≈øometime ≈øince, and then return to the trimming of my Owl.

lg.l: 'Twere ≈øimple fury in thee then to wa≈øt
Thy ≈øelf, on them that have no ta≈øt;
No, give them draff their fill,
They that love Lees and leave the lu≈øtie Wine,
Envy them not, their palats with the Swine.

div.p: The Raven is here numerous and Crowes, but Rooks, Danes, Popinjaes, Megpies there be none. It is ob≈øerved that the female of all Birds of prey and Ravin is ever bigger than the male, more venturous, hardy, and watchful: but ≈øuch Birds as do not live by prey and Ravin, the male is more large than the female. So much for Birds of prey, the next are Birds for the di≈øh, and the fir≈øt of the≈øe is,

The Turkie, which is in New-England a very large Bird, they breed twice or thrice in a year, if you would pre≈øerve the young Chickens alive, you mu≈øt give them no water, for if they come to have their fill of water they will drop away ≈øtrangely, and you will never be able to rear any of them: they are excellent meat, e≈øpecially a Turkie-Capon beyond that, for which Eight ≈øhillings was given, their Eggs are very whole≈øome and re≈øtore decayed nature exceedingly. But the French ≈øay they breed the Lepro≈øie; the Inde≈ø≈øes make Coats of Turkie-feathers woven for their Children.
The Partridge is larger than ours, white fle≈øht, but very dry, they are indeed a ≈øort of Partridges called Groo≈øes.

The Pidgeon, of which there are millions of millions, I have ≈øeen a flight of Pidgeons in the ≈øpring, and at Michaelmas when they return back to the Southward for four or five miles, that to my thinking had neither beginning nor ending, length nor breadth, and ≈øo thick that I could ≈øee no Sun, they ‚Ä¢ oyn Ne≈øt to Ne≈øt, and Tree to Tree by their Ne≈øts many miles together in Pine-Trees. But of late they are much dimi
‚Ä¢ i≈øhed, the Engli≈øh taking them with Nets. „Äà‚óä„Äâ have bought at Bo≈øton a dozen of Pidgeons ready pull'd and garbidgd for three penc
Ring-Doves they ≈øay are there too, but I could never ≈øee any.
The Snow-Bird is like a Chaf-Finch. go in flocks and are good meat.

The ≈øinging Birds are Thru≈øhes with red brea≈øts, which will be very fat and are good meat, ≈øo are the Thre≈ø≈øels, Filladies are ≈ømall ≈øinging Birds, Ninmurders little yellow Birds. New-England Nightingales painted with orient colours, black, white, blew, yellow, green and ≈øcarlet, and ≈øing ≈øweetly, Wood-larks, Wrens, Swallows, who will ≈øit upon Trees, and Starlings black as Ravens with ≈øcarlet pinions; other ≈øorts of Birds there are, as the Troculus, Wag-tail, or Di≈øhwater, which is here of a brown colour, Titmou≈øe two or three ≈øorts, the Dunneck or hedge-Sparrow who is ≈øtarke naked in his winter ne≈øt. The golden or yellow hammer, a Bird about the bigne≈øs of a Thru≈øh that is all over as red as bloud, Wood-Peckers of two or three ≈øorts, gloriou≈øly ≈øet out with variety of glittering colours. The Colibry, Viemalin, or ri≈øing or waking Bird, an Emblem of the Re≈øurrection, and the wonder of little Birds.

The water-≈øowl are the≈øe that follow, Hookers or wild-Swans, Cranes, Gee≈øe of three ≈øorts, grey, white, and the brant Goo≈ø ‚Ä¢ , the fir≈øt and la≈øt are be≈øt meat, the white are
lean and tough and live a long time; whereupon the proverb, Older than a white Goo≈øe; of the skins of the necks of grey Gee≈øe with their Bills the Indians makes Mantles and Coverlets ≈øowing them together and they ≈øhew prettily. There be four ≈øorts of Ducks, a black Duck, a brown Duck like our wild Ducks, a grey Duck, and a great black and white Duck, the≈øe frequent Rivers and Ponds; but of Ducks there be many more ≈øorts, as Hounds, old Wives, Murres, Doies, Shell-drakes, Shoulers or Shoflers, Widgeons, Simps, Teal, Blew wing'd, and green wing'd, Divers or Didapers, or Dipchicks, Fenduck, Duckers or Moorhens, Coots, Pochards, a water-fowl like a Duck, Plungeons, a kind of water-fowl with a long reddi≈øh Bill, Puets, Plovers, Smethes, Wilmotes, a kind of Teal, Godwits, Humilities, Knotes, Red-Shankes, Wobbles, Loones, Gulls, white Gulls, or Sea-Cobbs, Caudemandies, Herons, grey Bitterns, Ox-eyes, Birds called Oxen and Keen, Petterels, Kings fi≈øhers, which breed in the ≈øpring in holes in the Sea-banks, being unapt to propagate in Summer, by rea≈øon of the drine≈øs of their bodies, which becomes more moi≈øt when their pores are clo≈øed by cold. Mo≈øt of the≈øe Fowls and Birds are eatable. There are little Birds that frequent the Sea-≈øhore in flocks called Sanderlins,
they are about the bigne≈øs of a Sparrow, and in the fall of the leaf will be all fat; when I was fir≈øt in the Countrie the Engli≈øh cut them into ≈ømall pieces to put into their Puddings in≈øtead of ≈øuet, I have known twelve ≈øcore and above kill'd at two ≈øhots. I have not done yet, we mu≈øt not forget the Cormorant, Shape or Sharke; though I cannot commend them to our curious palats, the Indians will eat them when they are fley'd, they take them prettily, they roo≈øt in the night upon ≈øome Rock that lyes out in the Sea, thither the Indian goes in his Birch-Canow when the Moon ≈øhines clear, and when he is come almo≈øt to it, he lets his Canow drive on of it ≈øelf, when he is come under the Rock he ≈øhoves his Boat along till he come ju≈øt under the Cormorants watchman, the re≈øt being a≈øleep, and ≈øo ≈øoundly do ≈øleep that they will ≈ønore like ≈øo many Piggs; the Indian thru≈øts up his hand of a ≈øudden, gra≈øping the watchman ≈øo hard round about his neck that he cannot cry out; as ≈øoon as he hath him in his Canow he wrings off his head, and making his Canow fa≈øt, he clambreth to the top of the Rock, where walking ≈øoftly he takes them up as he plea≈øeth, ≈øtill wringing off their heads; when he hath ≈øhin as many as his Canow can carry, he gives a ≈øhout
which awakens the ≈øurviving Cormorants, who are gone in an in≈øtant.

The next Creatures that you are to take notice of, are they that live in the Element of water. Pliny reckons them to be of 177 kinds, but certainly if it be true that there is no Bea≈øt upon Earth, which hath not his like in the Sea, and which (perhaps) is not in ≈øome part parallel'd in the plants of the Earth; we may by a diligent ≈øearch find out many more: of the ≈øame opinion is the Poet, who ≈øaith that it is

q.l: Affirm'd by ≈øome that what on Earth we find,
The Sea can parallell in ≈øhape and kind.

div.p: Divine Dubertus goes further.

q.l: You Divine wits of elder dayes, from whom
The deep invention of rare works hath com ‚Ä¢ ,
Took you not pattern of our chiefe≈øt Tooles
Out of the lap of Thetis, Lakes, and Pools?
Which partly in the Waves, part on the edges
Of craggy Rocks, among their ragged ≈øedges,
Bring forth abundance of Pins, Spincers, ≈øpokes,
Pikes, piercers, needles, mallets, pipes & yoak ‚Ä¢ ,
Oars, ≈øails & ≈øwords, ≈øaws, wedges, razors, rammers,
Plumes, cornets, knives, wheels, vices, horns and hammers.

div.p: P≈øalm 104.25, 26. In ip≈øo mari magno & ≈øpatio≈øo, illic reptilia ≈øunt atque innumera animantia parva cum magnis. Illic navea ambulant; balaena quam forma≈øti ludendo in eo.

And as the females among≈øt Bea≈øts and Birds of prey for form and beautie ≈øurpa≈øs the males, ≈øo do they e≈øpecially among≈øt fi≈øhes; and tho≈øe I intend to treat of, I ≈øhall divide into ≈øalt-water fi≈øh, and fre≈øh-water fi≈øh.

The Sea that Pi≈øcina mirabilis affords us the greate≈øt number, of which I ≈øhall begin fir≈øt with the Whale a regal fi≈øh, as all fi≈øhes of extraordinary ≈øize are accounted, of the≈øe there are (as I have ≈øaid in another place) ≈øeven kinds the Ambergree≈øe-Whale the chie ‚Ä¢ e≈øt. Anno Dom. 1668 the 17 of July there was one of them thrown up on the ≈øhore between Winter-harbour and Cape-porpus, about eight mile from the place where I lived, that was five and fifty foot long. They are Creatures of a va≈øt magnitude and ≈øtrength. The Royal P≈øalmi≈øt, in the 148 p≈øalm, and the 7 ver≈øe, makes mention of them. Laudate Jebovam terre≈øtria; Cete (Dracones as ≈ø ‚Ä¢ me tra ‚Ä¢ ≈ølate it) & omnes aby≈ø≈øi. And Mo≈øes in his hi≈øtory of Job, Job 41.1. An extrahas balaenam ham ‚Ä¢ , &c.
Whereby the ≈øubtlety of the Devil is ≈øhewed, as al≈øo, the greatne≈øs and bruti≈øhne≈øs of the Devil by the Elephant, in the 10 ver≈øe of the foregoing Chapter. In the book of Jonas prophecies we read of a great fi≈øh, Jonah 1.17. Pararat autem Jehova pi≈øcem magnum, ‚Ä¢ ui ob≈øorberet Jonam. But whether this were a Whale or not is que≈øtioned by ≈øome. In the head (≈øaith Mr. Parkin≈øon the Herbali≈øt) of one only ≈øort of Whale-fi≈øh is found that which is called ≈øperma Caeti, it lyes in a hole therein, as it were a Well, taken out and pre≈øt that the oyl may come out, the ≈øub≈øtance is that we u≈øe for ≈øperma Caeti, and hath little or no ≈ømell, the oyl ≈ømells ≈øtrong. See the rarities of New-England.

The Sea-hare is as big as Grampus or Herrin-hog, and as white as a ≈øheet; There hath been of them in Black point-Harbour, & ≈øome way up the river, but we could never take any of them, ≈øeveral have ≈øhot ≈øluggs at them, but lo≈øt their labour.
The Sturgeon is a Regal fi≈øh too, I have ≈øeen of them that have been ≈øixteen foot in length: of their ≈øounds they make I≈øirgla≈øs, which melted in the mouth is excellent to ≈øeal letters.

Sharkes there are infinite ≈øtore, who tear the Fi≈øhermens nets to their great lo≈øs and hinderance; they are of two ≈øorts, one flat
headed, the other long ≈ønouted, the pretious ≈øtone in their heads (≈øoveraign for the ≈øtone in a man) ≈øo much coveted by the travelling Chirurgeon is nought el≈øe but the brains of the flat-headed Sharke. With the≈øe we may joyn the Dog-fi≈øh or Thornhound, who hath two long ≈øharp prickles on his back.

The Sea-hor≈øe or Mor≈øe is a kind of mon≈øter-fi≈øh numerous about the I≈øle of Sables. i. e. The ≈øandy I≈øle. An Amphibious Creature kill'd for their Teeth and Oyl, never brings forth more than two at a birth; as al≈øo doth the Soil and Manate or Cow-fi≈øh, which is ≈øuppo≈øed to be the Seamon≈øter ≈øpoken of by Jeremy, Lament. 4.3. Etiam phocae praebent mammam, lactant catulos ≈øuos; So the Latins render it, phoca a Sea-Calf or Soil.
The ≈ømall Sword-fi≈øh is very good meat, the Sea-bat or Sea-owl a kind of flying fi≈øh.

Negroes or Sea-Devils a very ugly fi≈øh, having a black ≈øcale, there are three ≈øorts of them, one a hideous fi≈øh, another about two foot long; of the≈øe I have ≈øeen ≈øtore in Black-point Harbour in the water, but never attempted to take any of them.

Squids a ≈øoft fi≈øh ≈øomewhat like a cudgel, their horns like a Snails, which ≈øometimes are found to be of an incredible length,
this fi≈øh is much u≈øed for bait to catch a Cod, Hacke, Pollu ‚Ä¢ k, and the like Sea-fi≈øh.
The Dolphin, Bonito, or Dozado, the a≈øhes of their teeth mixed with honey, is good to a≈ø≈øwage the pain of breeding teeth in Children.
The Sea-bream, Dorado, or Amber-fi≈øh, they follow ≈øhips as doth the Dolphin, and are good meat.
The Mackarel, of which there is choicefull plenty all ≈øummer long, in the ≈øpring they are ordinarily 18 inches long, afterwards there is none taken but what are ≈ømaller.
The Liver-fi≈øh like a Whiting.

The Herrin which are numerous, they take of them all ≈øummer long. In Anno Dom. 1670. they were driven into Black-point Harbour by other great fi≈øh that prey upon them ≈øo near the ≈øhore, that they threw them≈øelves (it being high water) upon dry land in ≈øuch infinite numbers that we might have gone up half way the leg among≈øt them for near a quarter of a mile. We u≈øed to qualifie a pickled Herrin by boiling of him in milk.

The Alewife is like a herrin, but has a bigger bellie therefore called an Alewife, they come in the end of April into fre≈øh
Rivers and Ponds; there hath been taken in two hours time by two men without any Weyre at all, ≈øaving a few ≈øtones to ≈øtop the pa≈ø≈øage of the River, above ten thou≈øand. The Italian hath a proverb, that he that hath ≈øeen one miracle will ea≈øily believe another; but this relation far from a miracle will peranter meet, in≈øtead of a belief with an Adulterate con≈øtruction from tho≈øe that are ≈øomewhat akin to St. Peters mockers, ≈øuch as deny the la≈øt judgement. I have known in England 9 ≈øcore and 16 Pikes and Pickarel taken with three Angles between the hours of three and ten in the morning, in the River Ow≈øe in the I≈øle of Ely, three quarters of a yard long above half of them; they make red Alewives after the ≈øame manner as they do herrins and are as good.

The Ba≈ø≈øe is a ≈øalt water fi≈øh too, but mo≈øt an end taken in Rivers where they ≈øpawn, there hath been 3000 Ba≈ø≈øe taken at a ≈øet, one writes that the fat in the bone of a Ba≈ø≈øes head is his braines which is a lye.

The Salmon likewi≈øe is a Sea-fi≈øh, but as the Ba≈ø≈øe comes into R ‚Ä¢ vers to ≈øpawn, a Salmon the fir≈øt year is a Salmon-≈øm ‚Ä¢ lt; The ≈øecond a Mort; The third a Sp ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ il; The fourth a Soar; The fi ‚Ä¢ th a S ‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢ el; The ≈øixth
a forket tail; and the ≈øeventh year a Salmon. There are another ≈øort of Salmon frequent in tho≈øe parts called white Salmons.
Capeling is a ≈ømall fi≈øh like a ≈ømelt.

The Turtle or Tortoi≈øe is of two ≈øorts Sea-Turtles and land-Turtles: of Sea-Turtles there are five ≈øorts, of land-Turtles three ≈øorts, one of which is a right land-Turtles that ≈øeldom or never goes into the water, the other two being the River-Turtle, and the pond-Turtle: there are many of the≈øe in the brooke Chy≈øon in the Holy land. The a≈øhes of a Sea-Turtle mixt with oyl or Bears-grea≈øe cau≈øeth hair to grow: the ≈øhell of a land-Turtle burnt and the a≈øhes di≈ø≈øolved in wine and oyl to an unguent healeth chaps and ≈øores of the feet: the fle≈øh burnt and the a≈øhes mixt with wine and oyl healeth ≈øore legs: the a≈øhes of the burnt ≈øhell and the whites of eggs compounded together healeth chaps in womens nipples; and the head pulverized with it prevents the falling of the hair, and will heal the Hemorrhoids, fir≈øt wa≈øhing of them with white-wine; and then ≈øtrewing on the powder.

Lob≈øter, which ≈øome ≈øay is at fir≈øt a whelk, I have ≈øeen a Lob≈øter that weighed twenty pound, they ca≈øt their ≈øhell-coats in the ≈øpring, and ≈øo do Crabs; having underneath a thin red skin which growes thicker and
hard in ≈øhort time. The Indians feed much upon this fi≈øh, ≈øome they ro≈øt, and ≈øome they dry as they do Lampres and Oy≈øters which are delicate breakfa≈øt meat ≈øo ordered, the Oy≈øters are long ≈øhell'd, I have had of them nine inches long from the point to the toe, containing an Oy≈øter like tho≈øe the Latines called Tridacuan that were to be cut into three pieces before they could get them into their mouths, very fat and ≈øweet.

The Mu≈øcle is of two ≈øorts, Sea-mu≈øcles in which they find Pearl and river-mu≈øcles. Sea-mu≈øcles dryed and pulverized and laid upon the ≈øores of the Piles and hemorrhoids with oyl will perfectly cure them.

The Whore is a ≈øhell-fi≈øh, the ≈øhells are called whores-eggs, being fine round white ≈øhells, in ≈øhape like a Mexico pompion, but no bigger than a good large Hens-egg; they are wrought down the ≈øides with little knobs and holes very prettily, but are but thin and brittle.

The Perriwig is a ≈øhell-fi≈øh that ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ h in the Sands flat and round as a ≈øhovel-board piece and very little thicker; the≈øe at a little hole in the middle of the ≈øhell thru≈øt out a cap of hair, but upon the lea≈øt motion of any danger it drawes it in again.

Trouts there be good ≈øtore in every brook, ordinarily two and twenty inches
long, their grea≈øe is good for the Piles and clifts.

The Eal is of two ≈øorts, ≈øalt-water Eals and fre≈øh-water Eals; the≈øe again are di≈øtingui≈øhed into yellow bellied Eals and ≈øilver bellied Eals; I never eat better Eals in no part of the world that I have been in, than are here. They that have no mind or lea≈øure to take them, may buy of an Indian half a dozen ≈øilver bellied Eals as big as tho≈øe we u≈øually give 8 pence or 12 pence a piece for at London, for three pence or a groat. There is ≈øeveral wayes of cooking them, ≈øome love them roa≈øted, others baked, and many will have them fryed; but they plea≈øe my palate be≈øt when they are boiled, a common way it is to boil them in half water, half wine with the bottom of a manchet, a fagot of Par≈øley, and a little winter ≈øavory, when they are boiled they take them out and break the bread in the broth, and put to it three or four ≈øpoonfuls of ye≈øt, and a piece of ≈øweet butter, this they pour to their Eals laid upon ≈øippets and ≈øo ≈øerve it up. I fancie my way better which is this, after the Eals are fley'd and wa≈øht I fill their bellies with Nutmeg grated and Cloves a little brui≈øed, and ≈øow them up with a needle and thred, then I ≈øtick a Clove here and there in their ≈øides about an inch a≈øunder,
making holes for them with a bodkin, this done I wind them up in a wreath and put them into a kettle with half water and half white wine-vinegar, ≈øo much as will ri≈øe four fingers above the Eals; in mid≈øt of the Eals I put the bottom of a penny white loaf, and a fagot of the≈øe herbs following, Par≈øley one handful, a little ≈øweet Marjoram, Peniroyal and Savory, a branch of Ro≈øemary, bind them up with a thred, and when they are boiled enough take out the Eals and pull out the threds that their bellies were ≈øowed up with, turn out the Nutmeg and Cloves, put the Eals in a di≈øh with butter and vinegar upon a chafing-di≈øh with coals to keep warm, then put into the broth three or four ≈øpoonfuls of good Ale-yea≈øt with the juice of half a Lemmon; but before you put in your yea≈øt beat it in a porringer with ≈øome of the broth, then break the cru≈øt of bread very ≈ømall and mingle it well together with the broth, pour it into a deep di≈øh and garni≈øh it with the other half of the Lemmon, and ≈øo ≈øerve them up to the Table in two di≈øhes.

The Fro≈øt fi≈øh is little bigger than a Gudgeon and are taken in fre≈øh brooks; when the waters are frozen they make a hole in the Ice about half a yard or yard wide, to which the fi≈øh repair in great numbers, where with
≈ømall nets bound to a hoop about the bigne≈øs of a fiskin-hoop with a ≈øtaff fa≈øtned to it they lade them out of the hole. I have not done with the fi≈øh yet, being willing to let you know all of them that are to be ≈øeen and catch'd in the Sea and fre≈øh waters in New-England, and becau≈øe I will not tire your patience overmuch, having no occa≈øion to enlarge my di≈øcour≈øe, I ≈øhall only name them and ≈øo conclude.

The fi≈øh are ≈øwum by, and the Serpents are creeping on, terrible creatures, carrying ≈øtings in their tails. It will ≈ømart wor≈øe than a Satyrs whip, though it were as big as Mr. Shepperds the mad Gentleman at Milton-Mowhrayes Con≈øtantinus La≈øculus.

The chief or Captain of the≈øe is the Rattle-≈ønake de≈øcribed already in my Journal, in ≈øome places of the Countrey there are none as at Plimouth, New-town, Nahant and ≈øome other places, they will live on one ≈øide of the River, and but ≈øwimming over and coming into the woods dye immediately.

The fat of a Rattle-≈ønake is very Soveraign for frozen limbs, brui≈øes, lamene≈øs by falls, Aches, Sprains. The heart of a Rattle-≈ønake dried and pulverized and drunk with wine or beer is an approved remedy again≈øt the biting and venome of a Rattle-≈ønake. Some body will give me thanks for di≈øcovering
the≈øe ≈øecrets and the re≈øt; Non omnibus omnia conveniunt.

The Snake of which there are infinite numbers of various colours, ≈øome black, others painted with red, yellow and white, ≈øome again of a gra≈øs-green colour powdered all over as it were with ≈øilver du≈øt or Mu≈øcovie-gla≈øs. But there is one ≈øort that exceeds all the re≈øt, and that is the Check-quered ≈ønake, having as many colours within the checkquers ≈øhaddowing one another, as there are in a Rainbow. There are two ≈øorts of ≈ønakes, the land-≈ønake and the water-≈ønake; the water-≈ønake will be as big about the belly as the Calf of a mans leg; I never heard of any mi≈øchief that ≈ønakes did, they kill them ≈øometimes for their skins and bones to make hatbands off, their skins likewi≈øe worn as a Garter is an excellent remedie again≈øt the cramp. I have found of the skins that they ca≈øt in woods in ≈øome quantity, they ca≈øt not their very skins, but only the ≈øuperfluous thin skin that is upon the very skin, for the very skin is ba≈øted to the fle≈øh, ≈øo Lob≈øters and Crabs.

The Earth-worm, the≈øe are very rare and as ≈ømall as a hor≈øe hair, but there is a Bug that lyes in the earth and eateth the ≈øeed, that is ≈øomewhat like a Maggot of a white colour with a red head, and is about
the bigne≈øs of ones finger and an inch or an inch and half long. There is al≈øo a dark dunni≈øh Worm or Bug of the bigne≈øs of an Oaten-≈øtraw, and an inch long, that in the ≈øpring lye at the Root of Corn and Garden plants all day, and in the night creep out and devour them; the≈øe in ≈øome years de≈øtroy abundance of Indian Corn and Garden plants, and they have but one way to be rid of them, which the Engli≈øh have learnt of the Indians; And becau≈øe it is ≈øomewhat ≈øtrange, I ≈øhall tell you how it is, they go out into a field or garden with a Birchendi≈øh, and ≈øpudling the earth about the roots, for they lye not deep, they gather their di≈øh full which may contain about a quart or three pints, then they carrie the di≈øh to the Sea-≈øide when it is ebbing-water and ≈øet it a ≈øwimming, the water carrieth the di≈øh into the Sea and within a day or two if you go into your field you may look your eyes out ≈øooner than find any of them.

Sow-bugs or Millipedes there be good ≈øtore, but none of that ≈øort that are blew and turn round as a pea when they are touched; neither are there any Beetles nor Maple-bugs, but a ≈øtinking black and red Bug called a Cacarooch or Cockroach, and a little black Bug like a Lady-cow that breeds in skins and furrs and will eat them to their
utter ≈øpoil. Likewi≈øe there be infinite numbers of Tikes hanging upon the bu≈øhes in ≈øummer time that will cleave to a mans garments and creep into his Breeches eating them≈øelves in a ≈øhort time into the very fle≈øh of a man. I have ≈øeen the ≈øtockins of tho≈øe that have gone through the woods covered with them. Be≈øides the≈øe there is a Bug, but whether it be a Native to the Countrie or a ≈øtranger I cannot ≈øay: Some are of opinion that they are brought in by the Merchant with Spani≈øh goods, they infe≈øt our beds mo≈øt, all day they hide them≈øelves, but when night comes they will creep to the ≈øleeping wretch and bite him wor≈øe than a flea, which rai≈øeth a ≈øwelling knub that will itch intolerably, if you ≈øcratch it waxeth bigger and growes to a ≈øcab; and if you chance to break one of the Bugs it will ≈øtink odiou≈øly: they call them Chinches or Wood-lice, they are fat, red and in ≈øhape like a Tike and no bigger. There are al≈øo Palmer-worms which is a kind of Catterpiller, the≈øe ≈øome years will devour the leaves of Trees leaving them as naked almo≈øt as in winter, they do much harm in the Engli≈øh Orchards. Of Snails there are but few, and tho≈øe very little ones, they lye at the Roots of long gra≈øs in moi≈øt places, and are no where el≈øe to be found.
Spiders and Spinners there be many, the la≈øt very big and of ≈øeveral colours.

The Pi≈ømire or Ant mu≈øt not be forgotten, accounted the lea≈øt Creature, and by Salomon commended for its wi≈ødom, Prov. 30.24.25 Q ‚Ä¢ atuor i≈øta parva ≈øunt humilia, tamen ≈øunt ≈øap ‚Ä¢ entia, apprime ≈øapientia: formi ‚Ä¢ a populus infirmus, quae comparant ea≈øtate cibum≈øuum, &c. There are two ≈øorts, red Ants and black Ants, both of them are many times ≈øound winged; not long ≈øince they were poured upon the Sands out of the clouds in a ≈øtorm betwixt Black-point and Saco, where the pa≈ø≈øenger might have walkt up to the Ankles in them.

The Gra≈øhopper is innum ‚Ä¢ rable and bigger by much than ours in England, having Tin≈øel-wings, with help whereof they will flye and skip a great way. Next to the≈øe in number are your Crickets, a man can walk no where in the ≈øummer but he ≈øhall tread upon them, The Italian who hath them cryed up and down the ≈øtreets (Grille che cantelo) and buyeth them to put into his Gardens, if he were in New-England would gladly be rid of them, they make ≈øuch a dinn in an Evening. I could never di≈øcover the Organ of their voice, they have a little clift in their Crown which opens, and at the ≈øame in≈øtant they ≈øhake their wings.
The E≈øt or Swift in New-England is a mo≈øt beautiful Creature to look upon, being larger than ours, and painted with glorious colours; but I lik'd him never the better for it.

Frogs too there are in ponds and upon dry land, they chirp like Birds in the ≈øpring, and latter end of ≈øummer croak like Toads. It is admirable to con≈øider the generating of the≈øe Creatures, fir≈øt they lay their gelly on the water in ponds and ≈øtill waters, which comes in time to be full of black ≈øpots as broad as the head of a Tenpenny nail, and round, the≈øe ≈øeparate them≈øelves from the gleir, and after a while thru≈øt out a tail, then their head comes forth, after their head ≈øprings out their fore-legs, and then their hinder-legs, then their tail drops off, and growes to have a head and four legs too, the fir≈øt proves a frog, the latter a water-nuet. The Herbali≈øt u≈øeth to ≈øay by way of admiration, quaelibet herba deum &c. So God is ≈øeen in the production of the≈øe ≈ømall Creatures which are a part of the Creation; Laudate Jehovam coelites, laudate eum in excel≈øis, &c. Laudent nomen Jehovae quae ip≈øo praecipiente illico creata ≈øunt &c. ip≈øae be≈øtiae & omnes jumenta, reptilia & aves alatae, P≈øal. 148.

The Toad is of two ≈øorts, one that is
≈øpeckled with white, and another of a a dark earthy colour; there is of them that will climb up into Trees and ≈øit croaking there; but whether it be of a third ≈øort, or one of the other, or both, I am not able to affirm; but this I can te≈øtifie that there be Toads of the dark coloured kind that are as big as a groat loaf. Which report will not ≈øwell into the belief of my ≈øceptique Sirs; nor that there is a Hell, being like Salomon's fool, Prov. 26.22. Sed ≈øi contunderes ≈øtultum in mortario cum mola pi≈øtillo, non recederet ab eo ≈øtultitia ejus.

Now before I proceed any further, I mu≈øt (to prevent mi≈øcon≈øtructions) tell you that the≈øe following Creatures, though they be not properly accounted Serpents, yet they are venomous and pe≈øtilent Creatures. As, fir≈øt the Rat, but he hath been brought in ≈øince the Engli≈øh came thither, but the Mou≈øe is a Native, of which there are ≈øeveral kinds not material to be de≈øcribed; the Bat or flitter mou≈øe is bigger abundance than any in England and ≈øwarm, which brings me to the infects or cut-wa≈øted creatures again, as fir≈øt the honey-Bee, which are carried over by the Engli≈øh and thrive there exceedingly, in time they may be produced from Bullocks when the wild Bea≈øts are de≈øtroyed. But the wa≈øp is common,
and they have a ≈øort of wild humble-Bee that breed in little holes in the earth. Near upon twenty years ≈øince there lived an old planter at Black-point, who on a Sun≈øhine day about one of the clock lying upon a green bank not far from his hou≈øe, charged his Son, a lad of 12 years of age to awaken him when he had ≈ølept two hours, the old man falls a≈øleep and lying upon his back gaped with his mouth wide enough for a Hawke to ≈øhit into it; after a little while the lad ≈øitting by ≈øpied a humble-Bee creeping out of his Fathers mouth, which taking wing flew quite out of ≈øight, the hour as the lad ghe≈øt being come to awaken his Father he jogg'd him and called aloud Father, Father, it is two a clock, but all would not rou≈øe him, at la≈øt he ≈øees the humble-Bee returning, who lighted upon the ≈øleepers lip and walked down as the lad conceived into his belly, and pre≈øently he awaked.

The Countrey is ≈øtrangely incommodated with flyes, which the Engli≈øh call Musketaes, they are like our gnats, they will ≈øting ≈øo fiercely in ≈øummer as to make the faces of the Engli≈øh ≈øwell'd and ≈øcabby, as if the ≈ømall pox for the fir≈øt year. Likewi≈øe there is a ≈ømall black fly no bigger than a flea, ≈øo numerous up in the Countrey,
that a man cannot draw his breath, but he will ≈øuck of them in: they continue about Thirty dayes ≈øay ≈øome, but I ≈øay three moneths, and are not only a pe≈øterment but a plague to the Countrey. There is another ≈øort of fly called a Gurnipper that are like our hor≈øe-≈ølyes, and will bite de≈øperately, making the bloud to ≈øpurt out in great quantity; the≈øe trouble our Engli≈øh Cattle very much, rai≈øing ≈øwellings as big as an egg in their hides. The Butterfly is of ≈øeveral ≈øorts and larger than ours; So are their Dragon-flyes. Glow-worms have here wings, there are multitudes of them in≈øomuch that in the dark evening when I fir≈øt went into the Countrey I thought the whole Heavens had been on fire, ≈øeeing ≈øo many ≈øparkles flying in the air: about Mount-Carmel, and the valley of Acree in the Holy-land there be abundance of them.
The≈øe are taken for Cantharides. Cantharides are green flyes by day, in the night they pa≈øs about like a flying Glow-worm with fire in their tails.

I have fini≈øhed now my relation of plants, &c. I have taken ≈øome pains in recollecting of them to memory, and ≈øetting of them down for their benefit from whom I may expect thanks; but I believe my reward
will be according to Ben John≈øons proverbs, Whi≈øtle to a J ‚Ä¢ de and he will pay you with a fart, Claw a churl by the britch and he will ≈øhit in your fi≈øt.

The people that inhabited this Countrey are judged to be of the Tartars called Samonids that border upon Ma≈øcovia, and are divided into Tribes; tho≈øe to the Ea≈øt and North-ea≈øt are called Churchers and Tarentines, and Monhegans. To the South are the Pequets and Narragan≈øets. We≈øtward Connecticuts and Mowhacks. To the North ward Aberginians which confi≈øt of Mattachu≈øets, Wippanaps and Tarrentines. The Pocanakets live to the We≈øtward of Plimouth. Not long before the Engli≈øh came into the Countrey, happened a great mortality among≈øt them, e≈øpecially where the Engli≈øh afterwards planted, the Ea≈øt and Northern parts were ≈øore ≈ømitten with the Contagion; fir≈øt by the plague, afterwards when the Engli≈øh came by the ≈ømall pox, the three Kingdoms or Sagamor≈øhips of the Mattachu≈øets were very populous, having under them ≈øeven Dukedoms or petti-Sagamor≈øhips, but by the plague were brought from 30000 to 300. There are not many now to the Ea≈øtward, the Pequots were de≈øtroyed by the Engli≈øh: the Mowhacks are about five hundred: Their ≈øpeech a dialect of the Tartars,
(as al≈øo is the Turki≈øh tongue) There is difference between Tongues and Languages, the divi≈øion of ≈øpeech at Babel is mo≈øt properly called Languages, the re≈øt Tongues.

As for their per≈øons they are tall and hand≈øome timber'd people, out-wri≈øted, pale and lean Tartarian vi≈øag'd, black eyed which is accounted the ≈øtronge≈øt for ≈øight, and generally black hair'd, both ≈ømooth and curi'd wearing of it long. No beards, or very rarely, their Teeth are very white, ≈øhort and even, they account them the mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary and be≈øt parts of man; And as the Au≈øtreans are known by their great lips, the Bavarians by their pokes under their chins, the Jews by their goggle eyes, ≈øo the Indians by their flat no≈øes, yet are they not ≈øo much depre≈øt as they are to The Southward.

The Inde≈ø≈øes that are young, are ≈øome of them very comely, having good features, their faces plump and round, and generally plump of their Bodies, as are the men likewi≈øe, and as ≈øoft and ≈ømooth as a mole-skin, of rea≈øonable good complexions, but that they dye them≈øelves tawnie, many prettie Brownetto's and ≈øpider finger'd L ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øes may be ≈øeen among≈øt them. The Vetula's or old women are lean and uglie, all of them are of a mode≈øt demeanor, con≈øidering their
Savage breeding; and indeed do ≈øhame our Engli≈øh ru≈øticks who≈øe rudene≈øs in many things exceedeth theirs.

Of di≈øpo≈øition very incon≈øtant, crafty, timorous, quick of apprehen≈øion, and very ingenious, ≈øoon angry, and ≈øo malicious that they ≈øeldom forget an injury, and barbarou≈øly cruel, witne≈øs their direful revenges upon one another. Prone to injurious violence and ≈ølaughter, by rea≈øon of their bloud dryed up with overmuch fire, very lecherous proceeding from choller adu≈øt and melancholy, a ≈øalt and ≈øharp humour; very fingurative or theevi≈øh, and bold importunate beggars, both Men and Women guilty of Mi≈øoxenie or hatred to ≈øtrangers, a quality appropriated to the old Brittains, all of them Cannibals, caters of humane fle≈øh. And ≈øo were formerly the Heathen-Iri≈øh, who u≈øed to feed upon the Buttocks of Boyes and Womens Paps; it ≈øeems it is natural to Savage people ≈øo to do. I have read in Relations of the Indians among≈øt the Spaniards that they would not eat a Spaniard till they had kept him two or three dayes to wax tender, becau≈øe their fle≈øh was hard. At Martins vinyard, an I≈øland that lyes South to Plimouth in the way to Virginia, certain Indians (whil≈øt I was in the Countrey) ≈øei≈øed upon a Boat that put into
to a By-Cove, kill'd the men and eat them up in a ≈øhort time before they were di≈øcovered.

Their hou≈øes which they call Wigwams, are built with Poles pitcht into the ground of a round form for mo≈øt part, ≈øometimes ≈øquare, they bind down the tops of their poles, leaving a hole for ≈ømoak to go out at, the re≈øt they cover with the bark of Trees, and line the in≈øide of their Wigwams with mats made of Ru≈øhes painted with ≈øeveral colours, one good po≈øt they ≈øet up in the middle that reaches to the hole in the top, with a ≈øtaff a cro≈øs before it at a convenient height, they knock in a pin on which they hang their Kettle, beneath that they ≈øet up a broad ≈øtone for a back which keepeth the po≈øt from burning; round by the walls they ≈øpread their mats and skins where the men ≈øleep whil≈øt their women dre≈øs theis victuals, they have commonly two doors, one opening to the South, the other to the North, and according as the wind ≈øits, they clo≈øe up one door with bark and hang a Dears skin or the like before the other. Towns they have none, being alwayes removing from one place to another for conveniency of food, ≈øometimes to tho≈øe places where one ≈øort of fi≈øh is mo≈øt plentiful, other whiles where others are. I have ≈øeen half
hundred of their Wigwams together in a piece of ground and they ≈øhew prettily, within a day or two, or a week they have been all di≈øper≈øed. They live for the mo≈øt part by the Sea-≈øide, e≈øpecially in the ≈øpring and ≈øummer quarters, in winter they are gone up into the Countrie to hunt Deer and Beaver, the younger webbs going with them. Tame Cattle they have none, excepting Lice, and Doggs of a wild breed that they bring up to hunt with.

Wives they have two or three, according to the ability of their bodies and ≈øtrength of their concupi≈øcence, who have the ea≈øieft labours of any women in the world; they will go out when their time is come alone, carrying a board with them two foot long, and a foot and half broad, bor'd full of holes on each ≈øide, having a foot beneath like a Jack that we pull Boots off with, on the top of the board a broad ≈øtrap of leather which they put over their fore-head, the board hanging at their back; when they are come to a Bu≈øh or a Tree that they fancy they lay them down and are delivered in a trice, not ≈øo much as groaning for it, they wrap the child up in a young Beaver-skin with his heels clo≈øe to his britch, leaving a little hole if it be a Boy for his Cock to peep out at; and lace him down to the
board upon his back, his knees re≈øting upon the foot beneath, then putting the ≈øtrap of leather upon their fore-head with the infant hanging at their back home they trudge; What other ceremonies they u≈øe more than dying of them with a liquor of boiled Hemlock-Bark, and their throwing of them into the water if they ≈øu≈øpect the Child to be gotten by any other Nation, to ≈øee if he will ≈øwim, if he ≈øwim they acknowledge him for their own, their names they give them when they are men grown, and covet much to be called after our Engli≈øh manner, Robin, Harry, Phillip and the like, very indulgent they are to their Children, and their children ≈øometimes to their Parents, but if they live ≈øo long that they become a burden to them, they will either ≈øtarve them or bury them alive, as it was ≈øuppo≈øed an Indian did his Mother at Ca≈øco in 1669.

Their Apparel before the Engli≈øh came among≈øt them, was the skins of wild Bea≈øts with the hair on, Buskins of Deers-skin or Moo≈øe dre≈øt and drawn with lines into ≈øeveral works, the lines being coloured with yellow, blew or red, Pumps too they have, made of tough skins without ≈øoles. In the winter when the ≈ønow will bear them, they fa≈øten to their feet their ≈ønow ≈øhooes which are made like a large Racket we play at
Tennis with, lacing them with Deers-guts and the like, under their belly they wear a ≈øquare piece of leather and the like upon their po≈øteriors, both fa≈øtened to a ≈øtring tyed about them to hide their ≈øecrets; on their heads they ware nothing: But ≈øince they have had to do with the Engli≈øh they purcha≈øe of them a ≈øort of Cloth called trading cloth of which they make Mantles, Coats with ≈øhort ≈øleeves, and caps for their heads which the women u≈øe, but the men continue their old fa≈øhion going bare-headed, excepting ≈øome old men among≈øt them. They are very proud as appeareth by their ≈øetting them≈øelves out with white and blew Beads of their own making, and painting of their faces with the above mentioned colours, they weave ≈øometimes curious Coats with Turkie feathers for their Children.

Their Diet is Fi≈øh and Fowl, Bear, Wildcat, Rattoon and Deer; dry'd Oy≈øters, Lob≈øters ro≈øted or dryed in the ≈ømoak, Lampres and dry'd Moo≈øe-tongues, which they e≈øteem a di≈øh for a Sagamor; hard eggs boiled and made ≈ømall and dryed to thicken their broth with, falt they have not the u≈øe of, nor bread, their Indian Corn and Kidney beans they boil, and ≈øometimes eat their Corn parcht or roa≈øted in the ear again≈øt the fire; they feed likewi≈øe upon earth-nuts,
or ground-nuts, rocts of water-Lillies, Che≈ø-nuts, and divers ≈øorts of Berries. They beat their Corn to powder and put it up into bags, which they make u≈øe of when ≈øtormie weather or the like will not ≈øuffer them to look out for their food. Pompiens and water-Mellons too they have good ≈øtore; they have prodigious ≈øtomachs, devouring a cruel deal, meer voragoes, never giving over eating as long as they have it, between meals ≈øpending their time in ≈øleep till the next kettlefull is boiled, when all is gone they ≈øatisfie them≈øelves with a ≈ømall quantity of the meal, making it ≈øerve as the frugal bit among≈øt the old Britains, which taken to the mountenance of a Bean would ≈øatisfie both thir≈øt and hunger. If they have none of this, as ≈øometimes it falleth out (being a very carele≈øs people not providing again≈øt the ≈øtorms of want and tempe≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity) they make u≈øe of Sir Francis Drake's remedy for hunger, go to ≈øleep.

They live long, even to an hundred years of age, if they be not cut off by their Children, war, and the plague, which together with the ≈ømall pox hath taken away abundance of them. P ‚Ä¢ iny reckons up but 300 Di≈øea≈øes in and about man, latter writers Six thou≈øand, 236 belonging to the eyes. There are not ≈øo many Di≈øea≈øes raigning
among≈øt them as our Europeans. The great pox is proper to them, by rea≈øon (as ≈øome do deem) that they are Man-eaters, which Di≈øe ‚Ä¢ ≈øe was brought among≈øt our Europeans fir≈øt by the Spaniards that went with Chri≈øtopher Columbus who brought it to Naples with their Indian-women, with whom the Italians and French conver≈øed Anno Dom. 1493. Paracel≈øus ≈øaith it hapned in the year 1478 and 1480. But all agree that it was not known in Europe before Columbus his voyage to America. It hath continued among≈øt us above two hundred and three ≈øcore years. There are Di≈øea≈øes that are proper to certain climates, as the Lepro≈øie to Aegypt, ≈øwelling of the Throat or Mentegra to A≈øia, the ≈øweating ≈øickne≈øs to the Inhabitants of the North; to the Portugals the Phthi≈øick, to Savoy the mumps; So to the We≈øt-Indies the Pox, but this doth not exclude other Di≈øea≈øes.
