In New-England the Indians are afflicted with pe≈øtilent Feavers, Plague, Black-pox, Con≈øumption of the Lungs, Falling-≈øickne≈øs, Kings-evil, and a Di≈øea≈øe called by the Spaniard the Plague in the back, with us Empyema, their Phy≈øicians are the Powaws or Indian Prie≈øts who cure ≈øometimes by charms and medicine, but in a general infection they ≈øeldom come among≈øt them,
therefore they u≈øe their own remedies, which is ≈øweating, &c. Their manner is when they have plague or ≈ømall pox among≈øt them to cover their Wigwams with Bark ≈øo clo≈øe that no Air can enter in, lining them (as I ≈øaid before) within, and making a great fire they remain there with a ≈øtewing heat till they are in a top ≈øweat, and then run out into the Sea or River, and pre≈øently after they are come into their Hutts again they either recover or give up the Gho≈øt; they dye patiently both men and women, not knowing of a Hell to ≈øcare them, nor a Con≈øcience to terrifie them. In times of general Mortality they omit the Ceremonies of burying, expo≈øing their dead Carka≈øes to the Bea≈øts of prey. But at other times they dig a Pit and ≈øet the di≈øea≈øed therein upon his breech upright, and throwing in the earth, cover it with the ≈øods and bind them down with ≈øticks, driving in two ≈ølakes at each end; their mournings are ≈øomewhat like the howlings of the Fi≈øh, ≈øeldom at the grave but in the Wigwam where the party dyed, blaming the Devil for his hard heartedne≈øs, and concluding with rude prayers to him to afflict them to further.

They acknowledge a God who they call Squan ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ m, but wor≈øhip him they do not,
becau≈øe (they ≈øay) he will do them no harm. But Abb ‚Ä¢ mocho or Cheepie many times ≈ømites them with incurable Di≈øea≈øes, ≈øcares them with his Apparitions and pannick Terrours, by rea≈øon whereof they live in a wretched con≈øternation wor≈øhipping the Devil for fear. One black Robin an Indian ≈øitting down in the Corn field belonging to the hou≈øe where I re≈øided, ran out of his Wigwam frighted with the apparition of two infernal ≈øpirits in the ≈øhape of Mohawkes. Another time two Indians and an Inde≈øs, came running into our hou≈øe crying out they ≈øhould all dye, Cheepie was gone over the field gliding in the Air with a long rope hanging from one of his legs: we askt them what he was like, they ≈øaid all wone Engli≈øhman, clothed with hat and coat, ≈øhooes and ≈øtockings, &c. They have a remarkable ob≈øervation of a flame that appears before the death of an Indian or Engli≈øh upon their Wigwams in the dead of the night: The fir≈øt time that I did ≈øee it, I was call'd out by ≈øome of them about twelve of the clock, it being a very dark night, I perceived it plainly mounting into the Air over our Church, which was built upon a plain little more than half a quarter of a mile from our dwelling hou≈øe, on the North≈øide of the Church: look on
what ≈øide of a hou≈øe it appears, from that Coa≈øt re≈øpectively you ≈øhall hear of a Coar≈øe within two or three days.

They wor≈øhip the Devil (as I ≈øaid) their Prie≈øts are called Powaws and are little bette ‚Ä¢ than Witches, for they have familiar conference with him, who makes them invulnerable, that is ≈øhot-free and ≈øtick-free. Craftie Rogues, abu≈øing the re≈øt at their p ‚Ä¢ ea≈øure, having power over them by rea≈øon of their Diabolical Art in curing of Di≈øea≈øes, which is performed with rude Ceremonies; they place the ≈øick upon the ground ≈øi ‚Ä¢ ring, and dance in an Antick manner round about him, beating their naked brea≈øts with a ≈øtrong hand, and making hideous faces, ≈øometimes calling upon the Devil for his help, mingling their prayers with horrid and barbarous charms; if the ≈øick recover, they ≈øend rich gifts, their Bowes and Arrowes, Wempompers, Mohacks, Beaver skins, or other rich Furs to the E ‚Ä¢ ≈øtward, where there is a va≈øt Rock not far from the ≈øhore, having a hole in it of an un≈øearchable profundity, into which they throw them.

Their Theologie is not much, but que≈øtionle≈øs they acknowledge a God and a Devil, and ≈øome ≈ømall light they have of the Souls immortality; for ask them whither
they go when they dye, they will tell you pointing with their finger to Heaven beyond the white mountains, and do hint at Noah's Floud, as may be conceived by a ≈øtory they have received from Father to Son, time out of mind, that a great while agon their Countrey was drowned, and all the People and other Creatures in it, only one Powaw and his Webb fore≈øeeing the Floud fled to the white mountains carrying a hare along with them and ≈øo e≈øcaped, after a while the Powaw ≈øent the Hare away, who not returning emboldned thereby they de≈øcended, and lived many years after, and had many Children, from whom the Countrie was filled again with Indians. Some of them tell another ≈øtory of the Beaver, ≈øaying that he was their Father.

Their learning is very little or none, Poets they are as may be ghe≈ø≈øed by their formal ≈øpeeches, ≈øometimes an hour long, the la≈øt word of a line riming with the la≈øt word of the following line, and the whole doth Con≈øtare ex pedibus. Mu≈øical too they be, having many pretty odd barbarous tunes which they make u≈øe of vocally at marriages and fea≈øtings; but In≈øtruments they had none before the Engli≈øh came among≈øt them, ≈øince they have imitated them and will make out Kitts and ≈øtring them as neatly,
and as Artificially as the be≈øt Fiddlemaker among≈øt us; and will play our plain le≈ø≈øons very exactly: the only Fidler that was in the Province of Meyn, when I was there, was an Indian called Scezway, whom the Fi≈øhermen and planters when they had a mind to be merry made u≈øe of. Arithmetick they skill not, reckoning to ten upon their ≈øingers, and if more doubling of it by holding their fingers up, their age they reckon by Moons, and their actions by ≈øleeps, as, if they go a journie, or are to do any other bu≈øine≈øs they will ≈øay, three ≈øleeps me walk, or two or three ≈øleeps me do ≈øuch a thing, that is in two or three days. A≈øtronomie too they have no knowledge of, ≈øeldom or never taking ob≈øervation of the Stars, Eclip≈øes, or Comets that I could perceive; but they will Progno≈øticate ≈øhrewdly what weather will fall out. They are generally excellent Zenagegues or guides through their Countrie.

Their exerci≈øes are hunting and fi≈øhing, in both they will take abundance of pains. When the ≈ønow will bear them, the young and lu≈øtie Indians, (leaving their papou≈øes and old people at home) go forth to hunt Mo ‚Ä¢ ≈øe, Deere, Bear and Beaver, Thirty or forty miles up into the Countrey; when they light upon a Mo ‚Ä¢ ≈øe they run him down,
which is ≈øometimes in half a day, ≈øometimes a whole day, but never give him over till they have tyred him, the ≈ønow being u≈øually four foot deep, and the Bea≈øt very heavie he ≈øinks every ≈øtep, and as he runs ≈øometimes bears down Arms of Trees that hang in his way, with his horns, as big as a mans thigh; other whiles, if any of their dogs (which are but ≈ømall) come near, yerking out his heels (for he ≈øtrikes like a hor≈øe) if a ≈ømall Tree be in the way he breaks it quite a≈øunder with one ≈øtroak, at la≈øt they get up to him on each ≈øide and tran≈øpierce him with their Lances, which formerly were no other but a ≈øtaff of a yard and half pointed with a Fi≈øhes bone made ≈øharp at the end, but ≈øince they put on pieces of ≈øword-blades which they purcha≈øe of the French, and having a ≈øtrap of leather fa≈øtned to the but end of the ≈øtaff which they bring down to the mid≈øt of it, they dart it into his ≈øides, haeret latere lethalis aru ‚Ä¢ d ‚Ä¢ , the poor Creature groans, and walks on heavily, for a ≈øpace, then ≈øinks and falls down like a ruined building, making the Earth to quake; then pre≈øently in come the Victors, who having cut the throat of the ≈ølain take off his skin, their young webbs by this time are walking towards them with heavie bags and kettles at their
backs, who laying down their burdens fall to work upon the Carka≈øs, take out the heart, and from that the bone, cut off the left ≈øoot behind, draw out the ≈øinews, and cut out his tongue &c. and as much of the Veni≈øon as will ≈øerve to ≈øatiate the hungry mawes of the Company: mean while the men pitch upon a place near ≈øome ≈øpring, and with their ≈ønow ≈øhoos ≈øhovel the ≈ønow away to the bare Earth in a circle, making round about a wall of ≈ønow; in the mid≈øt they make their Vulcan or fire near to a great Tree, upon the ≈ønags whereof they hang their ke ‚Ä¢ l ‚Ä¢ s fil'd with the Veni≈øon; whil≈øt that bods, the men after they have refre≈øht them≈øelves with a pipe of Tobacco di≈øpo≈øe them≈øelves to ≈øleep. The women tend the Cookerie, ≈øome of them ≈øcrape the ≈ølime and fat from the skin, clean≈øe the ≈øinews, and ≈øtretch them and the like, when the veni≈øon is boiled the men awake, and opening of their bags take out as much Indian meal as will ≈øerve their turns for the pre≈øent; they eat their broth with ≈øpoons, and their fl ‚Ä¢ ≈øh they divide into gobbets, eating now and then with it as much meal as they can hold betwixt three fingers, their drink they fetch from the ≈øpring, and were not acquainted with other, untill the French and Engli≈øh traded with that cur≈øed liquor
called Rum, Rum-bullion, or kill-Devil, which is ≈øtronger than ≈øpirit of Wine, and is drawn from the dro≈øs of Sugar and Sugar Canes, this they love dearly, and will part with all they have to their bare skins for it, being perpetually drunk with it, as long as it is to be had, it hath killed many of them, e≈øpecially old women who have dyed when dead drunk. This in≈øtead of bringing of them to the knowledge of Chri≈øtianitie, we have taught them to commit the bea≈øtly and crying ≈øins of our Nation, for a little profi ‚Ä¢ . When the Indians have ≈øtuft their paunches, if it be fair weather and about midday they venture forth again, but if it be foul and far ≈øpent, they betake them≈øelves to their field-bed at the ≈øign of the Star, expecting the opening of the Ea≈øtern window, which if it promi≈øe ≈øerenity, they tru≈øs up their fardles, and away for another Moo≈øe, this cour≈øe they continue for ≈øix weeks or two moneths, making their Webbs their Mules to carry their luggage, they do not trouble them≈øelves with the horns of Moo≈øe or other Deer, unle≈øs it be near an Engli≈øh plantation; becau≈øe they are weighty & cumber≈øome. If the Engli≈øh could procure them to bring them in, they would be worth the pains and charge, being ≈øold in England after the rate of forty or fifty
pounds a Tun; the red heads of Deer are the faire≈øt and fulle≈øt of marrow, and lighte≈øt; the black heads are heavie and have le≈øs marrow; the white are the wor≈øt, and the wor≈øt nouri≈øhed. When the Indians are gone, there gathers to the Carka≈øs of the Moo≈øe thou≈øands of Mattri≈øes, of which there are but few or none near the Sea-coa≈øts to be ≈øeen, the≈øe devour the remainder in a quarter of the time that they were hunting of it.

Their fi≈øhing followes in the ≈øpring, ≈øummer and fall of the leaf. Fir≈øt for Lob≈øters, Clams, Flouke, Lumps or P ‚Ä¢ dles, and Alewives; afterwards for Ba≈øs, Cod, Rock, Blewfi≈øh, Salmon, and Lampres, &c.

The Lob≈øters they take in large Bayes when it is low water, the wind ≈øtill, going out in their Birchen-Canows with a ≈øtaff two or three yards long, made ≈ømall and ≈øharpen'd at one end, and nick'd with deep nicks to take hold. When they ≈øpye the Lob≈øter crawling upon the Sand in two fathom water, more or le≈øs, they ≈øtick him towards the head and bring him up. I have known thirty Lob≈øters taken by an Indian lad in an hour and a half, thus they take Flouke and Lumps; Clams they dig out of the Clambanks upon the flats and in creeks when it is low water, where they are bedded ≈øometimes
a yard deep one upon another, the beds a quarter of a mile in length, and le≈øs, the Alewives they take with Nets like a pur≈øenet put upon a round hoop'd ≈øtick with a handle in fre≈øh ponds where they come to ≈øpawn. The Ba≈øs and Blew-fi≈øh they take in harbours, and at the mouth of barr'd Rivers being in their Canows, ≈øtriking them with a fi≈øgig, a kind of dart or ≈øtaff, to the lower end whereof they fa≈øten a ≈øharp jagged bone (≈øince they make them of Iron) with a ≈øtring fa≈øtened to it, as ≈øoon as the fi≈øh is ≈øtruck they pull away the ≈øtaff, leaving the bony head in the fi≈øhes body and fa≈øten the other end of the ≈øtring to the Canow: Thus they will hale after them to ≈øhore half a dozen or half a ≈øcore great fi≈øhes: this way they take Sturgeon; and in dark evenings when they are upon the fi≈øhing ground near a Bar of Sand (where the Sturgeon feeds upon ≈ømall fi≈øhes (like Eals) that are called Lances ≈øucking them out of the Sands where they lye hid, with their hollow Trunks, for other mouth they have none) the Indian lights a piece of dry Birch-Bark which breaks out into a flame & holds it over the ≈øide of his Canow, the Sturgeon ≈øeeing this glaring light mounts to the Surface of the water where he is ≈ølain and taken with a fi≈øgig. Salmons and Lampres
are catch'd at the falls of Rivers. All the Rivers of note in the Countrey have two or three de≈øperate falls di≈øtant one from another for ≈øome miles, for it being ri≈øing ground from the Sea and mountainous within land, the Rivers having their Originals from great lakes, and ha≈øtning to the Sea, in their pa≈ø≈øage meeting with Rocks that are not ≈øo ea≈øily worn away, as the loo≈øe earthie mould beneath the Rock, makes a fall of the water in ≈øome Rivers as high as a hou≈øe: you would think it ≈øtrange to ≈øee, yea admire if you ≈øaw the bold Barbarians in their light Canows ru≈øh down the ≈øwift and headlong ≈øtream with de≈øperate ≈øpeed, but with excellent dexterity, guiding his Canow that ≈øeldom or never it ≈øhoots under water or overturns, if it do they can ≈øwim naturally, ≈øtriking their pawes under their throat like a dog, and not ≈øpreading their Arms as we do; they turn their Canow again and go into it in the water.

Their Merchandize are their beads, which are their money, of the≈øe there are two ≈øorts, blew Beads and white Beads, the fir≈øt is their Gold, the la≈øt their Silver, the≈øe they work out of certain ≈øhells ≈øo cunningly that neither Jew nor Devil can counterfeit, they dril them and ≈øtring them, and make many curious works with them to adorn
the per≈øons of their Sagamours and principal men and young women, as Belts, Girdles, Tablets, Borders for their womens hair, Bracelets, Necklaces, and links to hang in their ears. Prince Phillip a little before I came for England coming to Bo≈øton had a Coat on and Buskins ≈øet thick with the≈øe Beads in plea≈øant wild works and a broad Belt of the ≈øame, his Accountrements were valued at Twenty pounds. The Engli≈øh Merchant giveth them ten ≈øhillings a fathom for their white, and as much more or near upon for their blew Beads. Delicate ≈øweet di≈øhes too they make of Birch-Bark ≈øowed with threads drawn from Spru≈øe or white Cedar-Roots, and garni≈øhed on the out-≈øide with flouri≈øh works, and on the brims with gli≈øtering quills taken from the Porcupine, and dyed, ≈øome black, others red, the white are natural, the≈øe they make of all ≈øizes from a dram cup to a di≈øh containing a pottle, likewi≈øe Buckets to carry water or the like, large Boxes too of the ≈øame materials, di≈øhes, ≈øpoons and trayes wrought very ≈ømooth and neatly out of the knots of wood, baskets, bags, and matts woven with Sparke, bark of the Line-Tree and Ru≈øhes of ≈øeveral kinds, dyed as before, ≈øome black, blew, red, yellow, bags of Porcupine quills woven and dyed al≈øo; Coats woven of
Turkie-feathers for their Children, Tobacco pipes of ≈øtone with Imagerie upon them, Kettles of Birchen-bark which they u≈øed before they traded with the French for Copper Kettles, by all which you may apparently ≈øee that nece≈ø≈øity was at fir≈øt the mother of all inventions. The women are the workers of mo≈øt of the≈øe, and are now, here and there one excellent needle woman, and will milk a Cow neatly, their riche≈øt trade are Furs of divers ≈øorts, Black Fox, Beaver, Otter, Bear, Sables, Mattrices, Fox, Wild-Cat, Rattoons, Martins, Mu≈øqua≈øh, Moo≈øe-skins.

Ships they have none, but do prettily imitate ours in their Birchen-pinnaces, their Canows are made of Birch, they ≈øhape them with flat Ribbs of white Cedar, and cover them with large ≈øheets of Birch-bark, ≈øowing them through with ≈øtrong threds of Spru≈øe-Roots or white Cedar, and pitch them with a mixture of Turpentine and the hard ro≈øen that is dryed with the Air on the out≈øide of the Bark of Firr-Trees. The≈øe will carry half a dozen or three or four men and a con≈øiderable fraight, in the≈øe they ≈øwim to Sea twenty, nay forty miles, keeping from the ≈øhore a league or two, ≈øometimes to ≈øhorten their voyage when they are to double a Cape they will put to ≈øhore, and
two of them taking up the Canow carry it cro≈øs the Cape or neck of land to the other ≈øide, and to Sea again; they will indure an incredible great Sea, mounting upon the working billowes like a piece of Corke, but they require skilful hands to guide them in rough weather, none but the Indians ≈øcarce dare to undertake it, ≈øuch like Ve≈ø≈øels the Ancient Brittains u≈øed, as Lucan relates.

q.l: Primum cana ≈øalix, madefacto vimine, parvam
Texitur in puppim, cae≈øoque induta juvenco,
Vectoris patiens tumidum ≈øuper emicat amnem.
Sic Venetus ≈øtagnante Pado, fu≈øoque Britanus
Navigat oceano‚Äî
When Sicoris to his own banks re≈øtor'd
Had left the field, of twigs, and willow boord
They made ≈ømall Boats, cover'd with Bullocks bide,
In which they reacht the Rivers further ≈øide.
So ≈øail the Veneti if Padus flow,
The Brittains ≈øail on their calm ocean ≈øo:
So the Aegyptians ≈øail with woven Boats
Of paper ru≈øhes in their Nilus Floats.

div.p: Their Government is monarchical, the Patrueius or they that de≈øcend from the elde≈øt proceeding from his loyns, is the Roytelet of the Tribe, and if he have Daughters, his Son dying without a Son, the Government de≈øcends to his Daughters Son: after the ≈øame manner, their lands de≈øcend. Cheetadaback was the chief Sachem or Roytelet of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets, when the Engli≈øh fir≈øt ≈øet down there. Ma≈ø≈øa≈øoit, the great Sachem of the Plimouth Indians, his dwelling was at a place called Sowans, about four miles di≈øtant from New-Plimouth‚ñ™ Sa≈øa≈øacus was the chief Sachem of the Pequets, and Mientoniack of the Narragan≈øets. The chief Roytelet among≈øt the Mohawks now living, is a Dutchmans Ba≈øtard, and the Roytelet now of the Pocanakets, that is the Plimouth-Indians, is Prince Philip alias Metacon, the Grand≈øon of Ma≈ø≈øa≈øoit. Among≈øt the Ea≈øtern Indians, Summer≈øant formerly was a famous Sachem. The now living Sachems of note are Sabaccaman, Terrumkin and Robinhood.

Their Wars are with Neighbouring Tribes, but the Mowhawks are enemies to all the other Indians, their weapons of Defence and Offence are Bowes and Arrowes, of late he is a poor Indian that is not ma≈øter
of two Guns, which they purcha≈øe of the French, and powder and ≈øhot, they are generally excellent marks men; their other weapons are Tamahawks which are ≈øtaves two foot and a half long with a knob at the end as round as a bowl, and as big as that we call the Jack or Mi≈øtri≈øs. Lances too they have made (as I have ≈øaid before) with broken ≈øword blades, likewi≈øe they have Hatchers and knives; but the≈øe are weapons of a latter date. They colour their faces red all over, ≈øuppo≈øing that it makes them the more terrible, they are lu≈øty Souldiers to ≈øee to and very ≈øtrong, meer Hercules Ru≈øticu≈øes, their fights are by Ambu≈øhments and Surpri≈øes, coming upon one another unawares. They will march a hundred miles through thick woods and ≈øwamps to the Mowhawks Countrey, and the Mowhawks into their Countrey, meeting ≈øometimes in the woods, or when they come into an Enemies Countrey build a rude fort with Pallizadoes, having loop-holes out of which they ≈øhoot their Arrowes, and fire their Guns, pelting at one another a week or moneth together; If any of them ≈øtep out of the Fort they are in danger to be taken pri≈øoners by the one ≈øide or the other; that ≈øide that gets the victory excoriats the hair≈øcalp of the principal ≈ølain Enemies which
they bear away in Triumph, their pri≈øoners they bring home, the old men and women they knock in the head, the young women they keep, and the men of war they torture to death, as the Ea≈øtern Indians did two M ‚Ä¢ whawks whil≈øt I was there, they bind him to a Tree and make a great fire before him, then with ≈øharp knives they cut off the fir≈øt joynts of his fingers and toes, then c ‚Ä¢ ap upon them hot Embers to ≈øear the vains; ≈øo they cut him a pieces joynt after joynt, ≈øtill applying hot Embers to the place to ≈øtanch the bloud, making the poor wretch to ≈øing all the while: when Arms and Legs are gone, they fl ‚Ä¢ y off the skin of their Heads, and pre≈øently put on a Cap of burning Embers, then they open his brea≈øt and take out his heart, which while it is yet living in a manner they give to their old Squaes, who are every one to have a bite at it. The≈øe Barbarous Cu≈øtoms were u≈øed among≈øt them more frequently before the Engli≈øh came; but ≈øince by the great mercy of the Almighty they are in a way to be Civilized and converted to Chri≈øtianity; there being three Churches of Indians gathered together by the pains of Mr. John Eliot and his Son, who Preaches to them in their Native language, and hath rendered the Bible in that Language for the benefit of
the Indians. The≈øe go clothed like the Engli≈øh, live in framed hou≈øes, have flocks of Corn and Cattle about them, which when they are fat they bring to the Engli≈øh Markets, the Hogs that they rear are counted the be≈øt in New-England. Some of their Sons have been brought up Scholars in Harvard Colledge, and I was told that there was but two Fellowes in that Colledge, and one of them was an Indian; ≈øome few of the≈øe Chri≈øtian Indians have of late Apo≈øtatized and fallen back to their old Super≈øtition and cour≈øe of life.

Thus much ≈øhall ≈øuffice concerning New-England, as it was when the Indians ≈øolely po≈ø≈øe≈øt it. I will now proceed to give you an accompt of it, as it is under the management of the Engli≈øh; but methinks I hear my ≈øceptick Readers muttering out of their ≈øcuttle mouths, what will accrew to us by this rambling Logodiarce? you do but bring ≈øtraw into Egypt, a Countrey abounding with Corn. Thus by the≈øe Famacides who are ≈øo minutely curious, I am dejected from my hope, whil≈øt they challenge the freedom of David's Ru≈ø≈øins, Our Tongues are our own, who ≈øhall controll us. I have done what I can to plea≈øe you, I have piped and you will not dance. I have told you as ≈øtrange things as ever you or your Fathers
have heard. The Italian ≈øaith Chi vide un miraculo facilmente ne crede un altro, he that hath ≈øeen one miracle will ea≈øilie believe another, miranda canunt ≈øed non credenda poetae. Oh I ≈øee the pad, you never heard nor ≈øaw the like, therefore you do not believe me; well Sirs I ≈øhall not ≈øtrain your belief and further, the following Relation I hope will be more tolerable, yet I could (it is po≈ø≈øible) in≈øert as wonderful things as any my pen hath yet gone over, and may, but it mu≈øt be upon condition you will not put me to the proof of it. Nemo tenetur ad impo≈ø≈øibilia, no man is obliged to do more than is in his power, is a rule in law. To be ≈øhort; if you cannot with the Bee gather the honey, with the Spider ≈øuck out the poy≈øon, as Sir John Davis hath it.

q.l: The Bee and Spider by a divers power
Suck honey and poy≈øon from the ≈øelf-≈øame flower.

div.p:
I am confident you will get but little poy≈øon here, no 'tis the poy≈øon of A≈øps under your tongue that ≈øwells you: truly, I do take you rather to be Spider catchers than Spiders, ≈øuch as will not laudably imploy them≈øelves, nor ≈øuffer others; you may well ≈øay non amo hominem, ≈øed non po≈ø≈øum
dicere quare, unle≈øs it be becau≈øe I am a Verone≈ø≈øa, no Romancer. To conclude; if with your mother wit, you can mend the matter, take pen in hand and fall to work, do your Countrey ≈øome ≈øervice as I have done according to my Talent. Henceforth you are to expect no more Relations from me. I am now return'd into my Native Countrey, and by the providence of the Almighty, and the bounty of my Royal Soveraigne≈øs am di≈øpo≈øed to a holy quiet of ≈øtudy and meditation for the good of my ≈øoul; and being ble≈ø≈øed with a tran≈ømentitation or change of mind, and weaned from the world, may take up for my word, non e≈øt mortale quod opto. If what I have done is thought uprears for the approvement of tho≈øe to whom it is intended, I ≈øhall be more than meanly contented.

New-England was fir≈øt di≈øcovered by John Cabota and his Son Seba≈øtian in Anno Dom. 1514. A further di≈øcovery afterwards was made by the honourable Sir Walter Rawleigh Knight in Anno 1584. when as Virginia was di≈øcovered, which together with Mary-land, New-England, Nova Scotia was known by one common name to the Indians, Wingandicoa, and by Sir Walter Rawleigh in honour of our Virgin Queen, in who≈øe n ‚Ä¢ me he took po≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øion of it, Virginia. In
King James his Reign it was divided into Provinces as is before named. In 1602. the≈øe north parts were further di≈øcovered by Capt. Bartholomew Go≈ønold. The fir≈øt Engli≈øh that planted there, ≈øet down not far from the Narragan≈øets-Bay, and called their Colony Plimouth, ≈øince old Plimouth, An. Dom. 1602. Sir John Popham Lord chief Ju≈øtice authorized by his Maje≈øty, King James, ≈øent a Colony of Engli≈øh to Sagadebock, An. 1606. Newfound-land was di≈øcovered by one Andrew Thorn an Engli≈øh man in Anno 1527. Sir Humphrey Gilbert a we≈øt Countrey Knight took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of it in the Queens name, Anno 1582. The two fir≈øt Colonies in New-England failing, there was a fre≈øh ≈øupply of Engli≈øh who ≈øet down in other parts of the Countrey, and have continued in a flouri≈øhing condition to this day.

The whole Countrey now is divided into Colonies, and for your better under≈øtanding ob≈øerve, a Colony is a ≈øort of people that come to inhabit a place before not inhabited, or Colonus qua≈øi, becau≈øe they ≈øhould be Tillers of the Earth. From hence by an u≈øual figure the Countrey where they ≈øit down, is called a Colony or Plantation.

The fir≈øt of the≈øe that I ≈øhall relate of, though la≈øt in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Engli≈øh, is now our mo≈øt Southerly Colony, and next
adjoyning to Mary-land, ≈øcil. the Manad ‚Ä¢ es or Manahanent lying upon the great R ‚Ä¢ ver Mohegan, which was fir≈øt di≈øcovered by Mr. Hud≈øon, and ≈øold pre≈øently by him to the Dutch without Authority from his Soveraign the King of England, Anno 1608. The Dutch in 1614 began to plant there, and call'd it New-Netherlands, but Sir Samuel Argal Governour of Virginia routed them, the Dutch after this got leave of King James to put in there for fre≈øh water in their pa≈ø≈øage to Bra≈øile, and did not offer to plant until a good while after the Engli≈øh were ≈øettled in the Countrey. In Anno 1664 his Maje≈øtie Charles the Second ≈øent over ≈øour worthie Gentlemen Commi≈ø≈øioners to reduce the Colonies into their bounds, who had before incroached upon one another, who marching with Three hundred red-Coats to Manadaes or Manhataes took from the Dutch their chief town then called New-Am≈øterdam, now New York, the Twenty ninth of Augu≈øt turn'd out their Governour with a ≈øilver leg, and all but tho≈øe that were willing to acknowledge ≈øubjection to the King of England, ≈øuffering them to enjoy their hou≈øes and e≈øtates as before. Thirteen days after Sir Robert Care took the Fort and Town of Auravia now called Albany; and Twelve days after that, the Fort and Town
of Aw≈øapha, then De-la-ware Ca≈øtle, man'd with Dutch and Sweeds. So now the Engli≈øh are ma≈øters of three hand≈øome Towns, three ≈øtrong Forts and a Ca≈øtle, not lo≈øing one man. The fir≈øt Governour of the≈øe parts for the King of England was Colonel Nicols, a noble Gentleman, and one of his Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners, who coming for England in Anno Dom. 1668 as I take it, ≈øurrendered the Government to Colonel Longlace.

The Countrey here is ble≈ø≈ø'd with the ‚Ä¢ iche≈øt ≈øoil in all New-England, I have heard it reported from men of Judgement and Integrity, that one Bu≈øhel of European-Wheat hath yielded a hundred in one year. Their other Commodities are Furs, and the „Äà‚óä„Äâ .

New-York is ≈øituated at the mouth of the great River Mohegan, and is built with Dutch Brick alla-moderna, the meane≈øt hou≈øe therein being valued at One hundred pounds, to the Landward it is compa≈ø≈øed with a Wall of good thickne≈øs; at the entrance of the River is an I≈øland well fortified, and hath command of any Ship that ≈øhall attempt to pa≈øs without their leave.
Albany is ≈øituated upon the ≈øame River on the We≈øt-≈øide, and is due North from New-York ≈øomewhat above Fifty miles.

Along the Sea-≈øide Ea≈øtward are many Engli≈øh-Towns, as fir≈øt We≈øtche≈øter, a Sea-Town about Twenty miles from New-York; to the Ea≈øtward of this is Greenwich, another Sea-Town much about the ≈øame di≈øtance; then Chiche≈øter, Fairfield, Stratford, Milford, all Sea-Towns twenty and thirty mile di≈øtant from one another, twenty miles Ea≈øtward of Milford is Newhaven the Metropolis of the Colony begun in 1637. One Mr. Eaton being there Governour: it is near to the ≈øhoals of Cape Cod, and is one of the four united Colonies.
The next Sea-Town Ea≈øtward of New-haven is called Guilford about ten mile, and I think belonging to that Colony.

From Guilford to Connecticut-River, is near upon twenty miles, the fre≈øh River Connecticut bears the name of another Colony begun in the year 1636 and is al≈øo one of the four united Colonies. Upon this River are ≈øituated 13 Towns, within two, three & four miles off one another. At the mouth of the River, on the We≈øt-≈øide is the Lord-Say, and Brooks fort, called Saybrook-fort. Beyond this Northward is the Town of Wind≈øor, then Northampton, then Pin≈øers-hou≈øe. On the Ea≈øt≈øide of the River, Hartford, about it low land well ≈øtored with meadow and very fertile. Wethersfield is
al≈øo ≈øituated upon Connecticut River and Springfield; but this Town although here ≈øeated, is in the juri≈ødiction of the Mattachu≈øets, and hath been infamous by rea≈øon of Witches therein. Hadley lyes to the Northward of Springfield. New-London which I take to be in the juri≈ødiction of this Coloney is ≈øituated to the Ea≈øtward of Connecticut-River by a ≈ømall River, and is not far from the Sea From Connecticut-River long I≈øland ≈øtretcheth it ≈øelf to Mohegan one hundred and twenty miles, but it is but marrow and about ≈øixteen miles from the main; the con≈øiderable≈øt Town upon it is Southampton built on the South≈øide of the I≈øland towards the Ea≈øtern end: oppo≈øite to this on the Northern≈øide is Fever≈øham, We≈øtward is A≈øhford, Huntingdon, &c. The I≈øland is well ≈øtored with Sheep and other Cattle, and Corn, and is rea≈øonable populous. Between this I≈øland and the mouth of Connecticut-River lyeth three ≈ømall I≈ølands, Shelter-I≈øland, Fi≈øhers-I≈øland, and the I≈øle of Wight. The next place of note on the Main is Narragan≈øets-Bay, within which Bay is Rhode-I≈øland a Harbour for the Shunamiti≈øh Brethren, as the Saints Errant, the Quakers who are rather to be e≈øteemed Vagabonds, than Religious per≈øons, &c.

At the further end of the Bay by the mouth of Narragan≈øets-River, on the South-≈øide thereof was old Plimouth plantation Anno 1602. To the Ea≈øtward of Martin's vinyard lyeth Nantocket-I≈øland, and further Ea≈øtward Elizabeths-I≈øland, the≈øe I≈ølands are twenty or thirty mile a≈øunder, and now we are come to Cape-Cod.

Cape-Cod was ≈øo called at the fir≈øt by Captain Go≈ønold and his Company Anno Dom. 1602, becau≈øe they took much of that fi≈øh there; and afterward was called Cape-James by Captain Smith: the point of the Cape is called Point-Cave and Tuckers Terror, and by the French and Dutch Mallacar, by rea≈øon of the perillous ≈øhoals. The fir≈øt place to be taken notice of on the South-≈øide of the Cape is We≈øts-Harbour, the fir≈øt Sea-Town Sandwich formerly called Duxbury in the Juri≈ødiction of New-Plimouth. Doubling the Cape we come into the great Bay, on the We≈øt whereof is New-Plimouth-Bay, on the Southwe≈øt-end of this Bay is ≈øituated New Plimouth, the fir≈øt Engli≈øh-Colony that took firm po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion in this Countrey, which was in 1620, and the fir≈øt Town built

The other Towns of note in this Colony are Green-Harbour to the Ea≈øtward of Plimonth towards the point of the Cape, & therefore ≈øomewhat unacce≈ø≈øible by land, here is excellent Timber for ≈øhipping; then Mar≈øhfield, Yarmouth, Rehoboth, Bridgwater, Warwick, Taunton, Ea≈øtham, by the Indians called Nam≈øet.

The fir≈øt Town Northea≈øt from Greenbarbor is Sittuate in the juri≈ødiction of the Mattachu≈øets-Colony, more Northward of Sittuate is Conchu≈ø≈øet and Hull a little Burg lying open to the Sea, from thence we came to Merton-point over again≈øt which is Pullin-point. Upon Merton-point (which is on the Larboard-≈øide) is a Town called Nanta≈øcot, which is two Leagues from Bo≈øton, where

The Bay is large, made by many I≈ølands, the chief Deere-I≈øland, which is within a flight ≈øhot of Pullin-point, great ≈øtore of Deere were wont to ≈øwim thither from the Main; then Bird-I≈øland, Gla≈øs-I≈øland, Slate-I≈øland, the Governours Garden, where the fir≈øt Apple-Trees in the Countrey were planted, and a vinyard; then Round-I≈øland, and Noddles-I≈øland not far from Charles-Town: mo≈øt of the≈øe I≈ølands lye on the North-≈øide of the Bay.
The next Town to Nanta≈øcot on the South-≈øide of the Bay is Wi≈ø≈øagu≈øet a ≈ømall Village, about three miles from Mount-wolle≈øton, about this Town the ≈øoil is very ≈øertile.

Within ≈øight of this is Mount-wolle≈øton or Merry-mount, called Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets-fields,

S ‚Ä¢ x miles beyond Braintree lyeth Dorche≈øter, a frontire Town plea≈øantly ≈øeated, and of large extent into the main land, well watered with two ≈ømall Rivers, her body and wings filled ≈øomewhat thick with hou≈øes to the number of two hundred and more, beautified with fair Orchards and Gardens, having al≈øo plenty of Cornland, and ≈øtore of Cattle, counted the greate≈øt Town heretofore in New-England, but now gives way to Bo≈øton, it hath a Harbout to the North for Ships.

A mile from Dorche≈øter is the Town of Roxbury, a fair and hand≈øome Countrey Town, the ≈øtreets large, the Inhabitants rich, repleni≈øhed with Orchards and Gardens, well watered with ≈øprings and ≈ømall fre≈øhets, a brook runs through it called Smelt-River, a quarter of a mile to the North-≈øide of the Town runs ≈øtony River: it is ≈øeated in the bottom of a ≈øhallow Bay, but hath no harbour for ≈øhipping. Two miles Northea≈øt from Roxbury, and
Forty miles from New-Plimouth, in the latitude of 42 or 43 degrees and 10 minutes, in the bottom of Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets-Bay is Bo≈øton (who≈øe longitude is 315 degrees, or as others will 322 degrees and 30 ≈øeconds.) So called from a Town in Lincoln≈øhire, which in the Saxons time bare the name of St. Botolph, and is the Metropolis of this Colony, or rather of the whole Countrey, ≈øituated upon a Penin≈øula, about four miles in compa≈øs, almo≈øt ≈øquare, and invironed with the Sea, ≈øaving one ≈ømall I≈øthmus which gives acce≈øs to other Towns by land on the South-≈øide. The Town hath two hills of equal height on the frontire part thereof next the Sea, the one well fortified on the ≈øuperficies with ≈øome Artillery mounted, commanding any Ship as ≈øhe ≈øails into the Harbour within the ≈øtill Bay; the other hill hath a very ≈øtrong battery built of whole Timber and fill'd with earth, at the de≈øcent of the hill in the extreame≈øt part thereof, betwixt the≈øe two ≈øtrong Arms, lyes a large Cove or Bay, on which the chiefe≈øt part of the Town is built, to the Northwe≈øt is a high mountain that out-tops all, with its three little ri≈øing hills on the ≈øummit called Tramount, this is furni≈øhed with a Beacon and great Guns, from hence you may overlook

look all the I≈ølands in the Bay, and de≈øcry ≈øuch Ships as are upon the Coa≈øt: the hou≈øes are for the mo≈øt part rai≈øed on the Sea-banks and wharfed out with great indu≈øtry and co≈øt, many of them ≈øtanding upon piles, clo≈øe together on each ≈øide the ≈øtreets as in London, and furni≈øhed with many fair ≈øhops, their materials are Brick, Stone, Lime, hand≈øomely contrived, with three meeting Hou≈øes or Churches, and a Town-hou≈øe built upon pillars where the Merchants may confer, in the Chambers above they keep their monethly Courts. Their ≈øtreets are many and large, paved with pebble ≈øtone, and the South-≈øide adorned with Gardens and Orchards. The Town is rich and very populous, much frequented by ≈øtrangers, here is the dwelling of their Governour. On the North-we≈øt and Northea≈øt two con≈øtant Fairs are kept for daily Traffick thereunto. On the South there is a ≈ømall, but plea≈øant Common where the Gallants a little before Sun-≈øet walk with their Marmalet-Madams, as we do in Morefields, &c. till the nine a clock Bell rings them home to their re≈øpective habitations, when pre≈øently the Con≈øtables walk their rounds to ≈øee good orders kept, and to take up loo≈øe people. Two miles from the town,
at a place called Muddy-River, the Inhabitants have Farms, to which belong rich arable grounds and meadows where they keep their Cattle in the Summer, and bring them to Bo≈øton in the Winter; the Harbour before the Town is filled with Ships and other Ve≈ø≈øels for mo≈øt part of the year.
Hingham is a Town ≈øituated upon the Sea-coa≈øts, South-ea≈øt of Charles-River: here is great ≈øtore of Timber, deal-boards, ma≈øts for Ships, white-Cedar, and fi≈øh is here to be had.

Dedham an inland-town ten miles from Bo≈øton in the County of Suffolk well watered with many plea≈øant ≈øtreams, and abounding with Garden fruit; the Inhabitants are Husbandmen, ≈øomewhat more than one hundred Families, having ≈øtore of Cattle and Corn.
The Town of Waymouth lyes open to the Sea, on the Ea≈øt Rocks and Swamps, to the South-ward good ≈øtore of Deer, arable ‚Ä¢ and and meadows.

On the North-≈øide of Bo≈øton flows Charles-River, which is about ≈øix fathom deep, many ≈ømall I≈ølands lye to the Bayward, ‚Ä¢ nd hills on either ≈øide the River, a very good harbour, here may forty Ships ride, ‚Ä¢ he pa≈ø≈øage from Bo≈øton to Charles-Town is ‚Ä¢ y a Ferry worth forty or fifty pounds a
year, and is a quarter of a mile over. The River Mi≈øtick runs through the right ≈øide of the Town, and by its near approach to Charles-River in one place makes a very narrow neck, where ≈øtands mo≈øt part of the Town, the market place not far from the water≈øide is ≈øurrounded with hou≈øes, forth of which i≈ø≈øue two ≈øtreets orderly built and beautified with Orchards and Gardens, their meeting-hou≈øe ≈øtands on the North-≈øide of the market, having a little hill behind it; there belongs to this Town one thou≈øand and two hundred Acres of arable, four hundred head of Cattle, and as many Sheep, the≈øe al≈øo provide them≈øelves Farms in the Country.
Up higher in Charles-River we≈øt-ward is a broad Bay two miles over, into which runs Stony River and Maddy-River.

Towards the South-we≈øt in the middle of the Bay is a great Oy≈øter bank, towards the North-we≈øt is a Creek; upon the ≈øhore is ≈øituated the village of Medford, it is a mile and half from Charles-town.

A ‚Ä¢ the bottom of the Bay the River begins to be narrower, half a quarter of a mile broad; by the North-≈øide of the R ‚Ä¢ ver is New town, three miles from Charles-town, a league and half by water, it was fir≈øt intended
for a City, the neate≈øt and be≈øt compacted Town, having many fair ≈øtructures and hand≈øom contrived ≈øtreets; the Inhabitants rich, they have many hundred Acres of land paled with one common fence a mile and half long, and ≈øtore of Cattle; it is now called Cambridge where is a Colledg for Students of late; it ≈øtretcheth from Charles-River to the Southern part of Merrimach-River.

Half a mile thence on the ≈øame ≈øide of the Rvier is Water-town built upon one of the branches of Charles-River, very fruitful and of large extent, watered with many plea≈øant ≈øprings and ≈ømall Rivulets, the Inhabitants live ≈øcatteringly. Within half a mile is a great pond divided between the two Towns, a mile and half from the Town is a fall of fre≈øh waters which conveigh them≈øelves into the Ocean through Charles-River, a little below the fall of waters they have a wair to catch fi≈øh, wherein they take ≈øtore of Ba≈ø≈øe, Shades, Alwives, Fro≈øt fi≈øh and Smelts, in two tides they have gotten one hundred thou≈øand of the≈øe fi≈øhes. They have ≈øtore of Cattle and Sheep, and near upon two thou≈øand Acres of arable land, Ships of ≈ømall burden may come up to the≈øe Towns.

We will now return to Charles-town again, where the River Mi≈øtick runs on the North-≈øide of the Town (that is the right ≈øide as before ≈øaid) where on the Northwe≈øt-≈øide of the River is the Town of Mi≈øtick, three miles from Charles-town, a league and half by water, a ≈øcattered village; at the head of this River are great and ≈øpacious ponds, full of Alewives in the ≈øpring-time, the noted≈øt place for this ≈øort of fi≈øh. On the We≈øt of this River is M ‚Ä¢ rchant Craddock's plantation, where he impaled a park.
Upon the ≈øame River and on the North-≈øide is the Town of Malden.
The next Town is Winni≈øimet a mile from Charles-town, the River only parting them, this is the la≈øt Town in the ≈øtill bay of Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets.

Without Pullin-point, ≈øix miles North-ca≈øt from Winni≈øimet is Cawgu≈øt, or Sagu≈øt, or Sangut now called Linn, ≈øituated at the bottom of a Bay near a River, which upon the breaking up of winter with a furious Torrent vents it ≈øelf into the Sea, the Town con≈øi≈øts of more than one hundred dwelling-hou≈øes, their Church being built on a level undefended from the North-we≈øt wind is made with ≈øteps de≈øcending
into the Earth, their ≈øtreets are ≈øtraight and but thin of hou≈øes, the people mo≈øt hu≈øbandmen. At the end of the Sandy beach is a neck of land called Nahant, it is ≈øix miles in circumference. Black William an Indian Duke out of his genero≈øity gave this to the Engli≈øh. At the mouth of the River runs a great Creek into a great mar≈øh called Rumney-mar≈øh, which is four miles long, and a mile broad, this Town hath the benefit of minerals of divers kinds, Iron, Lead, one Iron mill, ≈øtore of Cattle, Arable land and meadow.

To the North-ward of Linn is Marvil or Marble-head, a ≈ømall Harbour, the ≈øhore rockie, upon which the Town is built, con≈øi≈øting of a few ≈øcattered hou≈øes; here they have ≈øtages for fi≈øhermen, Orchards and Gardens, half a mile within land good pa≈øtures and Arable land.

Four miles North of Marble-head is ≈øituated New-Salem (who≈øe longitude is 315 degrees, and latitude 42 degrees 35 minutes) upon a plain, having a River on the South, and another on the North, it hath two Harbours, Winter Harbour and Summer Harbour which lyeth within Darbie's ≈øort, they have ≈øtore of Meadow and Arable, in this Town are ≈øome very rich Merchants.

Upon the Northern Cape of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets, that is Cape-Aun a place of fi≈øhing is ≈øituated, the Town of Gloce≈øter where the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets Colony fir≈øt ≈øet down, but Salem was the fir≈øt Town built in that Colony, here is a Harbour for Ships.
To the North-ward of Cape-Aun is Wona≈øquam, a dangerous place to ≈øail by in ≈øtormie weather, by rea≈øon of the many Rocks and ≈øoaming breakers.

The next Town that pre≈øents it ≈øelf to view is Ip≈øwich ≈øituated by a fair River, who≈øe fir≈øt ri≈øe is from a Lake or Pond twenty mile up, betaking its cour≈øe through a hideous Swamp for many miles, a Harbour for Bears, it i≈ø≈øueth forth into a large Bay, (where they fi≈øh for Whales) due Ea≈øt over again≈øt the I≈ølands of Sholes a great place of fi≈øhing, the mouth of that River is barr'd; it is a good haven-town, their meeting-hou≈øe or Church is beautifully built, ≈øtore of Orchards and Gardens, land for hu≈øbandry and Cattle.

Wenham is an inland Town very well watered, lying between Salem and Ip≈øwich, con≈øi≈øteth mo≈øt of men of judgment and experience in re ru≈øtica, well ≈øtored with Cattle. At the fir≈øt ri≈øe of Ip≈øwich-River in the highe≈øt part of the land near the head
≈øprings of many con≈øiderable Rivers; Sha≈øhin one of the mo≈øt con≈øiderable branches of Merrimach River, and al≈øo at the ri≈øe of Mi≈øtick River, and ponds full of plea≈øant ≈øprings, is ≈øituated Wooburn an inland-Town four miles ≈øquare beginning at the end of Charles-town bounds.
Six miles from Ip≈øwich North-ea≈øt is Rowley, mo≈øt of the Inhabitants have been Clothiers.
Nine miles from Salem to the North is Agowamine, the be≈øt and ≈øpaciou≈øe≈øt place for a plantation, being twenty leagues to the Northward of New-Plimouth.

Beyond Agowamin is ≈øituated Hampton near the Sea-coa≈øts not far from Merrimach-River, this Town is like a Flower-deluce, having two ≈øtreets of hou≈øes wheeling off from the main body thereof, they have great ≈øtore of ≈øalt Mar≈øhes and Cattle, the land is fertil, but full of Swamps and Rocks.

Eight miles beyond Agowamin runneth the delightful River Merrimach or Monumach, it is navigable for twenty miles, and well ≈øtored with fi≈øh, upon the banks grow ≈øtately Oaks, excellent Ship timber, not interiour to our Engli≈øh.

On the South-≈øide of Merrimach-River
twelve miles from Ip≈øwich, and near upon the wide venting ≈øtreams thereof is ≈øituated Newherrie, the hou≈øes are ≈øcattering, well ≈øtored with meadow, upland, and ‚Ä¢ rable, and about four hundred head of Cattle.
Over again≈øt Newberrie lyes the Town of Salisbury, where a con≈øtant Ferry is kept, the River being here half a mile broad, the Town ≈øcatteringly built.
H ‚Ä¢ rd upon the River of Sha≈øhin where Merrimach receives this and the other branch into its body, is ≈øeated Andover, ≈øtored with land and Cattle.
Beyond this Town by the branch of Merrimach-River called Sha≈øhin, lyeth Haverhill, a Town of large extent about ten miles in length, the inhabitants Husbandmen, this Town is not far from Salisbury.
Over again≈øt Haverhill lyeth the Town of Malden, which I have already mentioned.

In a low level upon a fre≈øh River a branch of Merrimach is ≈øeated Concord, the fir≈øt inland Town in Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets patent, well ≈øtored with fi≈øh, Salmon, Dace, Alewive, Shade, &c. abundance of fre≈øh mai≈øh and Cattle, this place is ≈øubject to bitter ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ orms.

The next Town is Sudbury built upon the ≈øame River where Concord is, but further up; to this Town likewi≈øe belongs great ≈øtore of fre≈øh mar≈øhes, and Arable land, and they have many Cattle, it lyeth low, by rea≈øon whereof it is much indammaged with flouds.
In the Centre of the Countrey by a great pond ≈øide, and not far from Woeburn, is ≈øituated Reading, it hath two mills, a ≈øawmill and a Corn-mill, and is well ≈øtockt with Cattle.

The Colony is divided into four Counties, the fir≈øt is Suffolk, to which belongs Dorche≈øter, Roxbury, Waymouth, Hingham, Dedham, Braintre, Sittuate, Hull, Nanta≈øcot, Wi≈øagu≈ø≈øet. The ≈øecond County is Middle≈øex, to this belongs Charles-town, Watertown, Cambridge, Concord, Sudbury, Woeburn, Reading, Malden, Mi≈øtick, Medford, Winni≈øimet and Marble-head. To the third County which is E≈ø≈øex, belongs New-Salem, Linn, Ip≈øwich, New-Berry, Rowley, Gloce≈øter, Wenham and Andover. The fourth County is Northfolk, to this belongs Salisbury, Hampton and Haverhill.

In the year of our Lord 1628, Mr. John Endicot with a number of Engli≈øh people ≈øet down by Capt-Aun at that place called
afterwards Glo≈øter, but their abiding-place was at Salem, where they built a Town in 1639. and there they gathered their fir≈øt Church, con≈øi≈øting but of Seventy per≈øons; but afterwards increa≈øed to forty three Churches in joynt Communion with one another, and in tho≈øe Churches were about Seven thou≈øand, ≈øeven hundred and fifty Souls, Mr. Endicot was cho≈øen their fir≈øt Governour.

The Twelfth of July Anno Dom. 1630. John Wenthorp E≈øq and the a≈ø≈øi≈øtants, arrived with the Patent for the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets, the pa≈ø≈øage of the people that came along with him in ten Ve≈ø≈øels came to 95000 pound: the Swine, Goats, Sheep, Neat, Hor≈øes co≈øt to tran≈øport 12000 pound, b ‚Ä¢
≈øides the price they co≈øt them; getting food for the people till they could clear the ground of wood amounted to 45000 pound: Nails, Gla≈øs, and other Iron work for their meeting and dwelling hou≈øes 13000 pound; Arms, Powder, Bullet, and March, together with their Artillery 22000 pound, the whole ≈øum amounts unto One hundred ninety two thou≈øand pounds They ≈øet down fir≈øt upon N ‚Ä¢ ddle-I≈øland afterwards they began to build upon the main. In 1637. there were not many hou≈øes in the Town of
Bo≈øton, among≈øt which were two hou≈øes of entertainment called Ordinaries, into which if a ≈øtranger went, he was pre≈øently followed by one appointed to that Office, who would thru≈øt him≈øelf into his company uninvited, and if he called for more drink than the Officer thought in his judgment he could ≈øoberly bear away, he would pre≈øently countermand it, and appoint the proportion, beyond which he could not get one drop.

The Patent was granted to Sir Henry Ro≈øewell, Sir John Young Knight, Thomas Southcoat, John Humphrey, John Endicot and Simon Whitecomb, and to their Heirs, A≈ø≈øigns, and A≈ø≈øociats for ever. The≈øe took to them other A≈ø≈øociats, as Sir Richard Salton≈øtall, I≈øaac John≈øon, Samuel Alder≈øey, Jo. Ven, Matth Craddock, George Harwood, Increa≈øe Nowell, Rich. Perry, Rich. Bellingham, Nathaniel Wright, Samuel Va≈øell, Theophilus Eaton, Thomas Goffe, Thomas Adams, Jo. Brown, Samuel Brown, Thomas Hutchins, Will Va≈øell, Will. Pinchon and George Foxcroft. Matth. Craddock was ordained and con≈øtituted Governour by Patent, and Thomas Goffe Deputy Governour of the ≈øaid Company, the re≈øt A≈ø≈øi≈øtants.

That part of New-England granted to
the≈øe fore-mentioned Gentlemen lyeth and extendeth between a great River called Monumach, alias Merrimach, and the often frequented Charles-River, being in the bottom of a Bay called Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets, alias Mattachu≈øets, alias Ma≈ø≈øatu≈øets-bay; and al≈øo tho≈øe lands within the ≈øpace of three Engli≈øh miles, on the South part of the ≈øaid Charles-River, or any or every part, and all the lands within three miles to the South-ward part of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets-bay, and all tho≈øe lands which lye within the ≈øpace of three Engli≈øh miles to the North-ward of the River Merrimach, or to the North-ward of any and every part thereof, and all lands what≈øoever within the limits afore≈øaid, North and South, in latitude, and in breadth and length and longitude of and within all the main land there, from the Atlantick and We≈øtern-Sea and Ocean on the Ea≈øt-part, to the South-Sea on the We≈øt-part, and all lands and grounds, place and places, ≈øoils, woods and wood-groves, Havens, Ports, Rivers, Waters, fi≈øhings and Hereditaments what≈øoever lying within the afore≈øaid lands and limits, and every part and parcel thereof, and al≈øo all I≈ølands lying in America afore≈øaid in the ≈øaid Seas, or either of them on the We≈øtern or Ea≈øtern
Coa≈øts or parts of the ≈øaid tracts of lands. Al≈øo all mines and minerals as well Royal of Gold, Silver, as others &c. With power to rule and govern both Sea and land, holden of the Ea≈øt manner of Greenwich in Com. Kent, in free and common ≈øoccage, yielding and paying to the King the fifth part of the Oar of Gold and Silver which ≈øhall be found at any time.
This Colony is a body Corporated and Politick in fact by the name of the Governour and Company of the Mattachu≈øets-bay in New-England.
That there ≈øhall be one Governour, and Deputy-Governour, and Eighteen A≈ø≈øi≈øtants of the ≈øame Company from time to time.
That the Governour and Deputy-Governour, A≈ø≈øi≈øtants and all other Officers to be cho≈øen from among≈øt the freemen, the la≈øt Wedne≈øday in Ea≈øter-term yearly in the general Court.
The Governour to take his Corporal Oath to be true and faithful to the Government, and to give the ≈øame Oath to the other Officers.
To hold a Court once a month, and any ≈øeven to be a ≈øufficient Court.

And that there ≈øhall be four general Courts kept in Term time, and one great general and ≈øolemn A≈ø≈øembly to make Laws and Ordinances; So they be not contrary and repugnant to the Laws and Statutes of the Realm of England. Their form of Government and what their Laws concern, you may ≈øee in the en≈øuing Table.

list.item:

1 Of buying and ≈øelling.
