2 That they do us wrong.

div.p: Anno Dom. 1646. they drew up a body of their Laws for the well ordering of their Commonwealth, as they not long ≈øince termed it.

The military part of their Commonwealth is governed by one Major-General, and three Serjeant Majors; to the Major-General belongeth particularly the Town of Bi≈øton, to the three Serjeant Majors belong the four Counties, but with ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to the Major-General. The fir≈øt Serjeant Major cho≈øen for the County of Suffolk was Major Gibbons. For the County of Middle≈øex Major Sedgwick. For the County of E≈ø≈øex and Northfolk Major Deni≈øon.
Every Town ≈øends two Burge≈ø≈øes to their great and ≈øolemn general Court.
For being drunk, they either whip or impo≈øe a fine of Five ≈øhillings; ≈øo for ≈øwearing and cur≈øing, or boring through the tongue with a hot Iron.
For k ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øing a woman in the ≈øtreet, though in way of civil ≈øalute, whipping or a fine.
For Single fornication whipping or a fine.
For Adultery, put to death, and ≈øo for Witchcraft.

An Engli≈øh woman ≈øuffering an Indian to have carnal knowledge of her, had an Indian cut out exactly in red cloth ≈øewed
upon her right Arm, and injoyned to wear it twelve moneths.
Scolds they gag and ≈øet them at their doors for certain hours, for all comers and goers by to gaze at.
Stealing is puni≈øhed with re≈øtoring four fould, if able; if not, they are ≈øold for ≈øome years, and ≈øo are poor debtors.
If you de≈øire a further in≈øpection to their Laws, I mu≈øt refer you to them being in print, too many for to be in≈øerted into this Relation.
The Governments of their Churches are Independent and Presbyterial, every Church (for ≈øo they call their particular Congregations) have one Pa≈øtor, one Teacher, Ruling Elders and Deacons.

They that are members of their Churches have the Sacraments admini≈øtred to them, the re≈øt that are out of the pale as they phra≈øe it, are denyed it. Many hundred Souls there be among≈øt them grown up to men & womens e≈øtate that were never Chri≈øtened.

They judge every man and woman to pay Five ≈øhillings per day, who comes not to their A≈ø≈øemblies, and impo≈øe fines of forty ≈øhillings and fifty ≈øhillings on ≈øuch as meet together to wor≈øhip God.
Quakers they whip, bani≈øh, and hang if they return again.
Anabapti≈øts they impri≈øon, fine and weary out.
The Government both Civil and Eccle≈øia≈øtical is in the hands of the thorow-pac'd Independents and rigid Presbyterians.

The gro≈øe Goddons, or great ma≈øters, as al≈øo ≈øome of their Merchants are damnable rich; generally all of their judgement, inexplicably covetous and proud, they receive your gifts but as an homage or tribute due to their tran≈øcendency, which is a fault their Clergie are al≈øo guilty of, who≈øe living is upon the bounty of their hearers. On Sundays in the afternoon when Sermon is ended the people in the Galleries come down and march two a brea≈øt up one Ile and down the other, until they come before the desk, for Pulpit they have none: before the desk is a long pue where the Elders and Deacons ≈øit, one of them with a mony box in his hand, into which the people as they pa≈øs put their offering, ≈øome a ≈øhilling, ≈øome two ≈øhillings, half a Crown, five ≈øhillings according to their ability and good will, after this they conclude with a P≈øalm; but this by the way.

The chiefe≈øt objects of di≈øcipline, Religion,
and morality they want, ≈øome are of a Lin≈øie-wool≈øie di≈øpo≈øition, of ≈øeveral profe≈ø≈øions in Religion, all like Aethiopians white in the Teeth, only full of ludification and injurious dealing, and cruelty the extreame≈øt of all vices. The chiefe≈øt cau≈øe of Noah's floud, Prov. 27.26. Agni erant ad ve≈øtitum tuum, is a frequent Text among them, no trading for a ≈øtranger with them, but with a Graecian faith, which is not to part with your ware without ready money, for they are generally in their payments recu≈øant and ≈ølow, great Syndies, or cen≈øors, or controllers of other mens manners, and ≈øavagely factious among≈øt them≈øelves.
There are main travelling women too, (in Salomon's ≈øence) more the pitty, when a woman hath lo≈øt her Cha≈øtity, ≈øhe hath no more to lo≈øe.

But mi≈øtake me not to general ≈øpeeches, none but the guilty take exceptions, there are many ≈øincere and religious people among≈øt them, de≈øcryed by their charity and humility (the true Characters of Chri≈øtianity) by their Zenodochie or ho≈øpitality, by their hearty ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to their Soveraign the King of England, by their diligent and hone≈øt labour in their callings, among≈øt the≈øe we may account the Royali≈øts, who are lookt upon with an evil eye and
tongue, boulted or puni≈øhed if they chance to la≈øh out, the tame Indian (for ≈øo they call tho≈øe that are born in the Countrey) are pretty hone≈øt too, and may in good time be known for hone≈øt Kings men.

They have ≈øtore of Children, and are well accommodated with Servants; many hands make light work, many hands make a full fraught, but many mouths eat up all, as ≈øome old planters have experimented; of the≈øe ≈øome are Engli≈øh, others Negroes: of the Engli≈øh there are can eat till they ≈øweat, and work till they freeze; & of the females that are like Mrs. Winters paddocks, very tender fingerd in cold weather.

There are none that beg in the Countrey, but there be Witches too many, bottle-bellied Witches among≈øt the Quakers, and others that produce many ≈øtrange apparitions if you will believe report, of a Shallop at Sea man'd with women, of a Ship and a great red Hor≈øe ≈øtanding by the main-ma≈øt, the Ship being in a ≈ømall Cove to the Ea≈øtward vani≈øhed of a ≈øuddain. Of a Witch that appeared aboard of a Ship twenty leagues to Sea to a Mariner who took up the Carpenters broad Axe and cleft her head with it, the Witch dying of the wound at home, with ≈øuch like bugbears and Terriculamentaes.
It is publi≈øhed in print, that there are not much le≈øs than Ten hundred thou≈øand ≈øouls Engli≈øh, Scotch and Iri≈øh in New-England.

Mo≈øt of their fir≈øt Magi≈øtrates are dead, not above two left in the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets, but one at Plimouth, one at Connecticut, and one at New-haven, they having done their generation work are laid a≈øleep in their beds of re≈øt till the day of doom, there and then to receive their reward according as they have done be it good or evil. Things of great indurance we ≈øee come to ruine, and alter, as great Flouds and Seas dryed up; mighty hills and mountains ≈øunk into hollow bottoms: marvel not then that man is mortal, ≈øince his nature is uncon≈øtant and tran≈øitory.

The Di≈øea≈øes that the Engli≈øh are afflicted with, are the ≈øame that they have in England, with ≈øome proper to New England, griping of the belly (accompanied with Feaver and Ague) which turns to the bloudy-fl ‚Ä¢ x, a common di≈øea≈øe in the Countrey, which together with the ≈ømall pox hath carried away abundance of their children, for this the common medicines among≈øt the poorer ≈øort are Pills of Cotton ≈øwallowed, or Sugar and Sallet-oyl boiled thick and made into Pills, Alloes pulverized
and taken in the pap of an Apple. I helped many of them with a ≈øweating medicine only.

Al≈øo they are troubled with a di≈øea≈øe in the mouth or throat which hath proved mortal to ≈øome in a very ≈øhort time, Quin≈øies, and Impo≈øtumations of the Almonds, with great di≈øtempers of cold. Some of our New-England writers affirm that the Engli≈øh are never or very rarely heard to ≈øneeze or cough, as ordinarily they do in England, which is not true. For a cough or ≈øtitch upon cold, Wormwood, Sage, Marygolds, and Crabs-claws boiled in po≈ø≈øet-drink and drunk off very warm, is a ≈øoveraign medicine.

Pleuri≈øies and Empyemas are frequent there, both cured after one and the ≈øame way; but the la≈øt is a de≈øperate di≈øea≈øe and kills many. For the Pleuri≈øie I have given Coriander-≈øeed prepared, Carduus-≈øeed, and Harts-horn pulverized with good ≈øucce≈øs, the do≈øe one dram in a cup of Wine.
The Stone terribly afflicts many, and the Gout, and Sciatica, for which take Onions roa≈øted, peeled and ≈øtampt, then boil them with neats-feet oyl and Rhum to a plai≈øter, and apply it to the hip.

Head-aches are frequent, Pal≈øies, Drop≈øies, Worms, Noli-me-tangeres, Cancers,
pe≈øtilent Feavers. Scurvies, the body corrupted with Sea-diet, Beef and Pork tainted, Butter and Chee≈øe corrupted, fi≈øh rotten, a long voyage, coming into the ≈øearching ≈øharpne≈øs of a purer climate, cau≈øeth death and ≈øickne≈øs among≈øt them.

Men and Women keep their complexions, but lo≈øe their Teeth: the Women are pittifully Tooth-≈øhaken; whether through the coldne≈øs of the climate, or by ≈øweetmeats of which they have ≈øtore, I am not able to affirm, for the Toothach I have found the following medicine very available, Brim≈øtone and Gunpowder compounded with butter, rub the mandible with it, the out≈øide being fir≈øt warm'd.
For falling off of the hair occa≈øioned by the coldne≈øs of the climate, and to make it curl, take of the ≈øtrong water called Rhum and wa≈øh or bath your head therewith, it is an admirable remedie.
For kibed heels, to heal them take the yellowe≈øt part of Rozen, pulverize it and work it in the palm of your hand with the tallow of a Candle to a ≈øalve, and lay of it to the ≈øore.
For frozen limbs, a plai≈øter framed with Soap, Bay-≈øalt, and Molo≈ø≈øes is ≈øure, or Cow-lung boiled in milk and applyed.
For Warts and Corns, bathe them with Sea-water.

There was in the Countrey not long ≈øince living two men that voided worms ≈øeven times their length. Likewi≈øe a young maid that was troubled with a ≈øore pricking at her heart, ≈øtill as ≈øhe lean'd her body or ≈øtept down with her ≈øoot to the one ≈øide or the other; this maid during her di≈øtemper voided worms of the length of a finger all hairy with black heads; it ≈øo fell out that the maid dyed; her friends de≈øirous to di≈øcover the cau≈øe of the di≈øtemper of her heart, had her open'd, and found two crooked bones growing upon the top of the heart, which as ≈øhe bowed her body to the right or left ≈øide would job their points into one and the ≈øame place, till they had worn a hole quite through. At Cape-Porpus lived an hone≈øt poor planter of middle-ige, and ≈øtrong of body, but ≈øo extreamly troubled with two lumps (or wens as I conjectured) within him, on each ≈øide one, that he could not re≈øt for them day nor night, being of great weight, and ≈øwagging to the one ≈øide or the other, according to the motion or po≈øture of his body; at la≈øt he dyed in Anno 1668 as I think, or thereabouts. Some Chirurgeons there were that proffered to open him, but his wife would not a≈ø≈øent to it, and ≈øo his di≈øea≈øe was hidden in the Grave.

It is the opinion of many men, that the blackne≈øs of the Negroes proceeded from the cur≈øe upon Cham's po≈øterity, others again will have it to be the property of the climate where they live. I pa≈øs by other Philo≈øophical rea≈øons and skill, only render you my experimental knowledge: having a Barbarie-moor under cure, who≈øe finger (prickt with the bone of a fi≈øh) was Impo≈øtumated, after I had lanc'd it and let out the Corruption the skin began to ri≈øe with proud fle≈øh under it; this I wore away, and having made a ≈øound bottom I incarnated it, and then laid on my skinning plai≈øter, then I perceived that the Moor had one skin more than Engli≈øhmen; the skin that is ba≈øted to the fle≈øh is bloudy and of the ≈øame Azure colour with the veins, but deeper than the colour of our Europeans veins. Over this is an other skin of a tawny colour, and upon that Epidermis or Cuticula, the flower of the skin (which is that Snakes ca≈øt) and this is tawny al≈øo, the colour of the blew skin mingling with the tawny makes them appear black. I do not peremptorily affirm this to be the cau≈øe, but ≈øubmit to better judgment. More rarities of this nature I could make known unto you, but I ha≈øten to an end; only a word or two of our Engli≈øh Creatures, and then to Sea again.

I have given you an Account of ≈øuch plants as pro≈øper there, and of ≈øuch as do not; but ≈øo briefly, that I conceive it nece≈ø≈øary to afford you ≈øome what more of them. Plantain I told you ≈øprang up in the Countrey after the Engli≈øh came, but it is but one ≈øort, and that is broad-leaved plantain.

Gilliflowers thrive exceedingly there and are very large, the Collibuy or humming-Bird is much plea≈øed with them. Our Engli≈øh dames make Syrup of them without fire, they ≈øteep them in Wine till it be of a deep colour, and then they put to it ≈øpirit of Vitriol, it will keep as long as the other.

Eglantine or ≈øweet Bryer is be≈øt ≈øowen with Juniper-berries, two or three to one Eglantine-berry put into a hole made with a ≈øtick, the next year ≈øeparate and remove them to your banks, in three years time they will make a hedge as high as a man, which you may keep thick and hand≈øome with cutting.
Our Engli≈øh Clover-gra≈øs ≈øowen thrives very well.
Radi≈øhes I have ≈øeen there as big as a mans Arm.
Flax and Hemp flouri≈øh gallantly.

Our Wheat i. e. ≈øummer Wheat many
times changeth into Rye, and is ≈øubject to be bla≈øted, ≈øome ≈øay with a vapour breaking out of the earth, others, with a wind North-ea≈øt or North-we≈øt, at ≈øuch time as it flowereth, others again ≈øay it is with lightning. I have ob≈øerved, that when a land of Wheat hath been ≈ømitten with a bla≈øt at one Corner, it begins at the ≈øtem (which will be ≈øpotted and goes upwards to the ear making it fruitle≈øs: in 1669 the pond that lyeth between Water-town and Cambridge, ca≈øt its fi≈øh dead upon the ≈øhore, forc't by a mineral vapour as was conjectured.

Our fruit-Trees pro≈øper abundantly, Apple-trees, Pear-trees, Quince-trees, Cherry-trees, Plum-trees, Barberry-trees. I have ob≈øerved with admiration, that the Kernels ≈øownor the Succors planted produce as fair & good fruit, without graffing, as the Tree from whence they were taken: the Countrey is repleni≈øhed with fair and large Orchards. It was affirmed by one Mr. Woolcut (a magi≈øtrate in Connecticut Colony) at the Captains Me≈ø≈øe (of which I was) aboard the Ship I came home in, that he made Five hundred Hog≈øheads of Syder out of his own Orchard in one year. Syder is very plentiful in the Countrey, ordinarily ≈øold for Ten ≈øhillings a Hog≈øhead. At the Taphou≈øes
in Bo≈øton I have had an Ale-quart ≈øpic'd and ≈øweetned with Sugar for a groat, but I ≈øhall in≈øert a more delicate mixture of it. Take of Maligo-Rai≈øons, ≈øtamp them and put milk to them, and put them in an Hippocras-bag and let it drain out of it ≈øelf, put a quantity of this with a ≈øpoonful or two of Syrup of Clove-Gilliflowers into every bottle, when you bottle your Syder, and your Planter will have a liquor that exceeds pa≈ø≈øada, the Nectar of the Countrey.

The Quinces, Cherries, Dam≈øons, ≈øet the Dames a work, Marmalad and pre≈øerved Dam≈øons is to be met with in every hou≈øe. It was not long before I left the Countrey that I made Cherry-wine, and ≈øo may others, for there are good ≈øtore of them both red and black.

Their fruit-trees are ≈øubject two di≈øea≈øes, the Meazels, which is when they are burned and ≈øcorched with the Sun, and low≈øine≈øs, when the wood-peckers job holes in their bark: the way to cure them when they are low≈øie is to bore a hole into the main root with an Augur, and pour in a quantity of Brandie or Rhum, and then ≈øtop it up with a pin made of the ≈øame Tree.

The fir≈øt Neat carried thither was to
New-Plimouth Anno 162 the≈øe thrive and increa≈øe exceedingly, but grow le≈øs in body than tho≈øe they are bred of yearly.

Hor≈øes there are numerous, and here and there a good one, they let them run all the year abroad, and in the winter ≈øeldom provide any fother for them, (except it be Magi≈øtrates, great Ma≈øters and Troopers Hor≈øes) which brings them very low in fle≈øh till the ≈øpring, and ≈øo cre≈øt fallen, that their cre≈øts never ri≈øe again. Here I fir≈øt met with that excre≈øcence called Hippomanes, which by ≈øome is ≈øaid to grow on the forehead of a foal new ca≈øt, and that the Mare bites it off as ≈øoon as foaled; but this is but a fable. A neighbour at Black point having a Mare with foal tyed her up in his Barn, the next day ≈øhe foaled, and the man ≈øtanding by ≈øpied a thing like a foals tongue to drop out of the foals mouth, which he took up and pre≈øented me with it, telling me withall, that he had heard many wonderful things reported of it, and that it was rank poy≈øon. I accepted of it gladly and brought it home with me, when it was dry it lookt like Glow, but of a dark brown colour; to omit all other u≈øes for it, this I can a≈ø≈øure you that a piece of it ≈øoakt in warm water or cold, will take ≈øport out of wollen Clothes being tub'd thereon.

Goats were the fir≈øt ≈ømall Cattle they had in the Countrey, he was counted no body that had not a Trip or Flock of Goats: a hee-Goat gelt at Michaelmas and turn'd out to feed will be fat in a moneths time, & is as good meat as a weather. I was taught by a Barbary Negro a medicine which before I proceed any further I will impart unto you, and that was for a ≈øwelling under the throat. Take Goats hair and clay and boil them in fair water to a poultis, and apply it very warm.
Sheep now they have good ≈øtore, the≈øe and Goats bring forth two, ≈øometimes three Lambs and Kids at a time.

Hoggs are here innumerable, every planter hath a Heard, when they feed upon ≈øhellfi≈øh and the like, as they do that are kept near the Sea and by the fi≈øhers ≈øtages, they ta≈øt fi≈øhie and rank; but fed with white Oak-Acorns, or Indian-Corn and Pea≈øe there is not better Pork in the whole world: be≈øides they ≈øometimes have the Meazels, which is known when their hinder legs are ≈øhorter than ordinary.

Catts and Dogs are as common as in England, but our Dogs in time degenerate; yet they have gallant Dogs both for fowl & wild Bea≈øts all over the Countrey: the Indians ≈øtore them≈øelves with them, being much
better for their turns, than their breed of wild dogs, which are (as I conceive) like to the Ta≈ø≈øo-canes or mountain dogs in Italy.

Of Engli≈øh Poultry too there is good ≈øtore, they have commonly three broods in a year; the hens by that time they are three years old have ≈øpurs like the Cock, but not altogether ≈øo big, but as long, they u≈øe to crow often, which is ≈øo rare a thing in other Countries, that they have a proverb Gallina recinit a Hen crowes. And in England it is accounted ominous; therefore our Farmers wives as ≈øoon as they hear a Hen crow wring off her neck, and ≈øo they ≈øerve their ≈øpur'd Hens, becau≈øe they ≈øhould not break their Eggs with their ≈øpurs when they ≈øit. In the year 1637. which was when I went my fir≈øt Voyage to New-England a good woman brought aboard with her a lu≈øty Cock and Hen that had horns like ≈øpurs growing out on each ≈øide of their Combs, but ≈øhe ≈øpoiled the breed, killing of them at Sea, to feed upon, for ≈øhe loved a fre≈øh bit.

In Anno 1647/8. Certain Indians coming to our hou≈øe clad in Deere-skin coats, de≈øired leave to lodge all night in our kitchin, it being a very rainie ≈øea≈øon, ≈øome of them lay down in the middle of the Room, and others under the Table, in the morning they
went away before any of the people were up; the poultry had their breakfa≈øt u≈øually in cold weather in the kitchin, and becau≈øe they ≈øhould not hinder the pa≈ø≈øing of the people too and again, it was thrown under the Table; in the afternoon they began to hang the wing, in the night the ≈øicke≈øt dropt dead from the perch, and the next day mo≈øt of them dyed; we could not of a ≈øudden ghe≈øs at the cau≈øe, but thought the Indians had either bewitched, or poy≈øoned them: it came at la≈øt into my head, ≈øeeing their Crops very full, or rather much ≈øwell'd, to open them, where I found as much Deers hair as Corn, they that pickt up none of the hair lived and did well.

In the year 1667. October the 7th among≈øt our poultry we had one white game Cock of the French k ‚Ä¢ nd, a bird of high price, when he was three years old he drooped and his ≈øpirit was quite gone; one of our Negro maids finding him in the yard dead brought him into the hou≈øe and acquainted me with it. I cau≈øed her to draw him, when his guts were all drawn our ≈øhe put in her hand again and felt a lump in his body as big as a half-peny loaf, ≈øtrongly fa≈øtned to his back, and much ado ≈øhe had to pull it out; I found it to be a tuff bag, containing ≈øtuff like liver, and very heavie, at one end
of the bag, another little bag filled with a fatty matter, his gizard, liver, and heart wa≈øted. The Pipe or Roupe is a common di≈øea≈øe among≈øt their poultry infecting one another with it. I conceive it cometh of a cold moi≈øture of the brain, they will be very ≈øleepie with it, the be≈øt cure for it is Garlick, and ≈ømoaking of them with dryed Hy≈øope.

In September following my Arrivage in the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets about the twelfth hour of the eight day, I ≈øhipt my ≈øelf and goods in a Bark bound to the Ea≈øt-ward, meeting as we ≈øailed out the Dutch Governour of New-Netherlands, who was received and entertained at Bo≈øton by the Governour and Magi≈øtrates with great ≈øolemnity. About nine of the clock at night we came to Salem and lay aboard all night.
The Ninth day we went a≈øhore to view the Town which is a mile long, and lay that night at a Merchants hou≈øe.

The Tenth day we came from Salem about twelve of the clock back to Marble-head: here we went a≈øhore and recreated our ≈øelves with Mu≈øick and a cup of Sack and ≈øaw the Town, about ten at night we returned to our Bark and lay aboard.

The Eleventh being Saturday, and the wind contrary, we came to Charles-town,
again about twelve of the clock we took ≈øtore of Mackarel.

The Thirteenth being Monday, we went aboard again about nine of the clock in the morning and out to Sea, about Sun going down we took ≈øtore of Mackarel. The wind was ≈øcanty all along, and in the night time we dur≈øt not bear much ≈øail, becau≈øe of the Rocks and foaming breakers that lay in our way.

The Fourteenth day we came up with Pa≈øcataway, or Pa≈øcatique, where there is a large River and a fair harbour, within here is ≈øeated a Colony, properly belonging to the Heirs of Captain Ma≈øon ≈øometime ≈øince of London; but taken into the Colony of Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets, by what right I will not here di≈øcu≈øs.
The chiefe≈øt places of note are the Bay or Harbour North from Bo≈øton, on the We≈øt≈øide of the Harbour are built many fair hou≈øes, and ≈øo in another part called Strawberry-bank.

By the Harbour is an I≈øland which of late days is filled with buildings, be≈øides there are two Towns more ≈øeated up higher upon the River, the one called D ‚Ä¢ ver; the Riverbanks are clothed with ≈øtately Timber, and here are two miles meadow land and arable enough; the other town is called Exce≈øter.
At the River Pa≈øcataway begins the Province of Main: having plea≈øed our ≈øelves with the ≈øight of Pa≈øcataway at a di≈øtance we ≈øailed on, and came to Black-point.

The Fifteenth day, about eight of the clock at night, where the next day I was ≈øhrewdly pinched with a great fro≈øt, but having two or three bottles of excellent Pa≈ø≈øada, and good cheer be≈øtowed upon me I made a ≈øhift to bear it out, and now we are in the Province of Main.

The Province of Main, (or the Countrey of the Troquoes) heretofore called Laconia or New-Summer≈øet≈øhire, is a Colony belonging to the Grand≈øon of Sir Ferdinando Gorges of A≈øhton Phillips in the County of Sommer≈øet, the ≈øaid Sir Ferdinando Gorges did expend in planting ≈øeveral parts of New-England above Twenty thou≈øand pounds ≈øterling, and when he was between three and four ≈øcore years of age did per≈øonally engage in our Royal Martyrs ≈øervice; and particularly in the Seige of Bri≈øtow, and was plundered and impri≈øoned ≈øeveral times, by rea≈øon whereof he was di≈øcountenanced by the pretended Commi≈ø≈øioners for forraign plantations, and his Province incroached upon by the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets Colony, who a≈ø≈øumed the Government thereof. His Maje≈øtie that now Reigneth ≈øent over his Commi≈ø≈øioners
to reduce them within their bounds, and to put Mr. Gorges again into po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. But there falling out a conte≈øt about it, the Commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øettled it in the Kings name (until the bu≈øine≈øs ≈øhould be determined before his Maje≈øtie) and gave Commi≈ø≈øions to the Judge of their Courts, and the Ju≈øtices to Govern and Act according to the Laws of England, & by ≈øuch Laws of their own as were not repugnant to them: But as ≈øoon as the Commi≈ø≈øioners were returned for England, the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets enter the province in a ho≈øtile manner with a Troop of Hor≈øe and Poot and turn'd the Judge and his A≈ø≈øi≈øtants off the Bench, Impri≈øoned the Major or Commander of the Militia, threatned the Judge, and ≈øome others that were faithful to Mr. Gorges intere≈øts. I could di≈øcover many other foul proceedings, but for ≈øome rea≈øons which might be given, I conceive it not convenient to make report thereof to vulgar ears; & quae ≈øupra nos nihil ad nos. Onely this I could wi≈øh, that there might be ≈øome con≈øideration of the great lo≈ø≈øes, charge and labour, which hath been ≈øu≈øtained by the Judge, and ≈øome others for above thirty years in upholding the rights of Mr. Gorge and his Sacred Maje≈øties Dominion again≈øt a many ≈øtubborn and elu≈øive people.

Anno Dom. 1623. Mr. Robert Gorge, Sir Ferdinando Gorges brother had for his good ≈øervice granted him by Patent from the Council of Plimouth all that part of the Land commonly called Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øiack, ≈øituated on the North-≈øide of the Bay of Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets.
Not long after this Sir Ferdinando Gorges had granted to him by Patent from the midde≈øt of Merrimack River to the great River Sagadehock, then called Laconia.

In 1635. Capt. William Gorge, Sir Ferdinand ‚Ä¢
's Nephew, was ≈øent over Governour of the Province of Main, then called New-Summer≈øet≈øhire.

Sir Ferdinando Gorge received a Charter-Royal from King Charles the fir≈øt the third of April in the Fifttenth of his Raign, granting to him all that part and portion of New-England, lying and being between the River of Pa≈øcataway, that is, beginning at the entrance of Pa≈øcataway-harbour, and ≈øo to pa≈øs up the ≈øame into the River of Newichawanoe or Neqhechewanek, and th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ugh the ≈øame unto the farthe≈øt head thereof afore≈øaid, North-ea≈øtward along the Seacoa≈øts, for Sixty miles to Sagadehac-River to Kencheck, even as far as the head thereof, and up into the main land North-we≈øtward for the ≈øpace of one hundred and twenty
miles. To the≈øe Territories are adjoyned the North half-I≈øle of Sholes, with ≈øeveral other I≈ølands, it lyeth between 44 degrees and 45 of Northerly latitude. The River Canada on the North-ea≈øt the Sea coa≈øt South, among≈øt many large Royalties, Juri≈ødictions and Immunities was al≈øo granted to the ≈øaid Sir Ferdinando Gorge, the ≈øame Royalties, priviledges and franchi≈øes as are, or of right ought to be enjoyed by the Bi≈øhop of Durham in the County Palatine of Durham; the planters to pay for every hundred Acres of land yearly, two ≈øhillings ≈øix pence, that is ≈øuch land as is given to them and their Heirs for ever.

The Officers by Patent are a Deputy Governour, a Chancellor, a Trea≈øurer, a Mar≈øhal for Souldiers, and Admiraltie for Sea affairs, and a Judge of the Admiraltie, a M ‚Ä¢ ≈øter of Ordinance, a Secretary, &c.
Towns there are not many in this province. Kittery ≈øituated not far from Pa≈øcataway is the mo≈øt populous.
Next to that Ea≈øtward is ≈øeated by a River near the Sea Gorgiana, a Majoraltie, and the Metropolitan of the province.
Further to the Ea≈øtward is the Town of Wells.

Cape-Porpus Ea≈øtward of that, where there is a Town by the Sea ≈øide of the ≈øame name,
the hou≈øes ≈øcatteringly built, all the≈øe Towns have ≈øtore of ≈øalt and fre≈øh mar≈øh with arable land, and are well ≈øtockt with Cattle.
About eight or nine mile to the Ea≈øtward of Cape-Porpus, is Winter harbour, a noted place for Fi≈øhers, here they have many ≈øtages.
Saco adjoyns to this, and both make one ≈øcattering Town of large extent, well ≈øtored with Cattle, arable land and mar≈øhes, and a Saw-mill.

Six mile to the Ea≈øtward of Saco & forty mile from Gorgiana is ≈øeated the Town of Black-point, con≈øi≈øting of about fifty dwelling hou≈øes, and a Magazine or Dogonne, ≈øcatteringly built, they have ≈øtore of neat and hor≈øes, of ≈øheep near upon Seven or Eight hundred, much arable and mar≈øh ≈øalt and fre≈øh, and a Corn-mill.
To the Southward of the point (upon which are ≈øtages for fi≈øhermen) lye two ≈ømall I≈ølands beyond the point, North-ea≈øtward runs the River Spurwinch.

Four miles from Black-point, one mile from Spurwinch River Ea≈øtward lyeth Richmans-I≈øland, who≈øe longitude is 317 degrees 30 ≈øeconds, and latitude 43 degrees and 34 minutes, it is three mile in circumference, and hath a pa≈ø≈øable and gravelly ford on the
North-≈øide, between the main and the Sea: at low-water, here are found excellent Whet≈øtones, and here likewi≈øe are ≈øtages for fi≈øhermen.

Nine mile Ea≈øtward of Black-point lyeth ≈øcatteringly the Town of Ca≈øco upon a large Bay, ≈øtored with Cattle, Sheep, Swine, abundance of mar≈øh and Arable land, a Corn-mill or two, with ≈øtages for fi≈øhermen.
Further Ea≈øt-ward is the Town of Kenebeck ≈øcated upon the River.
Further yet Ea≈øt-ward is Sagadehock, where there are many hou≈øes ≈øcattering, and all along ≈øtages for fi≈øhermen, the≈øe too are ≈øtored with Cattle and Corn lands.

The mountains and hills that are to be taken notice of, are fir≈øt Acomentiens hills, between Kettery and Gorgiana, the high hills of O≈ø≈øapey to the We≈øt-ward of Saco River, where the princely Pilhanaw Ayries, the white mountains, to the North-ward of Black point, the highe≈øt Terra≈ø≈øe in New-England, you have the de≈øcription of it in my Treati≈øe of the rarities of New-England.

A Neighbour of mine ra≈øhly wandering out after ≈øome ≈øtray'd Cattle, lo≈øt his way, and coming as we conceived by his Relation near to the head ≈øpring of ≈øome of the branches of Black point River or Saco-River,
light into a Tract of land for God knowes how many miles full of delfes and dingles, and dangerous precipices, Rocks and inextricable difficulties which did ju≈øtly daunt, yea quite deter him from endeavouring to pa≈øs any further: many ≈øuch like places are to be met with in New-England.

The ponds or lakes in this province are very large and many, out of which the great Rivers have their original; we read of the lake Bal≈øena that is thirty miles about, here are that come very near to it, ≈øtored with all ≈øorts of fre≈øh water fi≈øh; and if you will believe report, in one of them huge fi≈øhes like Whales are to be ≈øeen, and ≈øome of them have fair I≈ølands in them. Twelve mile from Ca≈øco-bay, and pa≈ø≈øable for men and hor≈øes, is a lake called by the Indians Sebug, on the brink thereof at one end is the famous Rock ≈øhap'd like a Moo≈øe-Deere or Helk, Diaphanous, and called the Moo≈øe-Rock. Here are found ≈øtones like Cry≈øtal, and Lapis Specularis or Mu≈øcovia gla≈øs both white and purple.

On the Ea≈øt-≈øide of Black-point River upon a plain, clo≈øe to the Sea-bank is a pond two mile in compa≈øs, fi≈øh it produceth, but tho≈øe very ≈ømall and black, and a number of Frogs and Snakes, and much frequented
by wild-fowl, Ducks, Teal, and wild-Swins, and Gee≈øe, e≈øpecially ≈øpring and fall when they pa≈øs along to the Southward, and return again to the North-ward where they breed.

The principal Rivers in the province of Main, are Pa≈øcataway-River, York-River, Kenibunck-River, near to this River clay bullets were ca≈øt up by a mineral vapour, this River is by the Town of Wells. Then Saco-River on the Ea≈øt-≈øide of the Town, the ≈øhore Rockie all along on both ≈øides, where mu≈øick echoes from ≈øeveral places: ≈øeven miles up the River is a great fall where abundance of Salmon, and Lamprons are taken at the fall; a great way up, the River runs upon the Rock, in rupibus defendendo efficis rivos, he cutteth out Rivers among the Rocks, ≈øa ‚Ä¢ th Job, of the Almighty, Job 28.10. A litt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ above the fall is a ≈øaw-mill. Then Black-pant River d ‚Ä¢ vided into many branches; this as mo≈øt of the Rivers in New-England, is bar'd with a bank of Sand, where the Indians take Sturgeon and Ba≈ø≈øe. Spur-winck-River is next, which by his near approach to Black-point-river maketh that neck of land almo≈øt an I≈øland. Further Ea≈øt-ward is Kenebeck-river fifty leagues off of New-Plimouth Ea≈øt-ward, and Pechip≈øent famous
for multitudes of mighty large Sturgeon. The la≈øt river of the province Ea≈øt-ward is the great river Sagadehock where Sir John Pophams Colony ≈øeated them≈øelves.
The chief harbours are Cape-porpus, Winter harbour, in which are ≈øome ≈ømall I≈ølands, Black-point, Richmans-I≈øland, Ca≈øco-bay the large≈øt in the province full of I≈ølands.

From Sagadehock to Nova Scotia is called the Duke of Yorkes province, here Pemmaquid, Montinicus, Mobegan, Capeanawhagen, where Capt Smith fi≈øh ‚Ä¢ for Whales; Mu≈øcataquid, all fill'd with dwelling hou≈øes and ≈øtages for fi≈øhermen, and have plenty of Cattle, arable land and mar≈øhes.
Nova Scotia was ≈øold by the Lord Starling to the French, and is now wholly in their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.

Now we are come to New-found-land, which is over again≈øt the gulf of St. Lawrence, an I≈øland near as ≈øpacious as Ireland, and lyeth di≈øtant from the Continent as far as England is from the neare≈øt part of France, and near half the way between Ireland and Virginia, its longitude is 334 degrees 20 ≈øeconds, and North latitude 46 degrees 30 minutes, or as others will 53 minutes. The longitude of places are uncertainly reported, but in latitudes mo≈øt agree.
Longitude is the di≈øtance of the meridian of any place from the meridian which pa≈ø≈øeth over the I≈øles of Azores, where the beginning of longitude is ≈øaid to be. The meridian is a great circle dividing the Equinoctial at right Angles into two equal parts, pa≈ø≈øing al≈øo through both the Poles, and the Zenith, to which circle the Sun coming twice every 24 hours, maketh the middle of the day, and the middle of the night. Every place hath a ≈øeveral meridian, but they all meet in the poles of the world. Latitude is counted from the Equinoctial to the end of 30 degrees on each ≈øide thereof. The Equinoctial is a great circle imagined in the Heavens, al≈øo dividing the heavens into two equal parts, and lying ju≈øt in the middle betwixt the two poles, being in compa≈øs from We≈øt to Ea≈øt, 360 degrees, every degree thereof on the terre≈øtrial Globe valuing 20 Engli≈øh miles, or 60 miles.

Into the Bay of St. Lawrence the River of St. Lawrence or Canada di≈øimbogues it ≈øelf, a River far exceeding any River in the elder world, thirty or forty mile over at the mouth, and in the Channel one hundred fathom deep; it runs on the back-≈øide of New England and Virginia: the French (it is ≈øaid) have gone up ≈øix weeks voyage in it, and have not yet di≈øcovered the ≈øpring-head: the longitude is 334 degrees
11 ≈øeconds, in 50 degrees 21 minutes of North latitude. This may ≈øatisfie a mode≈øt Reader, and I hope yield no offence to any. I ≈øhall onely ≈øpeak a word or two of the people in the province of Main and the Dukes province, and ≈øo conclude.

The people in the province of Main may be divided into Magi≈øtrates, Husbandmen, or Planters, and fi≈øhermen; of the Magi≈øtrates ≈øome be Royali≈øts, the re≈øt perver≈øe Spirits, the like are the planters and fi≈øhers, of which ≈øome be planters and fi≈øhers both, others meer fi≈øhers.

Handicrafts-men there are but few, the Tumelor or Cooper, Smiths and Carpenters are be≈øt welcome among≈øt them, ≈øhopkeepers there are none, being ≈øupplied by the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets Merchants with all things they ≈øtand in need of, keeping here and there fair Magazines ≈øtored with Engli≈øh goods, but they ≈øet exce≈ø≈øive prices on them, if they do not gain Cent per Cent, they cry out that they are lo≈øers, hence Engli≈øh ≈øhooes are ≈øold for Eight and Nine ≈øhillings a pair, wor≈øted ≈øtockins of Three ≈øhillings ≈øix pence a pair, for Seven and Eight ≈øhillings a pair, Dougla≈øs that is ≈øold in England for one or two and twenty pence an ell, for four ≈øhillings a yard, Serges of two ≈øhillings or three ≈øhillings a yard, for Six and Seven
≈øhillings a yard, and ≈øo all ≈øorts of Commodities both for planters and fi≈øhermen, as Cables, Cordage, Anchors, Lines, Hooks, Nets, Canvas for Sails, &c. Bisket twenty five ≈øhillings a hundred, Salt at an exce≈ø≈øive rate, pickled-herrin for winter bait Four and five pound a barrel (with which they ≈øpeed not ≈øo well as the waggi≈øh lad at Cape-porpus, who baited his hooks with the drown'd Negro's buttocks) ≈øo for Pork and Beef.

The planters are or ≈øhould be re≈øtle≈øs pains takers, providing for their Cattle, planting and ≈øowing of Corn, fencing their grounds, cutting and bringing home fuel, cleaving of claw-board and pipe-≈øtaves, fi≈øhing for fre≈øh water fi≈øh and fowling takes up mo≈øt of their time, if not all; the diligent hand maketh rich, but if they be of a droani≈øh di≈øpo≈øition as ≈øome are, they become wretchedly poor and mi≈øerable, ≈øcarce able to free them≈øelves and family from importunate famine, e≈øpecially in the winter for want of bread.

They have a cu≈øtom of taking Tobacco, ≈øleeping at noon, ≈øitting long at meals ≈øometimes four times in a day, and now and then drinking a dram of the bottle extraodinarily: the ≈ømoaking of Tobacco, if moderately u≈øed refre≈øheth the weary much, and ≈øo doth ≈øleep.

q.l: A Traveller five hours doth crave
To ≈øleep, a Student ≈øeven will have,
And nine ≈øleeps every Idle knave.

div.p: The Phy≈øician allowes but three draugh ‚Ä¢ s at a meal, the fir≈øt for need, the ≈øecond for plea≈øure, and the third for ≈øleep; but little ob≈øerved by them, unle≈øs they have no other liquor to drink but water. In ≈øome places where the ≈øprings are frozen up, or at lea≈øt the way to their ≈øprings made unpa≈ø≈øable by rea≈øon of the ≈ønow and the like, they dre≈øs their meat in Aqua Caele≈øtis, i. e. melted ≈ønow, at other times it is very well cookt, and they feed upon (generally) as good fle≈øh, Beef, Pork, Mutton, Fowl and fi≈øh as any is in the whole world be≈øides.

Their Servants which are for the mo≈øt part Engli≈øh, when they are out of their time, will not work under half a Crown day, although it be for to make hay, and for le≈øs I do not ≈øee how they can, by rea≈øon of the dearne≈øs of clothing. If they hire them by the year, they pay them Fourteen or Fifteen pound, yea Twenty pound at the years end in Corn, Cattle and fi≈øh: ≈øome of the≈øe prove excellent fowlers, bringing in as many as will maintain their ma≈øters hou≈øe; be≈øides the profit that accrews by their feathers.
They u≈øe (when it is to be had) a great round ≈øhot, called Bar≈øtable ≈øhot, (which is be≈øt for fowl) made of a lead blacker than our common lead, to ≈øix pound of ≈øhot they allow one pound of powder, Cannon powder is e≈øteemed be≈øt.

The fi≈øhermen take yearly upon the coa≈øts many hundred kentals of Cod, hake, haddock, polluck &c. which they ≈øplit, ≈øalt and dry at their ≈øtages, making three voyages in a year. When they ≈øhare their fi≈øh (which is at the end of every voyage) they ≈øeparate the be≈øt from the wor≈øt, the fir≈øt they call M ‚Ä¢ rchantable fi≈øh, being ≈øound, full grown fi≈øh and well made up, which is known when it is clear like a Lanthorn horn and without ≈øpots; the ≈øecond ≈øort they call refu≈øe fi≈øh, that is ≈øuch as is ≈øalt burnt, ≈øpotted, rotten, and carele≈øly ordered: the≈øe they put off to the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets Merchants; the merchantable for thirty and two and thirty ryals a kental, (a kental is an hundred and twelve pound weight) the refu≈øe for Nine ≈øhillings and Ten ≈øhillings a kental, the Merchant ≈øends the merchantable fi≈øh to Lisbanne, Bilbo, Burdeaux, Mar≈øiles, Tallo ‚Ä¢ n, Rochel, ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ an, and other Cities of France, to the Canaries with cla ‚Ä¢ -board and pipe≈øtaves which is there and at the Charibs a prime Commodity: the refu≈øe fi≈øh they put
off at the Charib-I≈ølands, Barbadoes, Jamaica, &c. who ≈øeed their Negroes with it.

To every Shallop belong four fi≈øhermen, a Ma≈øter or Steer≈øman, a Mid≈øhip-man, and a Forema≈øt-man, and a ≈øhore man who wa≈øhes it out of the ≈øalt, and dries it upon hurdles pitcht upon ≈øtakes brea≈øt high and tends their Cookery; the≈øe often get in one voyage Eight or Nine pound a man for their ≈øhares, but it doth ≈øome of them little good, for the Merchant to increa≈øe his gains by putting off his Commodity in the mid≈øt of their voyages, and at the end thereof comes in with a walking Tavern, a Bark laden with the Legitimate bloud of the rich grape, which they bring from Phial, Madera, Canaries, with Brandy, Rhum, the Barbadoes ≈øtrong-water, and Tobacco, coming a≈øhore he gives them a Ta≈øter or two, which ≈øo charms them, that for no per≈øwa≈øions that their imployers can u≈øe will they go out to Sea, although fair and ≈øea≈øonable weather, for two or three days, nay ≈øometimes a whole week till they are wearied with drinking, taking a≈øhore two or three Hog≈øheads of Wine and Rhum to drink off when the Merchant is gone. If a man of quality chance to come where they are roy≈øtering and gulling in Wine with a dear ≈øelicity, he mu≈øt be ≈øociable and Roly-poly with them, taking off
their liberal cups as freely, or el≈øe be gone, which is be≈øt for him, for when Wine in their guts is at full Tide, they quarrel, fight and do one another mi≈øchief, which is the conclu≈øion of their drunken compotations. When the day of payment comes, they may ju≈øtly complain of their co≈øtly ≈øin of drunkenne≈øs, for their ≈øhares will do no more than pay the reckoning; if they ≈øave a Kental or two to buy ≈øhoo ‚Ä¢ s and ≈øtockins, ≈øhirts and wa≈øtcoats w ‚Ä¢ th, 'tis well, otherwayes they mu≈øt enter into the Merchants books for ≈øuch things as they ≈øtand in need off, becoming thereby the Merchants ≈ølaves, & when it ri≈øeth to a big ≈øum are con≈øtrained to mortgage their plantation if they have any, the Merchant when the time is expired is ≈øure to ≈øeize upon their plantation and ≈øtock of Cartle, turning them out of hou≈øe and home, poor Creatures, ‚Ä¢ o look out for a new habitation in ≈øome remote place where they begin the world again. The lavi≈øh planters have the ≈øame fate, partaking with them in the like bad husbandry, of the≈øe the Merchant buys Beef, Pork. Pea≈øe, Wheat and Indian Corn, and ≈ø ‚Ä¢ lls it again many times to the fi≈øhermen. Of the ≈øame nature are the people in the Dekes province, who not long before I left the Countrey petitioned the Governour and Magi≈øtrates in
the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets to take them into their Government, Birds of a feather will ralley together.

Anno Dom. 1671. The year being now well ≈øpent, and the Government of the province turned top≈øi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ vy, being heartily weary and expecting the approach of winter, I took my leave of my friends at Black-paint. And on the 28 of Augu≈øt being Monday I ≈øhipt my ≈øelf and my goods aboard of a ≈øhall ‚Ä¢ p bound for Bo≈øton: towards Sun ≈øet, ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e wind being contrary, we put into Gibb ‚Ä¢ ns his I≈øland, a ≈ømall I≈øland in Winner harbour
‚Ä¢ bout two leagues from black-point We≈øt-ward, here we ≈øtayed till the 30. day being Wedne≈øday, about nine of the clock we ≈øet ≈øail, and towards Sun-≈øet came up with Gorgiana, the 31 day being Thur≈øday we put into Cape-Ann-harbour about Su ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t. September the 1 being Saturday in the morning before day we ≈øe ‚Ä¢ ≈øail and came to Bo≈øton about three of the clock in the afternoon, where I ‚Ä¢ ound the Inhabitants exceedingly ‚Ä¢ ffl ‚Ä¢ cted with griping of the guts, and Heaver, and Ague, and bloudy Flux.

The Eight day of October being Wedne≈øday, I boarded the new-Supply of Bo≈øton 1 ‚Ä¢ 0 Tun, a Ship of better ≈øa ‚Ä¢ l than defence, her Guns being ≈ømall, and for ≈øalutation only, the Ma≈øter Capt. Fairweather, her
≈øailers 16. and as many pa≈ø≈øengers. Towards night I returned to Bo≈øton again, the next day being Thank≈øgiving day, on Fryday the Tenth day we weighed Anchor and fell down to Hull.

The 12 and 13 day about 20 leagues from Cape-Sable a bitter ≈øtorm took us, beginning at ≈øeven of the clock at night, which put us in terrible fear of being driven upon the Cape, or the I≈øland of Sables where many a tall ≈øhip hath been wrackt.

November the One and twenty about two of the clock afternoon we ≈øaw within kenning before us thick clouds, which put us in hope of land, the Bo≈øon brings out his pur≈øe, into which the pa≈ø≈øengers put their good will, then pre≈øently he nails it to the main-ma≈øt, up go the boyes to the mainma≈øt-top ≈øitting there like ≈øo many Crowes, when after a while one of them cryes out land, which was glad tidings to the wearied pa≈ø≈øengers, the boyes de≈øcend, and the pur≈øe being taken from the ma≈øt was di≈øtributed among≈øt them, the lad that fir≈øt de≈øcryed land having a double ≈øhare: about three of the clock Scilly was three leagues off.

The Four and twentieth day we came to Deal, from thence the 25. to Lee, the 26. being Sunday we ≈øteemed the Tide to Grave≈øend, about two of the clock afternoon.
The 27 we came up with Wollich where I landed and refre≈øht my ≈øelf for that night, next day I footed it four or five miles to Bexley in Kent to vi≈øit a near kin≈øman, the next day proved rainie, the 30 day being Fryday my kin≈øman accommodated me with a Hor≈øe and his man to Greenwich, where I took a pair of Oars and went aboard our Ship then lying before Radeliff, here I lay that night. Next day being Saturday, and the fir≈øt of December I cleared my goods, ≈øhot the bridge and landed at the Temple about ≈øeven of the clock at night, which makes my voyage homeward 7 weeks and four days, and from my fir≈øt ≈øetting out from London to my returning to London again Eight years Six moneths and odd days.

Now by the merciful providence of the Almighty, having perform'd Two voyages to the North-ea≈øt parts of the We≈øtern-world, I am ≈øafely arrived in my Native Countrey; having in part made good the French proverb, Travail where thou can≈øt, but dye where thou oughte≈øt, that is, in thine own Countrey.
Chronological OBSERVATIONS OF AMERICA, From the year of the World to the year of Chri≈øt, 1673.

LONDON: Printed for Giles Widdowes, at the Green- „Äà‚óä„Äâ
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
Paul's-Church-yard 1674.

div.head: The Preface.
div.p:
THE Terre≈øtrial World is by our learned Geographers divided into four parts, Europe, A≈øia, Africa and America ≈øo named from Americus Ve≈øpucius the Florentine, Seven years after Columbus; although Columbus and Cabota de≈øerved rather the honour of being Godfathers to it: notwith≈øtanding by this name it is now known to us, but was utterly unknown to the Ancient Europeans before their times, I will not ≈øay to the Africans and A≈øians, for Plato in his Timeus relateth of a great I≈øland, called Atlantis, and Philo the Jew in his book De mundo, that it was over-flowen with water, by rea≈øon of a mighty Earthquake; The like happened
to it 600 years before Plato: thus was the Atlantick Ocean, cau≈øed to be a Sea, if you will believe the ≈øame Philo≈øopher, who flouri≈øhed 366 years before the Birth of our Saviour.

America is bounded on the South with the ≈øtreight of Magellan, where there are many I≈ølands di≈øtingui≈øhed by an interflowing Bay; the We≈øt with the pacifique Sea, or mare-del-zur, which Sea runs towards the North, ≈øeparateing it from the Ea≈øt parts of A≈øia; on the Ea≈øt with the Atlantick, or our we≈øtern Ocean called mare-del-Nort; and on the North with the Sea that ≈øeparateth it from Groveland, thorow which Seas the ≈øuppo≈øed pa≈ø≈øage to China lyeth; the≈øe North parts, as yet are but barely di≈øcovered by our voyagers.

The length of this new World between the ≈øtreights of Anian and Magellan is 2400 German miles, in breadth between Cabo de fortuna near the Anian ≈øtreights is 1300 German n ‚Ä¢ tles. About 18 leagues from Nombre
de dios, on the South-Sea lyeth Panama (a City having three fair Mena≈øteri ‚Ä¢ s in it) where the narrowe≈øt part of the Countrey is, it is much le≈øs than A≈øia, and far bigger than Europe, and as the re≈øt of the world divided into I≈ølands and Continent, the Continent ≈øuppo≈øed to contain about 1152400000 Acres.

The Native people I have ≈øpoken of already: The di≈øcoverers and Planters of Colonies, e≈øpecially in the Northea≈øt parts; together with a continuation of the proceedings of the Engli≈øh in New-England, from the fir≈øt year of their ≈øetling there to purpo≈øe, to this pre≈øent year of our Lord 1673. with many other things by the way in≈øerted and worth the ob≈øerving I pre≈øent unto your view in this en≈øuing Table.

Anno Mundi 3720 Britain known to the Graecians as appeared by Polybius the Greek Hi≈øtorian 265 years before the Birth of our Saviour, & after him Athenaeus a Greek Author of good account 170 before Chri≈øt, relateth that Hiero ≈øent for a ma≈øt for a great Ship that he had built to Britain.
Anno Mundi 3740 Hanno the Carthaginian flouri≈øhed, who ≈øent to di≈øcover the great I≈øland Atlantis, i. e. America.

Anno Mundi 3873 Britain unknown to the Romans was fir≈øt di≈øcovered to them by Julius Cae≈øar, 54 years before the Birth of Chri≈øt, who took it to be part of the Continent of France, and got nothing but the ≈øight of that part called afterwards England, which is the South of Britain.
Anno Domini 86 Britain di≈øcovered to be an I≈øland, and conquered by Julius Agricola 136. years after Julius Cae≈øars entrance into it.
Anno Domini 99 The Emperour Trajan flouri≈øhed and ≈øtretched the Confines of the Roman Enpire, unto the remote≈øt Dominions of the Ea≈øt-Indies, who never before that time had heard of a Roman.

Anno Domini 745 Boniface Bi≈øhop of Mens a City in Germany, was accu≈øed before Pope Zachary in the time of Ethelred King of the Ea≈øt-Angles for Here≈øie, &c. in that he averred there were Antipodes. St. Augu≈øtine and Lactantius opinion was that there were none.
Anno Domini 827 Egbert the Saxon Monarch changed the name of the people in England, and called them Engli≈øh-men.
Anno Domini 844 The Turks or Scythians came from thence in the time of Ethelwolf King of the We≈øt-Saxons. If the Ottoman-line ≈øhould fail, the Chrim Tartar is to ≈øucceed, being both of one Family.

Anno Domini 959 Edgar Sirnamed the Peaceable, the 30 Monarch of the Engli≈øh, cau≈øed the Wolves to be de≈øtroyed by impo≈øing a Tribute upon the Princes of Wales; and Fage Prince of North-Wales paid him yearly 300 Wolves,
which continued three years ≈øpace, in the fourth year there was not a Wolf to be found, and ≈øo the Tribute cea≈øed.
Anno Domini 1160 In the Emperours Frederick Barbaro≈ø≈øa's time, certain We≈øt-Indians came into Germany.
Anno Domini 1170 Madoc the Son of Owen Gwineth Prince of North-Wales his voyage to the We≈øt-Indies, he planted a Colony in the We≈øtern part of the Countrey, in our Henry the Seconds Raign.
Anno Domini 1300 Flavio of Malphi in Naples invented the Compa≈øs in our Edward the fir≈øts time.
Anno Domini 1330 The Canaries di≈øcovered by an Engli≈øh Ship.
Anno Domini 1337 In Edward the third's time a Comet appeared, continuing 30 days.
Anno Domini 1344 Machan an Engli≈øh-man accidentally di≈øcovered Madera-I≈øland.
Anno Domini 1350 E≈øtotiland di≈øcovered by fi≈øhermen of Freez-land, in Edward the third's Raign.

Anno Domini 1360 The Franci≈øcan-Fryer Nicholas de Linne,
who is ≈øaid to di≈øcover the Pole by his black Art, went thither in the Raign of Edward the Third.
Anno Domini 1372 Sir John Mandivel, the Great Traveller dyed at Leige a City in the Netherland Provinces in Edward the Third's Raign.
Anno Domini 1380 Nicholas and Antonio Zeni, two Noble Gentlemen of Venice were driven by Tempe≈øt upon the I≈øland of E≈øtotiland or Gronland, in our Edward the Third's Raign.
Anno Domini 1417 The Canaries Conquered by Betan-Court a Frenchman.
Anno Domini 1420 The I≈øland of Madera di≈øcovered in our Henry the Fifth's time.

Anno Domini 1428 The I≈øland Puerto Santo, or Holy-port di≈øtant from Madera 40 miles, di≈øcovered by Portingal Mariners on All-hallowes-day, and therefore called Holy-port, it is in compa≈øs 150 miles, in Henry the Sixth's Raign.
Anno Domini 1440 The I≈øland of Cape de verd di≈øcovered.
Anno Domini 1452 The Marine parts of Guinea di≈øcovered by the Portingals in Henry the Sixth's Raign.
Anno Domini 1478 Ferdinando fir≈øt Monarch of all Spain.
Anno Domini 1485 Henry the Seventh began to Raign.
Anno Domini 1486 The Kingdom of Angola and Congo, with the I≈ølands of St. George, St. James and St. Helens di≈øcovered.
Anno Domini 1488 Chri≈øtopher Columbus a Genoue≈øe offered the di≈øcovery of the We≈øt-Indies to Henry the Seventh.
Anno Domini 1492 Chri≈øtopher Columbus ≈øent to di≈øcover the We≈øt-Indies by Ferdinando King of Arragon, and I≈øabella Queen of Ca≈øtile, who de≈øcended from Edward the Third King of England.

The Caribby-I≈ølands the Antilles or Cani
‚Ä¢ al, or Camerean-I≈ølands now di≈øcovered by Chri≈øtopher Columbus, and took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Florida and Hi≈øpaniola for the King of Spain.

Anno Domini 1493 Alexander the Sixt Pope of Rome a Spa
‚Ä¢ iard, took upon him to divide the world ‚Ä¢ y his Bull, betwixt the Portingal and the
‚Ä¢ paniard, bearing date the fourth of May,
‚Ä¢ iving to the one the Ea≈øt, and to the other ‚Ä¢ he We≈øt-Indies.
St. Jean Porto Rico di≈øcovered by Chri≈øtopher Columbus, Cuba and Jamaica di≈øcovered by him, this was his ≈øecond voyage.
Anno Domini 1495 Seba≈øtian Cabota the fir≈øt that attempted to di≈øcover the North-we≈øt pa≈ø≈øage at the charge of Henry the Seventh.
Anno Domini 1497 Chri≈øtopher Columbus his third voyage to the We≈øt-Indies, and now he di≈øcovered the Countreys of Paria and Cumana, with the I≈ølands of Cubagua and Margarita.

John Cabota and his Son Seba≈øtian Cabota ≈øent by Henry the Seventh, to di≈øcover the We≈øt-Indies, which they performed from the Cape of Florida to the 67 degree and a half of Northerly latitude, being ≈øaid by ≈øome to be the fir≈øt that di≈øcovered Florida, Virginia, and New-found-land.
Va≈øques de Gama his voyage to Africa.
Anno Domini 1500 Chri≈øtopher Columbus his fourth and la≈øt voyage to the We≈øt-Indies.
Ja≈øper Corteriaglis a Portugal, his voyage to di≈øcover the North-We≈øt pa≈ø≈øage, he di≈øcovered Greenland, or Terra Corteriaglis, or Terra di Laborodoro.

Anno Domini 1501 Amerious Ve≈øputius a Florentine imployed by the King of Ca≈øtile and Portingal, to di≈øcover
the We≈øt-Indies, named from him Seven year after Columbus, America.
Anno Domini 1506 Chri≈øtopher Columbus dyed.
Anno Domini 1508 Henry the Seventh dyed Augu≈øt the Two and twentieth.
Henry the Eighth King of England.
Anno Domini 1514 Seba≈øtian Cabota, the Son of John made further di≈øcovery of all the North-ea≈øt coa≈øts from Cape Florida to New-found-land, and Terra Laborador.
Anno Domini 1516 The voyage of Sir Thomas Pert Vice-Admiral of England, and Seba≈øtian Cabota, the Eighth of Henry the Eighth to Bra≈øil, St. Domingo, and St. Juan de puerto rico.
Anno Domini 1520 Ferdinando Magellano a noble Portingal ≈øet forth to ≈øail about the world, but was 1521 unfortunately ≈ølain.

Anno Domini 1522 The Bermuduz-I≈øle 400 in number, being 500 miles di≈øtant from Virginia, a ‚Ä¢ d 3300 miles from the City of London in the latitude 32 degrees and 30 minutes, di≈øcovered now accidentally by John Bermuduz a Spaniard.
Anno Domini 1523 Stephen Gomez his voyage to di≈øcover the North-we≈øt pa≈ø≈øage, ≈øome will have it in Twenty five.
Anno Domini 1527 New-found-land di≈øcovered by one Andrew Thorn, the Southern part but 600 leagues from England.
John de Ponce for the Spaniard took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Florida.
Anno Domini 1528 Nevis or Mevis planted now according to ≈øome writers.
Anno Domini 1534 Califormia que≈øtioned, ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ther I≈øland or Continent, fir≈øt di≈øcovered be the Spaniard.
Nova Francia lying between the 40 and 50 degree of the Artic-poles Altitude di≈øcovered by Jaques Carthier in his fir≈øt voyage, the fir≈øt Colony planted in Canada.
Anno Domini 1536 The Puritan-Church policy began now in Geneva.
Anno Domini 1542 Mon≈øieur du Barvals voyage to Nova Francia, ≈øent to inhabite tho≈øe parts.
Anno Domini 1548 Henry the Eighth dyed.
Edward the Sixth King of England began to Raign.
Seba≈øtian Cabota made grand Pilot of England by Edward the Sixth.
Anno Domini 1550 The ≈øweating ≈øickne≈øs in England.
Anno Domini 1553 Edward the Sixth dyed.
Mary Queen of England began to Raign.
Sir Hugh Willoughby, and all his men in two Ships in his fir≈øt attempt to di≈øcover the North-ea≈øt pa≈ø≈øage, were in October frozen to death in the Haven called Arzima in Lapland.
Anno Domini 1558 Queen Mary dyed.
Elizabeth Queen of England began to Raign November the Seventeenth.
Anno Domini 1560 Salvaterra a Spaniard his voyage to the North-we≈øt pa≈ø≈øage.
Anno Domini 1562 Sir John Hawkin's fir≈øt voyage to the We≈øt-Indies.
The fir≈øt expedition of the French into Florida, undertaken by John Ribald.
Anno Domini 1565 Tobacco fir≈øt brought into England by Sir John Hawkins, but it was fir≈øt brought into u≈øe by Sir Walter Rawleigh many years after.
Anno Domini 1566 The Puritans began to appear in England.
Anno Domini 1569 Anthony Jenkin≈øon the fir≈øt of the Engli≈øh that ≈øailed through the Ca≈øpian-Sea.
Anno Domini 1572 Private Presbyteries now fir≈øt erected in England.
Sir Francis Drake's fir≈øt voyage to the We≈øt-Indies.
Anno Domini 1573 The Hollanders ≈øeek for aid from Queen Elizabeth.

Anno Domini 1576 Sir Martin Frobi≈øher the fir≈øt in Queen Elizabeths days that ≈øought for the Northwe≈øt pa≈ø≈øage, or the ≈øtreight, or pa≈ø≈øage to China, and meta incognita, in three ≈øeveral voyages, others will have it in 1577.

Anno Domini 1577 November the 17 Sir Francis Drake began his voyage about the world with five Ships, and 164 men ≈øetting ≈øail from Plimouth, putting off Cape de verde. The beginning of February, he ≈øaw no Land till the fifth of April, being pa≈øt the line 30 degrees of latitude, and in the 36 degree entered the River Plates) whence he fell with the ≈øtreight of Magellan the 21 of Augu≈øt, which with three of his Ships he pa≈ø≈øed, having ca≈øt off the other two as impediments to him, and the Marigold to≈ø≈øed from her General after
pa≈ø≈øage was no more ≈øeen. The other commanded by Capt. Winter ≈øhaken off al≈øo by Tempe≈øt, returned thorow the Streights and recovered England, only the Pellican, whereof him≈øelf was Admiral, held on her cour≈øe to Chile, Coquimbo, Cinnama, Palma, Lima, upon the we≈øt of America, where he pa≈ø≈øed the line 1579 the fir≈øt day of March, and ≈øo forth until he came to the latitude 47. Thinking by tho≈øe North Seas to have found pa≈ø≈øage to England, but fogs, fro≈øts and cold winds forced him to turn his cour≈øe South-we≈øt from thence, and came to Anchor 38 degrees from the line, where the King of that Countrey pre≈øented him his Net-work Crown of many coloured feathers, and therewith re≈øigned his Scepter of Government unto his Dominion, which Countrey Sir Francis Drake took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of in the Queens name, and named it Nova Albion, which is thought to be part of the I≈øland of Califormia.
Sir Martin Frobi≈øher's ≈øecond voyage.
Anno Domini 1578 Sir Humphrey Gilbert a Devon≈øhire Knight attempted to di≈øcover Virginia, but without ≈øucce≈øs.
Sir Martin Frobi≈øher's third voyage to Meta incognita. Freezeland now called We≈øt-England, 25 leagues in length, in the latitude of 57.
Sir Francis Drake now pa≈ø≈øed the Streights of Magellan in the Ship called the Pellican.
Anno Domini 1579 Sir Francis Drake di≈øcovered Nova Albion in the South-Sea.
Others will have Sir Martin Frobi≈øher's fir≈øt voyage to di≈øcover the North-we≈øt pa≈ø≈øage to be this year.

Anno Domini 1580 From Nova Albion he fell with Ternate, one of the I≈øles of Molucco, being courteou≈øly entertained of the King, and from thence he came unto the I≈øles of Calebes, to Java Major, to Cape buona ≈øperanza, and fell with the coa≈øts of Guinea, where cro≈ø≈øing again the line, he came to the height of the Az ‚Ä¢ res, and thence to England upon the third of November 1580. after three years lacking twelve days, and was Knighted, and his Ship laid up at Deptford as a monument of his fame.
Anno Domini 1581 The Provinces of Holland again ≈øeek for aid to the Queen of England.

Anno Domini 1582 Sir Humphrey Gilbert took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of New found-land or Terra Nova, in the harbour of St. John, for and in the name of
Queen Elizabeth, it lyeth over again≈øt the gulf of St. Lawrence, and is between 46 and 53 degrees of the North-poles Altitude.
Anno Domini 1583 Sir Walter Rawleigh in Ireland.
Sir Humphrey Gilbert attempted a plantation in ≈øome remote parts in New-England.
He peri≈øhed in his return from New-found-land.
Anno Domini 1584 The woful year of ≈øub≈øcription ≈øo called by the Brethren, or Di≈øciplinarians.

Sir Walter Rawleigh obtained of Queen Elizabeth a Patent for the di≈øcovery and peopling of unknown Countries, not actually po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by any Chri≈øtian Prince. Dated March 25. in the ≈øix and twentieth of her Raign,

April the 27 following, he ≈øet forth two Barkes under the Command of Mr. Philip Amedas and Mr. Arthur Barlow, who arrived on that part of America, which that Virgin Queen named Virginia, and thereof in her Maje≈øties name took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion July the Thirteenth.
Anno Domini 1585 Cautionary Towns and Forts in the low-Countreys delivered unto Queen Elizabeths hands.

Sir Richard Greenvile was ≈øent by Sir
Walter Rawleigh April the Ninth, with a Fleet of 7 ≈øail to Virginia, and was ≈øtiled the General of Virginia. He landed in the I≈øland of St. John de porto Rico May the Twelfth, and there fortified them≈øelves and built a Pinna≈ø≈øe, &c. In Virginia they left 100 men under the Government of Mr. Ralph Lane, and others.
Sir Francis Drake's voyage to the We≈øt-Indies, wherein were ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ken the Cities of St. Jago, St. Domingo Cartagena, and the Town of St. Augu≈øtine in Florida.
Now (≈øay ≈øome) Tobacco was fir≈øt brought into England by Mr. Ralph Lane out of Virginia.
Others will have Tobacco to be fir≈øt brought into England from Peru, by Sir Francis Drake's Mariners.

June the 20 a damnable cheat like to have been put upon England by a Brief for New-England,
which as it appeared was produced before the King came in, but not printed (by Mr. Leach in Shoe-lane) till June, pretending that 18 Turks-men of War the 24 of January 1653/60 landed at a Town, called Kingsword (alluding to Charles-town) three miles from Bo≈øton, kill'd 40, took Mr. Sims mini≈øter pri≈øoner, wounded him, kill'd his wife and three of his little children, carried him away with 57 more, burnt the Town, carried them to Argier, their lo≈øs amounting to 12000 pound, the Turk demanding 8000 pound ran≈øom to be paid within 7 moneths. Signed by Thomas Margets, Edward Calamy, William Jenkin, William Vincent, George Wind, Jo≈øeph Caryl, John Menord, William Cooper, Thomas Manton Mini≈øters.
Hugh Peters put to death the 16 of October.
Thomas Venner a Wine-Cooper hang'd drawn and quartered Ian. 19.

Mr. Thomas Prince cho≈øen Governour of new Plimouth colony.
Mr. John Endicot cho≈øen Governour of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets colony, Mr. Bellingham Deputy.

Mr. Samuel Stone Teacher of Hartford Church in New-England, now dyed al≈øo.

Charles Chancie batchelor of Divinity, and Pre≈øident of Harvard-Colledge in New-England.
Anno Domini 1664 Mr. Thomas Prince cho≈øen Governour of new-Plimouth colony.
Mr. John Endicot cho≈øen Governour of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets colony, Mr. Francis Willowby Deputy Governour, Mr. Thomas Leveret Major General.

May the 20 the Kings Commi≈ø≈øioners arrived in New-England, viz. Sir Robert Carr, Colonel Nicols, Colonel Cartwright and Mr. Samuel Maverich, with whom came one Mr. Archdale as Agent for Mr. Ferdinando Gorges, who brought to the colony in the province of Main, Mr. F. Gorges order from his Maje≈øty Charles the Second, under his man ‚Ä¢ al, and his Maje≈øties Letters to the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets concerning the ≈øame, to be re≈øtored unto the quiet po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and enjoyment of the ≈øaid province in New-England, and the Government thereof, the which during the civil Wars in England the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets colony had u≈øurpt, and (by help of a Jacobs ≈øtaff) mo≈øt ≈øhamefully encroached upon Mr. Gorges rights and priviledges.

The 29 of Augu≈øt, the Manadaes, called Novede Belgique, or New Netherlands, their chief Town New-Am≈øterdam, now called
New-Yorke, Surrendered up unto Sir Robert Carr and Colonel Nichols his Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners; thirteen days after in September the Fort and Town of Arania now called Albany; twelve days after that, the Fort and Town of Aw≈øapha; then de la Ware Ca≈øtle man'd with Dutch and Sweeds, the three fir≈øt Forts and Towns being built upon the River Mehegan, otherwi≈øe called Hud≈øons River.
The whole Bible Tran≈ølated into the Indian-Tongue, by Mr. Johu Eliot Senior, was now printed at Cambridge in New-England.

December a great and dreadful Comet, or blazing-≈øtar appeared in the South-ea≈øt in New-England for the ≈øpace of three moneths, which was accompanied with many ≈øad effects, great mildews bla≈øting in the Countrey the next Summer.
Anno Domini 1665 Mr. Thomas Prince cho≈øen Governour of new-Plimouth colony.
Mr. John Endicot cho≈øen Governour of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets colony, Mr. Francis Willowby Deputy Governour, Mr. Leveret Major General.

Mr. John Endicot Governour of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets
colony decea≈øed, March the three and twentieth.
Capt. Davenport kill'd with lightning as he lay on his bed at the Ca≈øtle by Bo≈øton in New-England, and ≈øeveral wounded.

Three kill'd in a moment by a blow of Thunder at Mar≈øhfield in New-Plimouth
colony, and four at Pa≈øcataway colony, and divers burnt with lightning, a great whirlwind at the ≈øame time.

Anno Domini 1668 Mr. Thomas Prince cho≈øen Governour of New-Plimouth colony.
Mr. Richard Bellingham cho≈øen Governour of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets colony, Mr. Fr. Willowby Deputy Governour, and Mr. Leveret major General.

At a place called Kenebunch, which is in the Province of Main, not far from the River-≈øide, a piece of clay ground was thrown up by a mineral vapour (as was ≈øuppo≈øed) over the tops of high oaks that grew between it and the River, into the River, ≈øtopping the cour≈øe thereof, and leaving a hole Forty yards ≈øquare, wherein
were Thou≈øands of clay bullets as big as mu≈øquet bullets, and pieces of clay in ≈øhape like the barrel of a mu≈øquet. The like accident fell out at Ca≈øco, One and twenty miles from it to the Ea≈øtward, much about the ≈øame time; And fi≈øh in ≈øome ponds in the Countrey thrown up dead upon the banks, ≈øuppo≈øed likewi≈øe to be kill'd with mineral vapours.
A wonderful number of Herrins ca≈øt up on ≈øhore at high water in Black-point-Harbour in the province of Main, ≈øo that they might have gone half way the leg in them for a mile together.
Mr. Thatcher cho≈øen Pa≈øtor of the Pre≈øbyterian Church at Bo≈øton.

Mr. Richard Bellingham cho≈øen Governour of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets colony, Mr. Leveret D ‚Ä¢ puty, and major General.
Elder Pen now dyed at Bo≈øton, the Engli≈øh troubled much with griping of the guts, and bloudy Flux, of which ≈øeveral dyed.

October the Two and twentieth a Ship called the flying Falcon of Am≈øterdam, arrived at Dover, having been out ≈øince the fir≈øt of January 1669, and been in the South-Seas
in the latitude of 50 degrees, having ≈øailed 12900 Dutch leagues, the ma≈øter told us he made main land, and di≈øcovered two I≈ølands never before di≈øcovered, where were men all hairy, Eleven foot in height.
